text: Good drivers covered by high-risk automobile insurers may find it hard to overcome that stigma when seeking new coverage from a standard insurer, a new analysis suggests.

headline: Review: Reanimating an Autistic Artist With ‘Soot and Spit’
text: It’s a strange medium for an artist to work in, but soot and spit were what James Castle used in place of ink or watercolors, beginning as a child in the early 1900s. Profoundly deaf and autistic, he refused to learn language when he was sent away to school, yet he was resourcefully, voraciously creative.

headline: For Carl Reiner and His Fellow Nonagenarians, Death Can Wait
text: The title of Carl Reiner’s most recent book is “Too Busy to Die,” and this 95-year-old comedy legend can thank his vivid dreams for inspiring many of the (sometimes wacky) ideas that keep him going.

headline: How to Buy a Home
text: Buying a home can seem like a daunting process, but with careful research and determination, the keys to that dream home can be yours. We’ll help you along your path toward homeownership.

headline: 9 TV Shows We’ll Be Talking About in June
text: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

headline: Chandraswamy, Who Fell From Favor as a Guru to Celebrities, Dies at 66
text: NEW DELHI — Chandraswamy, a Hindu holy man who counseled such 1980s glitterati as Elizabeth Taylor, the Saudi arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi and the Sultan of Brunei before coming under a barrage of criminal investigations, died here on May 23. He was 66.

headline: Latin Pop Thrives, No Bieber Required
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Western Yunnan Crossing Bridge Noodle
text: This Brooklyn restaurant excels at a deconstructed potage that servers combine at the table.

headline: For This Soup, Some Assembly Is Required (and Provided)
text: “Once upon a time, there was a scholar who was studying hard for his imperial exams on a small island of Yunnan.” So begins the legend of crossing-the-bridge noodles, as written on the wall at Western Yunnan Crossing Bridge Noodle in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: How CUNY Became Poetry U.
text: The City University of New York is many things. It is vast. It is accessible to students without a lot of money. It is exceptionally diverse. It is not, however, particularly fancy, the kind of place that oozes exclusivity or prestige.

headline: Verse in the City
text: A selection of poems from some of the accomplished poets teaching in the CUNY system.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Binge-Watching Trump’s Climate Horror Show
text: There was certainly a lot of buildup. Before President Trump formally announced on Thursday that the United States would pull out of the Paris climate agreement, he teased the public about the timing of the decision, almost as though he were savoring it.

headline: German Music Festival to Resume After Terrorist Scare
text: BERLIN — One of Germany’s biggest rock festivals was set to resume, the organizers said on Saturday, a day after the police ordered tens of thousands of fans to leave because of an unspecified terrorist threat.

headline: Blue Apron Has a Good Product. Beware of the Stock.
text: Blue Apron, the meal-kit delivery company that wants to go public, serves up delicious meals and tantalizing sales growth. But look closely at the ingredients. New-customer acquisition costs are surging, customers are ordering fewer meals, and competitors abound. Like Groupon before it, Blue Apron is a case where the product is fine but the stock is best avoided.

headline: Review: In David Gordon’s Life and Art, the Past Is the Present
text: “Live Archiveography,” written and staged by David Gordon, is a compelling, bewildering achievement. Astonishingly layered, its overlapping elements connect rehearsal and performance, historical film and prepared script, dance theater and personal life to become part of the history not just of Mr. Gordon but also of dance and theater. It’s both new and all about recycling; it’s live and all about the past.

headline: Robert Caro, Nearing the End of His Epic L.B.J. Bio, Eyes a Trip to Vietnam
text: An epic biography is nearing its close. Slowly but surely.

headline: An Ice Cream Truck at Carnegie Hall: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
text: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what they’ve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
text: Lately it seems the made-up food holidays are multiplying. (There’s probably even a “Made-Up Food Holiday” holiday.)

headline: What’s Keeping the Mayor From Going Green? His Gym Routine
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has a message for New Yorkers looking for a productive way to respond to President Trump’s decision to remove the United States from the Paris accord on climate change: Do your part, and stop using plastic grocery bags.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
text: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Running in the Sahara
text: Have you ever daydreamed of ice cubes? The idea sounded absurd until I undertook the Marathon des Sables, a 147-mile adventure through the Sahara’s scorching 130-degree temperatures, towering sand dunes and steep mountain passes. When I crossed the finish line on April 14, the race had shown me the joy of suffering and how to appreciate life’s simple pleasures.

headline: ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ Season 1, Episode 8: Profit and Pleasure
text: Behind every door in Gilead, horror breeds. Sometimes it comes in obvious forms — the gouged eyes of handmaids or the hollow gazes of women forced into prostitution. But as “The Handmaid’s Tale” nears the end of its first season, I’ve become more intrigued by the horror that remains unexplored. Nothing has been granted less consideration in the series so far than Moira’s perspective and the role of race in Gilead. But this week’s episode finally offers an answer to the question that has been hanging over the season: What happened to Moira?

headline: Senior Congo Officials Linked to Kabila Face Sanctions for Rights Abuses
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Several senior officials in President Joseph Kabila’s government were hit with sanctions this week by the European Union and the United States for “planning, directing or committing” serious human rights violations in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trump Golf Course Struggles in Bronx, Where Many Can’t Afford to Play
text: The Bronx waited more than three decades for a landfill at the foot of the Whitestone Bridge to be transformed into a municipal golf course.

headline: To Honor Canadian Natives, a Lawmaker Speaks in Mohawk
text: Cultural appropriation is a touchy topic in Canada these days, with the recent controversy in Canadian media over whether it is appropriate for nonindigenous writers to take on a native voice for artistic expression. But Marc Miller, a member of Canada’s Parliament, decided he was on solid ground in giving a speech in Kanyen’kéha, the language of the Mohawks, in the House of Commons on Thursday.

headline: Perfect Pairings
text: Elevate your afternoon with a glass of Veuve Clicquot Rosé and these perfect pairings.

headline: Unicef Fears Yemen Cholera Outbreak Could Hit 300,000 in Coming Weeks
text: Cholera cases in Yemen could quadruple in the next month to 300,000, the regional director of Unicef said Friday, calling the spread of the disease in the war-ravaged country “incredibly dire.”

text: Enjoy your picnic with cheese and charcuterie that goes perfectly with a glass of Yellow Label.

headline: Economic Fallout of Climate Move? It Depends on How We Value Time
text: President Trump’s decision to abandon the Paris climate accord — and his broader unwillingness to fight climate change — will have broad economic consequences.

headline: Eric Broadley, Acclaimed Designer of Championship Racecars, Dies at 88
text: Eric Broadley, a onetime cabinetmaker from Britain who became an acclaimed designer of racecars whose speedy creations won the Indianapolis 500 and numerous other events, died May 28 in Cambridge, England. He was 88.

headline: Husband of Kellyanne Conway Steps Back From Possible Justice Dept. Post
text: WASHINGTON — George T. Conway III, the husband of the presidential counselor Kellyanne Conway, has withdrawn himself from consideration to become the head of the Justice Department’s civil division, he said in a statement on Friday, citing family considerations as he became the latest sign of personnel woes at the White House.

headline: Corrections: June 3, 2017
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What Is the Green Climate Fund and How Much Does the U.S. Actually Pay?
text: In announcing his decision to exit the Paris accord, President Trump scorned the Green Climate Fund. Does the United States contribute an outsize share?

headline: W.N.B.A. Players’ Overseas Obligations Cramp Their Teams
text: When the Liberty traded for center Kia Vaughn in January, Coach Bill Laimbeer knew there was a caveat.

headline: Mick Mulvaney on the Budget, Congressional Scorekeepers and Staying Frugal
text: Mick Mulvaney, the White House budget director, may be one of the most maligned men in Washington because he is the bearer of budget cuts. He has been accused of everything from ethnic cleansing to wanting to kill a million people. He gets “fan mail” with fake business cards tucked in that give his job title as a “starver of hungry children and elderly.”

headline: Canada Today: Powerful Storytelling and Climate Politics
text: Catherine Porter, the Toronto bureau chief, and I are among a cadre of Canadians who help produce The New York Times. While some of the others are also reporters, many of the Canadians lurking within The Times are editors, which means you usually don’t see their names.

headline: Trump Nominates Richard Spencer as Navy Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday announced the nomination of Richard V. Spencer, an investment banker and retired Marine aviator, to be secretary of the Navy.

headline: Elliot Martin, Prolific Theater Producer, Dies at 93
text: Elliot Martin, who transformed himself from a teenage radio cowboy and Broadway chorus boy into one of the pre-eminent producers of the American theater, died on May 21 at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 93.

headline: Meeting the Paris Climate Goals Was Always Hard. Without the U.S., It Is Far Harder.
text: WASHINGTON — In December 2015, delegates from 195 nations announced to a roar of applause in Paris that they had finally sealed a pact aimed at keeping global temperatures from rising more than 2 degrees Celsius to avoid the worst ravages of climate change.

headline: Cousin of Brussels Bombers Is Charged With Ties to Terrorist Network
text: PARIS — The police in Belgium have charged a cousin of the brothers who set off suicide bombs in Brussels in March 2016 with being part of the terrorist network that planned and carried out those attacks and the attacks in Paris in November 2015.

headline: French Open Women’s Draw Highlights an Age of Thirtysomethings
text: PARIS — All but gone are the days of ingénues dominating in Paris. The grandes dames look poised to remain the ruling class at Roland Garros.

headline: Photographs of Marie Cosindas
text: Marie Cosindas’s artfully composed still lifes and portraits opened up a new world of color to a medium dominated by black-and-white images.

headline: Marie Cosindas, Whose Photographs Brought Color to the Fore, Dies at 93
text: Marie Cosindas, a photographer whose painterly, artfully composed still lifes and portraits, made with Polaroid film, broke with the dominant black-and-white aesthetic of the early 1960s and opened up a new world of color, died on May 25 in Boston. She was 93.

headline: Two Filipino Movie Stars Earn Meeting With an Idol (Jack Nicklaus)
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — As the two amateur golfers waited eagerly to meet Jack Nicklaus, two of their own admirers waited, star-struck themselves, to meet them.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ex-Penn State Officials Get Jail Terms in Sandusky Case
text: “This is a Shakespearean tragedy; this is a fall from grace that is both unfortunate and well deserved.”

headline: Leaders Lament U.S. Withdrawal, but Say It Won’t Stop Climate Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — World leaders vowed Friday to confront climate change in a new international coalition that no longer includes the United States government, moving quickly to reshape global environmental alliances after President Trump’s decision to abandon the Paris climate accord.

headline: Trauma, Taxes and Trump
text: In the middle of his speech trashing the climate accord, President Trump suddenly blurted out that his “tax bill is moving along in Congress.” This was something of a surprise since, A) there is no tax bill and, B) nothing is moving along in Congress.

headline: Fringe Groups Revel as Protests Turn Violent
text: Kyle Chapman expected he might find a fight. And he did — with a teenage girl.

headline: Six Days and 50 Years of War
text: In June 1967 Arab leaders declared their intention to annihilate the Jewish state, and the Jews decided they wouldn’t sit still for it. For the crime of self-preservation, Israel remains a nation unforgiven.

headline: Apple Piles On the Features, and Users Say, ‘Enough!’
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As Apple prepares to show off new features for the iPhone and other devices at its developer conference on Monday, the company is grappling with an uncomfortable issue: Many of its existing features are already too complicated for many users to figure out.

headline: Jack McCloskey, Architect of Detroit Pistons’ ‘Bad Boys’ Teams, Dies at 91
text: Jack McCloskey, whose canny decisions and steady leadership as general manager of the Detroit Pistons paved the way for their first two National Basketball Association championships, in 1989 and ’90, died on Thursday in Savannah, Ga. He was 91.

headline: Small Businesses Cheer ‘New Sheriff in Town’ After Climate Pact Exit
text: As news that President Trump was pulling out of the Paris climate accord hit at a luncheon for small-business owners in Toledo, Ohio, on Thursday, an already happy crowd suddenly turned euphoric.

headline: Weaver of Greek Mythology
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The constructor Roland Huget is primarily a late-week constructor, playing around with a variety of open and themeless puzzle designs. In today’s crossword, his seventh for The New York Times, he chooses a grid design that is new for him but, as he notes below, has been used before by other constructors.

headline: De Blasio Moves to Curb Puerto Rican Militant’s Parade Profile
text: Oscar López Rivera, the Puerto Rican nationalist at the center of a controversy over the Puerto Rican Day Parade in New York, has talked at times about how 35 years in federal prison could not break his spirit.

headline: ‘We Travel Together’
text: “We want fair treatment for our taxpayers. We don’t want other leaders and other countries laughing at us anymore. And they won’t be. They won’t be. I was elected to represent the citizens of Pittsburgh, not Paris.” — President Trump, June 1, 2017

headline: The Problem With Jared Kushner
text: What are we supposed to make of the news that Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior White House adviser, met with the Russian ambassador in December to discuss establishing a back channel between the incoming Trump administration and the Kremlin, using Russian diplomatic facilities?

headline: To Truly Resist Trumpism, Cities Must Look Within
text: Long before the nation’s attention turned to the investigation of the Trump administration’s ties to Russia, the president’s discriminatory and divisive policies and rhetoric were drawing intense criticism — and cities were being lauded as leaders of the resistance against them. Some of this praise of cities is deserved. But if they are to make meaningful change, local leaders also must look inward to confront the Trumpian forces that have long existed within their own boundaries.

headline: You Don’t Know Tiger Woods
text: I can’t remember the name of my high school biology teacher or that kind woman I had a pleasant lone date with at Corner Bistro in 2003. But I can recite the entire lineup for the 1982 St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: A Conscientious Objector in a War Zone
text: Mennonites have refused to participate in war for almost 500 years. I grew up in a small Mennonite community in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia, where Mennonites have been refusing conscription since the Civil War. Being a conscientious objector to the Vietnam War was an easy choice for me.

headline: Trump Appears Unlikely to Hinder Comey’s Testimony About Russia Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump does not plan to invoke executive privilege to try to prevent James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, from providing potentially damaging testimony to Congress on statements the president made about an investigation into his former national security adviser, two senior administration officials said Friday.

headline: Protecting Consumers in Patent Cases
text: Patent infringement cases may seem like arcane disputes between faceless businesses. But they can have huge effects on the economy and on individual consumers. Just wait until the next time you have to buy a cartridge for your printer.

headline: With Murphy’s Law in Effect, Yankees Can’t Catch the Blue Jays
text: TORONTO — The Yankees’ scouting report told them exactly where Toronto’s Kendrys Morales would hit the ball if it were a grounder. So third baseman Chase Headley was shifted to the other side of second base, second baseman Starlin Castro moved into shallow right field and Didi Gregorius was not far from second base.

headline: Manchester Bomber Met With ISIS Unit in Libya, Officials Say
text: The bomber who killed 22 people at a pop concert in Manchester, England, last month had met in Libya with members of an Islamic State unit linked to the November 2015 Paris terrorist attack, according to current and retired intelligence officials.

headline: Here’s How a Chinese Tech Firm Borrowed $2.1 Billion in a Hurry
text: When a Chinese tech company with global ambitions began to run short of cash last year, it sought billions of dollars from new investors. One of them was a music teacher.

headline: This Time, Matt Harvey Struggles Against the Pirates
text: Not long ago, a pitching matchup of Matt Harvey versus Gerrit Cole in early June would have amounted to a summer blockbuster — a marquee attraction featuring two of baseball’s finest young right arms.

headline: Former Contractor Sues Dale Chihuly, Claiming He Helped Create Artwork
text: Dale Chihuly, the artist whose show of 20 glass art installations is on display spread across the 250 acres of the New York Botanical Garden, used a group of unpaid assistants for 15 years to create works that were attributed solely to him, a man claimed in a lawsuit filed on Friday in Seattle.

headline: Bill Maher Apologizes for Use of Racial Slur on ‘Real Time’
text: The HBO late-night host Bill Maher apologized on Saturday for using a racial epithet during an interview with Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, on a live broadcast of his show on Friday night. HBO denounced the remark as “completely inexcusable and tasteless,” and said it would be edited out of future airings.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: A Tim Burton Trio and ‘The Essentials’
text: Tim Burton revels in freakiness in “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children.” And Alec Baldwin and David Letterman discuss David’s Lean’s “Brief Encounter.”

headline: Fact Check: Trump’s Exit From the Paris Climate Accord
text: President Trump is pulling the United States out of the Paris climate accord. The New York Times checks his claims about what the agreement really does.

headline: Covfefe, the Paris Climate Accord and Other Must Read Trump News of the Past Week.
text: Worried that you missed an important political story this week? You’re not alone. Catch up on a very hectic week of news.

headline: For Britain’s Labour Party, a Mild Defeat May Be Worst of All
text: BIRMINGHAM, England — Birmingham Northfield, a modest residential area on the southwest border of England’s second-largest city, has backed the Labour candidate for Parliament the last 25 years. But in conversations along its main shopping street, a mixture of discount stores like Pound Store Plus and a Women’s Aid shop, it is not hard to detect the guilty temptation of voting Conservative as the June 8 election approaches — and the main problem bedeviling Labour.

headline: Dive With a Cousteau in a Private Submarine
text: Pierre-Yves Cousteau, the youngest son of Jacques Cousteau, explores a sunken ship and artificial reef in the Bahamas. Join him in 360 degrees aboard a submersible craft.

headline: Dissecting Marissa Mayer’s $900,000-a-Week Yahoo Paycheck
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When a withered Yahoo is absorbed by Verizon Communications in the next week or so, it will be the end of an era for one of the pioneering names of the internet age.

headline: ‘We All Have to Be Prepared to Stand Up’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: The Doctor Is In. Co-Pay? $40,000.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When John Battelle’s teenage son broke his leg at a suburban soccer game, naturally the first call his parents made was to 911. The second was to Dr. Jordan Shlain, the concierge doctor here who treats Mr. Battelle and his family.

headline: Are HGTV’s Tarek and Christina the New Brad and Jen?
text: LOS ANGELES — Since November, a single tabloid magazine, In Touch Weekly, has devoted its cover to them in full or in part at least 14 times. In total, In Touch has done more than 90 articles on them.

headline: Young Tony Nominee of ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ Gets Ready for His Big Day
text: On most Wednesdays, in the roughly three-hour break between the matinee and evening performances of “Dear Evan Hansen,” the Tony-nominated musical playing at the Music Box Theater, the actor Mike Faist usually slips out for a walk down to the Hudson River. (“It’s nice to get outside and maybe get some semblance of nature,” he says.) Then he grabs a light snack and a quick nap back in his tiny fourth-floor dressing room.

headline: Istanbul Style by the Bosphorus
text: “There is such vibrant energy in Istanbul, regardless of the political climate,” the photographer Devin Yalkin said. His parents met in Nisantasi, a district on the European side. They lived across the street from each other, and when they were in their mid-20s, his father asked his mother out on a date through the window of their apartments. Ultimately they immigrated to America and Mr. Yalkin was born in Manhattan. Turkey, he said, is “always a really interesting place for me to be, because I see it as a place that I could have grown up in if my parents had decided to stay.”

headline: The Fashion Outlaw Dapper Dan
text: The Harlem couturier Daniel Day, better known as Dapper Dan, was all over social media last week after Gucci unveiled a jacket that looked very much like one he designed nearly three decades ago for the Olympic sprinter Diane Dixon.

headline: At the ‘Summer White House,’ You Are Never Far From a Trump Photo
text: Under cloudy skies in fall 2002, as guests and reporters looked on, Donald J. Trump dug into the ground with a gold-painted shovel to signify the opening of  Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J.

headline: India Acknowledges Three Cases of Zika Virus
text: NEW DELHI — Officials in Ahmedabad, India, saw the first of the cases in November: A 34-year-old woman who had just given birth to a healthy child came down with a fever, and tests later confirmed that she was infected with the mosquito-borne Zika virus.

headline: Bared Breast Enthralls a Future Czar, and Stokes a Russian Culture War
text: MOSCOW — It is an eye-catching wardrobe malfunction that beguiles a future czar.

headline: Airlines Step Up Stopover Options
text: Travelers with ambitious travel plans may find additional multicity routes at bargain rates as international airlines add free stopovers and other incentives to make the midway hub a second destination.

headline: Explosions Rock Funeral in Kabul, Killing at Least 7 and Injuring Dozens
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three explosions on Saturday rocked the funeral service of a victim of antigovernment protests in Kabul, killing at least seven people and injuring dozens after a tense and bloody week in the Afghan capital.

headline: ‘Building the Wall,’ Which Imagines Life After Trump, to Close
text: A political drama that sketches a dark vision of an America in recovery after the imagined impeachment of President Trump will close its New York production on Sunday — about a month before the play’s producers originally intended, according to the producer, Jeffrey Richards.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Techies Versus Trump Again
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: The Biggest, Strangest ‘Batteries’
text: What if you need a battery? A really big one — big enough to run a city?

headline: How Real Madrid Won Its Second Straight Champions League Title
text: Real Madrid resoundingly restated its case as the world’s best soccer club on Saturday, getting two goals from Cristiano Ronaldo and outclassing the Italian champion Juventus, 4-1, in the Champions League final in Cardiff, Wales.

headline: He Proposed. But That Was Just the Half of It.
text: Mansi Snehal Kothari and Sushil Raja Atmakuri were married May 29 in a townhouse at 241 West 17th Street in New York, where the groom’s family stayed for the wedding. Malika Atmakuri, the groom’s sister, who is ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

headline: Getting Rid of Tree Roots From Next Door
text: Q. Roots from my  neighbor’s tree have grown under the driveway of my house in Astoria, Queens, causing the asphalt to heave, buckle and crack. Who is responsible for repairing this damage, my neighbor or me?

headline: Ariel Stein and Rares Orzata: This Circus Has Two Rings
text: Ariel Melissa Stein and Rares Iulian Orzata were married June 3 at the Park Hyatt New York, in Manhattan. Justice Douglas E. McKeon of New York State Supreme Court in the Bronx, officiated.

headline: The N.B.A. Finals and the LeBron James Effect
text: My first experience covering the N.B.A. finals for The New York Times remains vivid for me. It was 2014, and the San Antonio Spurs defeated the Miami Heat for the championship.

headline: Video of Manila Casino Attack Shows Robbery Was Goal, Police Say
text: MANILA — Security camera footage released Saturday of the casino attack in Manila that killed 37 people shows an armed man setting fires in several rooms and stealing gambling chips but making no attempt to shoot fleeing customers and employees.

headline: No, Your Phone Didn’t Ring. So Why Voice Mail From a Telemarketer?
text: Frank Kemp was working on his computer when his cellphone let out the sound of Mario — from Super Mario Bros. — collecting a coin. That signaled he had a new voice mail message, yet his phone had never rung.

headline: Andy Murray Gets Past Juan Martín del Potro at the French Open
text: PARIS — After the chair umpire confirmed that Juan Martín del Potro’s final forehand of his first set on Saturday was out, the 29th-seeded del Potro stared, still in disbelief that he had lost the opening frame of his third-round match against top-seeded Andy Murray at the French Open.

headline: The View From Behind the Velvet Rope
text: Whether you’re covering a political campaign, a rock concert or the launch of a new cruise ship, one of the privileges of being a reporter is being allowed behind the velvet rope — to the front of the line, onto the stage or into the limo — to interview subjects. It’s not something I seek out (far from it), but as a business reporter who covered Wall Street and C.E.O.s for years, it came with the territory.

headline: Obama Unwittingly Handed Trump a Weapon to Cripple the Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials knew they were on shaky ground in spending billions of dollars on health insurance subsidies without clear authority. But they did not think a long-shot court challenge by House Republicans was cause for deep concern.

headline: Variety: Diagramless Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — When we last saw Brendan Emmett Quigley, he was busy building something with tools, but today he’s deconstructing in more than one way. If you’ve never done a diagramless crossword, don’t panic about the lack of grid; you’re supposed to build it yourself, with hints from the numbering of the clues.

headline: For David Griffin, a Cavaliers Architect, the Future Is Uncertain
text: CLEVELAND — David Griffin was on a far court, walking through offensive sets with Tyronn Lue, the coach he hired in the middle of last season. On the other side of the gym, LeBron James, the megastar he helped bring back to Ohio, stood in front of news media microphones, expounding on his Cleveland Cavaliers and the collective sharpshooters known as the Golden State Warriors, the two teams that are facing off in the N.B.A. finals for a third consecutive year.

headline: Gorsuch Rejects Doubts Over ‘Rule of Law Today’
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, in his first public remarks since joining the Supreme Court in April, spoke forcefully on Friday about letting judges have the last word in assessing the constitutionality of government actions.

headline: For Brewers’ Travis Shaw, Trade Was a ‘Blessing’
text: The Boston Red Sox arrive at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday for the first of three visits, but their homegrown third baseman just left town. Travis Shaw spent four games in New York last week, helping keep his Milwaukee Brewers atop the National League Central.

headline: ‘Last Secret’ of 1967 War: Israel’s Doomsday Plan for Nuclear Display
text: On the eve of the Arab-Israeli war, 50 years ago this week, Israeli officials raced to assemble an atomic device and developed a plan to detonate it atop a mountain in the Sinai Peninsula as a warning to Egyptian and other Arab forces, according to an interview with a key organizer of the effort that will be published Monday.

headline: An Ad Trump Signed Supporting Action on Climate Change
text: This ad appeared in The New York Times in December 2009, urging President Barack Obama to push a global climate change pact being negotiated in Copenhagen. Donald J. Trump and members of his family supported the ad, along with other business leaders.

headline: How G.O.P. Leaders Came to View Climate Change as Fake Science
text: WASHINGTON — The campaign ad appeared during the presidential contest of 2008. Rapid-fire images of belching smokestacks and melting ice sheets were followed by a soothing narrator who praised a candidate who had stood up to President George W. Bush and “sounded the alarm on global warming.”

headline: How the Stanley Cup Wound Up in a Canal, or Didn’t
text: If you know anything about the early history of the Stanley Cup, you’ve probably heard this story: The Cup, hockey’s most famous championship trophy, was once kicked into the Rideau Canal in Ottawa. The tale has been passed down for generations — but it probably isn’t true.

headline: Trump Plans to Shift Infrastructure Funding to Cities, States and Business
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump will lay out a vision this coming week for sharply curtailing the federal government’s funding of the nation’s infrastructure and calling upon states, cities and corporations to shoulder most of the cost of rebuilding roads, bridges, railways and waterways.

headline: The Single-Payer Party? Democrats Shift Left on Health Care
text: For years, Republicans savaged Democrats for supporting the Affordable Care Act, branding the law — with some rhetorical license — as a government takeover of health care.

headline: What Monkeys Can Teach Us About Fairness
text: Monkeys were taught in an experiment to hand over pebbles in exchange for cucumber slices. They were happy with this deal.

headline: The Tennis Mom Who Put the Blemish in Martina Navratilova’s 86-1 Record
text: Kathleen Horvath peered over the railing high above the indoor courts at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. Outside, rain was pouring down so hard that it sounded as if the New York Philharmonic’s percussion section were rehearsing on the roof.

headline: Springtime’s Not-So-Peaceable Kingdom
text: NASHVILLE — In spring, I search for nests. I part the branches of shrubs and low-limbed trees, peering into their depths for a clump of sticks and string and shredded plastic — the messy structure of a mockingbird’s nest. I squat and look upward for a cardinal’s tidy brown bowl. I stand even with the end of my house and look from the side into the ivy climbing the bricks, searching for a tiny avian hammock tucked into the leaves by house finches. I check the fern hanging under the eaves for the vortex tunnel built by a Carolina wren. I watch at my window for blue jays flying into and out of the tree canopy, and I try to pinpoint the exact Y-crook in the branches where they’ve hidden their young.

headline: Written Proof That the President’s Lobbyist Ban Is Worthless
text: We wanted to believe that President Trump was doing the right thing when the White House announced in January that executive branch officials would be banned for two years from working on policy or regulations they once were paid to influence as lobbyists and lawyers.

headline: America in Retreat
text: The swiftness of President Trump’s transformation of America’s global image from a proud and valued leader to something more nearly resembling a whiny bully has heads spinning at home and abroad. Mr. Trump was elected on a slogan of “America First” and a promise that the country would never again be bound by agreements and conventions that, in his view, compromised its sovereignty. But the policies and pronouncements that have flowed from this promise have in fact made the United States, and his presidency, the object of disbelief, alarm, even derision.

headline: Trump Stomps Planet Earth
text: WASHINGTON — We’ve been conditioned by Hollywood to see the president of the United States step up to the lectern to confidently tell us how he will combat the existential threat to the planet — be it aliens, asteroids, tidal waves, volcanoes, killer sharks, killer robots or a 500-billion-ton comet the size of New York City.

headline: Neither Hot Nor Cold on Climate
text: LIKE a lot of conservatives who write about public policy, my views on climate change place me in the ranks of what the British writer Matt Ridley once dubbed the “lukewarmers.”

headline: These Campus Inquisitions Must Stop
text: Racism pervades our country. Students who have roiled college campuses from coast to coast have that exactly right.

headline: Innocent Until Your Mug Shot Is on the Internet
text: PORTLAND, ORE. — On a cold, rainy morning in January of last year, Matthew Medlin hopped a refrigerated freight car in downtown Portland, Ore., and headed north. Mr. Medlin is 33 and homeless, with dagger-like stripes tattooed above his eyes and four dots below them — symbols of what he described as his belief in lycanthropy, the mythical transformation of humans into wolves. He has been a habitual methamphetamine user for years. He’s schizophrenic.

headline: What I Learned at Cowboy Camp
text: Lincoln, Neb. — One of the first things I did when I moved to Nebraska two years ago was find myself some cows to herd. I’d moved to a state that proudly says it has more than three times as many cows as it does people in order to take a job at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln, the state’s capital.

headline: How Interracial Love Is Saving America
text: As a descendant of slaves and slaveholders, I embody uncomfortable incongruities — just as America does. In “Notes on the State of Virginia,” Thomas Jefferson wrote with anguish about the risks of amalgamation, or interracial sex, to a new nation. Whites were “stained” when they mixed with blacks, whom he speculated were inferior in mind and form.

headline: The Specialists’ Stranglehold on Medicine
text: Republicans are trying to cut health care spending. But hacking away at Medicaid, weakening coverage requirements and replacing Obamacare’s subsidies with a convoluted tax credit will not deal with the real crisis in American health care.

headline: Devils, Needing an Answer, Query the Top N.H.L. Prospects
text: BUFFALO — One of the most colorful stories about an N.H.L. prospect concerned Trevor Linden and the Vancouver Canucks. In 1988, Brian Burke, the assistant general manager for the Canucks at the time, had asked Linden to come from his home in Medicine Hat, Alberta, to Vancouver for psychological testing before the draft.

headline: Trump’s NATO Bombast Gets Us Where Statesmanship Can’t
text: “Whither NATO” is probably the greatest snoozer headline of the past half-century. It has been used on editorials, op-ed articles, think-tank reports — anyplace an editor wants to communicate, “I’ve been forced at gunpoint to publish this essay, but for God’s sake don’t read it.” If Donald Trump had done nothing more than to create a legitimate occasion for calling a newspaper article “Whither NATO,” his place in history would be assured. Small, but assured.

headline: Rocketing to the Sun and Its Flaming Secrets
text: Like the countless stars that come and go, flaring and dying across the universe, the sun still holds many mysteries. That should change markedly next year when NASA launches the first satellite aimed at our own star to reveal the secrets of the sun’s atmosphere, the corona.

headline: Choosing When and How to Die
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Dilemma on Troop Surge in Afghanistan Now Vexes Trump
text: WASHINGTON — A new president confronts an old war, one that bedeviled his predecessor. He is caught between seasoned military commanders, who tell him that the road to victory is to pour in more American troops, and skeptical political advisers, who argue that a major deployment is a futile exercise that will leave him politically vulnerable.

headline: Nigeria’s Afrobeats Music Scene Is Booming, but Profits Go to Pirates
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — Forcing a smile, Seyi Shay, a music star in Nigeria, stood for hours under the hot lights of a film studio to record a video. Three changes of clothes, two wigs and multiple touch-ups later, she was still at it, singing snippets of the song over and over.

headline: Phil Mickelson Says He’ll Skip U.S. Open to Attend Daughter’s Graduation
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Phil Mickelson said on Saturday that he would withdraw from the United States Open, the only major championship he has not won, to attend what he considers a more important event — his daughter Amanda’s high school graduation.

headline: California’s ‘Green Rush’ Takes Hmong Back to Their Opium-Growing Roots
text: HAYFORK, Calif. — The red and purple opium poppies that his family grew on a mountainside half a world away were filled with an intoxicating, sticky sap that his mother traded for silver coins to feed her children and pay for their escape.

headline: Fake ICE Notices Urge Washington Residents to Report ‘Illegal Aliens’
text: Richard Byrne first saw the posters in his Washington, D.C., neighborhood on Thursday morning as he walked to a commuter train station.

headline: Advice to Writers
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes a theme gets you right in the feels, as the cool kids are saying these days.

headline: Another Terrorist Attack Strikes the Heart of London
text: LONDON — Another night of terrorism unfolded in Britain on Saturday with two attacks that killed six civilians in the center of the capital, London police said.

headline: Sara Ehrman, Outspoken Feminist With Deep Ties to Clintons, Dies at 98
text: Sara Ehrman, a fixture in liberal politics who advised President Bill Clinton on the Israeli-Arab conflict but was best known as the woman who advised a young Hillary Rodham not to move to Arkansas to marry Mr. Clinton, died Saturday in Washington. She was 98.

headline: Terrorist Attacks at the Center of London
text: A van mowed down pedestrians on London Bridge, and it was reported that people were stabbed at the nearby Borough Market.

headline: Attack in Manila: Terrorism or Robbery?
text: The Islamic State has claimed a Friday attack on a casino in Manila. But authorities released security-camera footage Saturday that they say shows the assailant was a thief, not a terrorist.

headline: Protesters in Washington Demand Independent Russia Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The March for Truth, the latest in what has become nearly weekly demonstrations of various stripes against the Trump administration, drew a sign-waving crowd to the Washington Monument on Saturday to protest possible collusion between associates of President Trump and Russian officials in the 2016 election.

headline: Real Madrid, Hard to Define, Firms Its Stamp on Champions League
text: CARDIFF, Wales — Real Madrid’s original Galácticos, that glittering collection of talent, could not do it. Neither could the Dream Team that Johan Cruyff built in Barcelona in the 1990s, nor its spiritual heir, constructed by Pep Guardiola and fueled by Lionel Messi, two decades later.

headline: Attacks in London: What We Know and What We Don’t Know
text: Visit this page for full coverage of the episode.

headline: Yankees’ Jordan Montgomery Bends Blue Jays to His Will
text: TORONTO — When Logan Munson arrived for the start of baseball practice for his senior season at the University of South Carolina back in 2011, a tall, gangly, somewhat goofy freshman sat down in the locker room stall next to him. His name was Jordan Montgomery.

headline: With Macron’s Blessing, France Unveils a Sweeping Ethics Overhaul
text: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron’s justice minister François Bayrou presented legislation on Thursday that would drastically rein in abuses in French politics, and would amount to a vigorous reinforcement of the existing ethics apparatus.

text: Three attackers drove a white van into pedestrians on London Bridge on Saturday night before stabbing people at nearby Borough Market.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How G.O.P. Shifted on Climate Science

headline: London Attacks: ‘It Was Utter Horror’
text: LONDON — It was a warm, drizzly Saturday night, and the bars at Borough Market here were packed, as usual. Tucked below an offramp of London Bridge, near the banks of the Thames, the market is a warren of narrow streets populated with trendy bars and restaurants, where some people had just finished watching the Champions League soccer final.

headline: Addison Reed Enters Early, and the Mets Leave With a Victory
text: On Saturday at Citi Field against the Pittsburgh Pirates, with his team clinging to a two-run lead, Mets Manager Terry Collins called the bullpen and asked closer Addison Reed if he could throw two innings to secure a win.

headline: London Attacked Again: Pictures From the Scene
text: London was stunned Saturday night by attacks that killed seven people  in the center of the capital. A van ran down pedestrians on London Bridge, then continued to nearby Borough Market, where three attackers emerged and began stabbing people, the police said. Armed officers responded and killed the assailants, who were wearing fake explosive vests, the police said.

headline: While Nashville Parties, the Predators Cut Loose
text: NASHVILLE — The denizens of Smashville donned gold boas and gold caps and gold T-shirts that said “Hockey-Tonk” and sauntered down Lower Broadway. Men with “I Need Tickets” signs around their necks meandered through bachelorette parties quaffing from plastic cups and taking selfies outside Bridgestone Arena, where a junked car adorned with the Pittsburgh Penguins logo awaited sledgehammering. Families toting camping chairs weaved through the crowd, staking out territory for the Alan Jackson concert, or the Game 3 viewing party, or both.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: Megyn Kelly Moves to NBC, and ‘The Leftovers’ Ends
text: Megyn Kelly, who left Fox News two weeks before the inauguration of President Trump, settles into the anchor seat of her new NBC show. “The Leftovers” ends its run — and leaves questions unanswered. And some cut-ups try to crack the 1970s comedy scene.

headline: Right and Left React to the Paris Climate Agreement News
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: Manila Casino Attacker Was a Gambling Addict, the Philippine Police Say
text: MANILA — The man who set fire to a Manila casino last week, killing 37 people, was not a terrorist but a heavy gambler who was deep in debt and had lost his job, the police and relatives of the man said Sunday.

headline: After London Attack, Prime Minister Says, ‘Enough Is Enough’
text: LONDON — Declaring “enough is enough,” Prime Minister Theresa May vowed on Sunday to conduct a sweeping review of Britain’s counterterrorism strategy after three knife-wielding assailants unleashed an assault late Saturday night, the third major terrorist attack in the country in three months.

headline: Making a Living by Jumping Off a Cliff
text: On sea cliffs in Lima, Peru, Fernando Canchari Vásquez jumps into the Pacific Ocean to solicit money, and support his family. He dresses up as a friar to embody a local legend and entertain tourists.

text: 1300 Hudson Street, No. 5B, Hoboken

headline: Rwanda’s Soccer Sisterhood
text: Gloria Nibagwire, 22, is one of Rwanda’s best soccer players. She is part of a group of women who have used the sport to reclaim their lives and re-establish a sense of community two decades on from genocide.

headline: Watch the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic
text: Liberty State Park, N.J. — On June 3, 2017, Veuve Clicquot celebrated the 10th Anniversary of the Polo Classic.

text: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Prime Minister Theresa May's Statement
text: The British leader vowed a sweeping review of the nation’s counterterrorism strategy after the late-night assault, the third in less than three months.

headline: Trump’s Off-the-Cuff Tweets Strain Foreign Ties
text: WASHINGTON — On one level, President Trump reacted to Saturday night’s terrorist attack in London much as his predecessors might have. He expressed solidarity and telephoned Britain’s prime minister to offer condolences. “WE ARE WITH YOU,” he wrote to Britons.

headline: The Empathetic Dog
text: Benjamin Stepp, an Iraq war veteran, sat in his graduate school course trying to focus on the lecture. Neither his classmates nor his professor knew he was silently seething.

text: For more personal finance tips, sign up for the Your Money newsletter here.

headline: New York Police Officer in Critical Condition After Being Dragged by Car
text: A police officer was in critical condition Sunday morning after being dragged by a car for more than two blocks while responding to a report of shots fired in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

headline: Upsets Mean French Open Women’s Trophy Will Be Hoisted Over a First-Timer
text: PARIS — With the four remaining Grand Slam winners all falling in their fourth-round matches Sunday at the French Open, there will be a new women’s major champion crowned Saturday at Roland Garros.

headline: Benjy Melendez’s Legacy: Peace and Hope in the Bronx
text: Benjamin Melendez arrived in New York from Puerto Rico as an 8-year-old at the dawn of the tumultuous 1960s. He came of age in the South Bronx, where by decade’s end he helped start the Ghetto Brothers, one of the many street gangs that arose amid the borough’s devastation. It was also where his father, Juan, ran two bodegas and never turned away anyone who was hungry, but broke. Benjy, as he preferred to be called, took notice.

headline: The Triumph of ‘Wonder Woman’
text: The box office has made its ruling, and the verdict is clear. You can’t keep a wonderful woman down.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Jean Sammet, Co-Designer of a Pioneering Computer Language, Dies at 89
text: Jean E. Sammet, an early software engineer and a designer of COBOL, a programming language that brought computing into the business mainstream, died on May 20 in Maryland. She was 89.

headline: Embracing What’s Natural
text: This week we’re turning over the Race/Related newsletter to participants in The New York Times Student Journalism Institute.

headline: From the Cradle of Innovation Comes a Self-Driving Team
text: The Golden State Warriors are the N.B.A.’s driverless car.

headline: Jimmy Piersall, Whose Mental Illness Was Portrayed in ‘Fear Strikes Out,’ Dies at 87
text: Jimmy Piersall, the often outrageous outfielder and broadcaster whose emotional breakdown while a rookie with the Boston Red Sox was portrayed in the 1957 movie “Fear Strikes Out,” a rare glimpse, for its time, at an athlete’s mental illness, died on Saturday in Wheaton, Ill. He was 87.

headline: New York Police Officer in Critical Condition After Being Dragged by Car
text: A New York City police officer was fighting for his life after he was injured late Saturday when he was dragged by a stolen car in Brooklyn, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Sunday.

headline: Portland Killings Dredge Up Legacy of Racist Laws in Oregon
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The fatal stabbing of two good Samaritans who intervened when a man on a commuter train shouted slurs at two women — both African-American, one in Muslim dress — has reawakened bitter memories of this state’s past and revived a debate over what people here call the “two Oregons,” where islands of tolerance abut places awash in frustration and rage.

headline: Chinese City With a Russian Past Struggles to Preserve Its Legacy
text: HARBIN, China — When he first arrived in the northeastern Chinese city of Harbin in 1984 to attend university, Bu Chong was stunned to see an imposing, European-style building on campus with tall columns, arched doors and elaborate reliefs. “I’m from the countryside,” he said, “and I’d never seen anything like this.”

headline: A Second Hamptons Art Fair Is Canceled
text: Art Southampton has canceled its 2017 season, becoming the second major fine arts fair on the East End of Long Island to suspend programming for the coming season. Art Hamptons, the region’s first art fair, canceled its season in February, leaving the once growing Hamptons market with one fair, Market Art + Design.

headline: Warship Named for Giffords Is Close to Being Ready for Sea
text: WASHINGTON — In January 2012, Representative Gabrielle Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, decided to resign her seat, a sad coda to the assassination attempt she had miraculously survived, but which left her badly disabled.

headline: Turning Against Trump: How the Chinese Covered the Climate Pact Exit
text: BEIJING — President Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate change accord drew criticism from leaders around the world. In China, the government seized the moment to cast doubt on American democracy and promote an image of China as a responsible superpower. Here’s how the state-controlled news media covered Mr. Trump’s decision and what the portrayal suggests about China’s efforts to extend influence across the globe.

headline: Celebrities Flock to Warriors. And We’re Talking About Practice.
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — It is basketball by invitation only, and if you are lucky enough to receive one, you get to watch Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson hoist 3-pointers or gawk as Kevin Durant extends his impossibly long frame and soars to the basket. You also get to take in the rest of the Golden State Warriors, the most dazzling team in the N.B.A.

headline: What to Expect as Bill Cosby’s Sex Assault Trial Begins
text: Read live updates of Day 4 of the Bill Cosby trial.

headline: National Politics Hang Over Tuesday’s New Jersey Primary
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The African-American heritage parade on Saturday here drew to a momentary standstill. Philip D. Murphy, a Democratic candidate for governor, was darting back and forth across the street, responding to endless calls for handshakes, hugs and selfies.

headline: ‘Pamplona’ Is Canceled After Stacy Keach Falls Ill
text: The Goodman Theater in Chicago will cancel the remaining performances of “Pamplona,” a world-premiere play by Jim McGrath starring the veteran actor Stacy Keach as Ernest Hemingway.

headline: Filipinos Flee Duterte’s Violent Drug Crackdown
text: MANILA — Every morning before dawn, Rosario Perez checks to make sure her sons are still alive. The three brothers, all in their 20s, sleep at the houses of friends and relatives, moving regularly, hoping that whoever may have been assigned to kill them won’t catch up with them.

headline: Mary Barra on Engineering
text: “It gives you a great foundation for continues learning,” Ms Barra says.

headline: Sugar Talks May Hint at Trump Approach to U.S.-Mexico Trade
text: MEXICO CITY — The sugar barons of Florida, Alfonso and José Fanjul, have been equal-opportunity political donors for decades, showering largess on the campaigns of Democrats and Republicans alike to ensure that lawmakers will protect the American sugar industry.

headline: A Very British Response to Terror
text: LONDON — The first thing that popped up on my Twitter feed in the aftermath of the terror attack in London on Saturday night was a photo of the evacuation.

headline: Outcry Over EpiPen Prices Hasn’t Made Them Lower
text: A few weeks ago, after some particularly incompetent parenting on my part (nuts in the dessert, a rushed trip to an emergency room after my child’s allergic reaction), I visited the local pharmacy to fill an EpiPen prescription.

headline: London, Narendra Modi, James Mattis: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Ariana Grande Brings Message of Defiance to Concert for Manchester Victims
text: GREATER MANCHESTER, England — The message onstage and in the crowd at “One Love Manchester,” a benefit concert for victims of the Manchester attack that was hosted by the pop star Ariana Grande, was one of defiance.

headline: From Maine, a Call for a More Measured Take on Health Care
text: BANGOR, Me. — Hundreds of miles from the health care debate that will begin again this week in Congress, lobstermen here are out in force, bees are furiously pollinating the state’s famous blueberries and part-time workers are preparing for another summer tourist season.

headline: 16 Years Later, Bush’s Climate Pact Exit Holds Lessons for Trump
text: WASHINGTON — The new president decided that the international climate change agreement negotiated by his predecessor was a job killer that sacrificed American sovereignty. So he pulled the United States out while much of the world jeered.

headline: Against Terror, Is London Pride Enough?
text: LONDON — One of the most tweeted pictures from last night’s terror attack on London Bridge shows a group of people running away from the scene of the killings. The runners are led by a man who is carefully balancing a half-full beer glass in his hand, as if even the threat of sudden, savage death isn’t reason enough to part a Brit from the pleasure of his pint.

headline: Gaza Dating Site Matches Widows to Men Seeking 2nd (or 3rd) Wife
text: GAZA CITY — He was looking for a woman with particular attributes, hopefully a widow of a man killed in the struggle against Israel, without children, between 25 and 30, from southern Gaza. Her requirement was no less important: She was looking for a married man.

headline: India, Pakistan and Something Deeper Than Cricket
text: BIRMINGHAM, England — “Any spare tickets for sale?”

headline: New Life for a 125-Year-Old Literary Journal
text: Adam Ross was more than 100 pages into a new novel about a child actor in 1970s New York when a rare opportunity came up. The Sewanee Review, a 125-year-old literary journal that published some of the 20th century’s greatest American writers, was seeking a new editor.

headline: Review: Boris Eifman, the Sensationalist of Russian Ballet
text: Did the choreographer Boris Eifman watch too many Ken Russell movies at a formative age? As Russell was, Mr. Eifman is drawn to tales of trauma and martyrdom in period costumes. His protagonists tend to be women or artists or both — the sculptor Camille Claudel, the composer Tchaikovsky, the ballerinas Olga Spessivtseva and Tanaquil Le Clercq, and (not artists but ah, what sufferers) good old Tatiana and Anna Karenina from the classics of Russian literature. Mr. Eifman dramatizes their miseries and throws in splashes of historical color amid the anguish.

headline: Review: Tom Zé Brings Brazilian Songs With Breezy Tunes and Sly Jokes to BAM
text: The comedy began when Tom Zé strolled onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night, an elfin figure dressed in a white shirt and blue-jean overalls. “Finally, I am here,” said Mr. Zé, a Brazilian songwriter who last performed in New York City in 2011.

headline: ‘Wonder Woman’ Deflects Doubt to Win Battle at the Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — Patty Jenkins and “Wonder Woman” just broke Hollywood’s superhero glass ceiling.

headline: What Was Bill Maher’s Big Mistake?
text: I know what he meant. Lots of people know what he meant. Nonetheless, the thing about some jokes is that they’re open to interpretation, and the interpretation isn’t up to him.

headline: Review: ‘If You’re Not in the Obit, Eat Breakfast’ Finds Vigor After 90
text: In this era full of baby boomers caring for frail parents, we’ve seen plenty of documentaries, plays and memoirs about dementia, infirmity, loss. But in the HBO documentary “If You’re Not in the Obit, Eat Breakfast,” Carl Reiner and friends take up another side of the phenomenon of longer life spans: the many people in their later years who are still sharp and vigorous and engaged.

headline: G.M. Wants to Drive the Future of Cars That Drive Themselves
text: DETROIT — The chief executive of General Motors, an automaker synonymous with Detroit, saw the future of driving not in the Motor City but on the streets of San Francisco.

headline: Bad Thing to Blow
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — For a Monday puzzle, Paul Coulter’s New York Times Crossword debut packed quite an “Aha!” moment for me. I didn’t immediately recognize what the circled squares were meant to be, but it was a pleasant surprise when the theme drove itself into my brain.

headline: 10,000 New Yorkers. 2 Decades. A Data Trove About ‘Everything.’
text: Your phone, in all likelihood, knows more about you than your doctor. Your credit card company knows your likes and dislikes better than your closest friend. Google knows your thoughts, and even completes your sentences. Your telephone service provider knows where you are at all times. Facebook, for many, knows more than the rest combined.

headline: Cambodia’s Buddhist Monks Find a Second Calling: Political Correspondent
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Wearing an orange robe and speaking calmly into his smartphone, the Venerable Luon Sovath eased his way through the throngs of people gathered outside Polling Station 867 in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital.

headline: The Digital Bystander
text: Live-streaming apps like Facebook Live and Periscope give us a voyeuristic peek into the lives of others. But what is our obligation when we encounter digital violence?

headline: What the Kitty Genovese Killing Can Teach Today’s Digital Bystanders
text: The rape itself was horrific enough. In March, half a dozen boys and young men lured a 15-year-old girl to a house in Chicago and sexually assaulted her there, brutally and repeatedly. But what made this episode singularly appalling was the attackers’ streaming their crime on Facebook Live. From a count posted with the video, investigators deduced that about 40 people watched in real time. Yet not one of the viewers bothered to summon the authorities.

headline: Steve Kerr Returns to Coach Warriors in Game 2 of the N.B.A. Finals
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — After a six-week absence, Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, was back on the bench at Oracle Arena on Sunday for Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals. When his face appeared on the arena’s giant video boards a few minutes before the opening tipoff, the crowd stood and roared.

headline: Ad Campaigns Tag Along as Men Embrace Different Paths
text: It wasn’t that long ago that commercials for the body spray Axe spoke to a certain type of male fantasy: Guys used the product and women who looked like supermodels flocked to them.

headline: Ballet Dancer Leaps Onto Subway Tracks and Lifts Man to Safety
text: After a 58-year-old man fell onto subway tracks Saturday night in Manhattan, a ballet dancer, who had just watched his wife perform with American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House, leapt down after him. With a lift that they do not teach in dance school, he moved him to safety.

headline: Another Terrorist Attack, and More Agony, in Britain
text: These are trying times for Britain. Two grotesque terror attacks within two weeks. An important and unexpectedly close election Thursday on how to exit Europe. The issues involved — stopping terrorism without sacrificing democratic values, ending a long relationship with the least damage to both sides — would be enough for any nation, much less one as emotionally battered as this one.

headline: Climate Science Meets a Stubborn Obstacle: Students
text: WELLSTON, Ohio — To Gwen Beatty, a junior at the high school in this proud, struggling, Trump-supporting town, the new science teacher’s lessons on climate change seemed explicitly designed to provoke her.

headline: Wendell Burton, Actor and Megachurch Minister, Dies at 69
text: Wendell Burton, whose promising Hollywood career began with a starring role opposite Liza Minnelli in the 1969 film “The Sterile Cuckoo” but fizzled before he turned to ministerial work for the megachurch preacher Joel Osteen, died on Tuesday in Houston. He was 69.

headline: Trump, Who Pledged to Overhaul Nuclear Arsenal, Now Faces Increased Costs
text: WASHINGTON — When President Barack Obama’s term ended in January, he left a momentous decision to the Trump administration: whether to continue a 30-year, $1 trillion program to remake America’s atomic weapons, as well as its bombers, submarines and land-based missiles.

text: Palmer Freeman Luckey was the kind of wunderkind Silicon Valley venerates. When he was just 21, he made an overnight fortune selling his start-up, a company called Oculus VR that made virtual-reality gear, to Facebook for $2 billion in 2014.

headline: Terrorist Attacks in Britain: A Short History
text: The attack that killed seven people on Saturday in London was the third act of terrorism in Britain in the past three months. But the country has long struggled against terrorism and political violence within its borders. Here is a brief history of fatal terrorist attacks in Britain in recent years.

text: It has offices in a sleek Manhattan skyscraper. Its bonds are accessible to millions of American investors. And it holds ties to some of New York’s biggest banks.

headline: In Its Series Finale, ‘The Leftovers’ Crosses Beautifully to the Other Side of Grief
text: “The Leftovers” cycled through several theme songs in its final season. In its wonderful series finale, “The Book of Nora,” it returned to “Let the Mystery Be,” by Iris DeMent, whose lyrics begin:

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Series Finale Recap: Over There
text: The showrunner for “The Leftovers,” Damon Lindelof, has never made any secret of his intention to baffle. Before the first season debuted, he said he’d follow the lead of the titular novel by Tom Perrotta and wouldn’t explain why or how 140 million people disappeared from Earth in what came to be known as the Sudden Departure. But the very fact of the event established a supernatural backdrop to this drama. And as the man who helped bring “Lost” into the world, Lindelof knows how to milk the fantastical for every spine-tingling, pulse-pounding moment ... even if his ultimate goal is to keep our feet firmly planted on the ground.

headline: Damon Lindelof on the ‘Leftovers’ Finale, Mark Linn-Baker and Preserving the Mystery
text: It’s been seven years since “Lost” departed from television, but its co-creator Damon Lindelof knows that many people will still assess Sunday’s conclusion of “The Leftovers” through the prism of his most famous project, which disappointed some fans with its ending.

headline: Warriors Handily Defeat the Cavaliers in Game 2
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — If welcoming back Steve Kerr, their ailing coach, were not enough to inspire the Golden State Warriors on Sunday night, Klay Thompson timed the return of his missing shooting touch for the occasion of a 132-113 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers and a two-games-to-none lead in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: On Mosul’s Front Line: A Grueling Battle on Civilian Streets
text: MOSUL, Iraq — The Islamic State’s grip on Mosul has shrunk to a tighter circle of neighborhoods in the western part of the city. But many civilians are still trapped in those areas, and the militants are giving no ground easily.

headline: Drug Deaths in America Are Rising Faster Than Ever
text: New data compiled from hundreds of health agencies reveals the extent of the drug overdose epidemic last year. Our estimates show deaths rising faster than ever — up about 19 percent in 2016, and all evidence suggests they will rise again in 2017.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Bachelorette’ and ‘If You’re Not in the Obit, Eat Breakfast’
text: Rachel Lindsay continues her quest to ride off in the sunset on “The Bachelorette.” Carl Reiner talks with some nonagenarians about the secret to longevity. And TCM devotes Mondays in June to Audrey Hepburn.

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3, Episode 5 Recap: Vegas Baby
text: It’s hard to say exactly why Showtime made four hours of “Twin Peaks” available online two weeks ago and then made us wait so long to see more, but the network’s strategy may have benefited the series’ fifth chapter, which is by far the most disconnected to date. By now, anyone who cares about “Twin Peaks” has had time to digest the mysteries, absurdities, and brain-busting oddities of parts one through four, which may make the “here’s a bunch of new scenes” approach of this week’s episode easier to process.

headline: Looking Like the Enemy: The Color Gold Saturates the N.B.A. and N.H.L. Finals
text: NASHVILLE — Fans attending Games 1 and 2 of the Stanley Cup finals in Pittsburgh received gold giveaway T-shirts. So did those attending Games 1 and 2 of the N.B.A. finals at the Golden State Warriors’ arena in Oakland, Calif. So did everyone who showed up in Nashville on Saturday for Game 3 of the N.H.L.’s title showdown.

headline: Black Soldiers’ Double War
text: A book documents the complex history of black soldiers, illuminating their triumphs and challenges.

headline: Kick This Rock: Climate Change and Our Common Reality
text: The 18th-century critic, Samuel Johnson, once tried to refute the Irish philosopher George Berkeley’s view that nothing is material by kicking a rock. “Thus I refute him!” he reportedly declared. For a long time, I thought this proved that Johnson should have kept to literary criticism and left philosophy to the professionals. Berkeley’s view, after all, was that everything we perceive is an idea — rocks (and rock-kicking) sensations included.

headline: Is There an Emerging Democratic Agenda?
text: While Donald Trump and his Congressional majority continue to push a harsh, hard-right ideology, so far they’ve been a legislative failure. And for good reason: For years, all they did was oppose Barack Obama and the Democrats, without bothering to develop an actual governing agenda of their own. Democrats must not make the same mistake. Playing defense is necessary, but it is not sufficient.

headline: Dorm Troopers: Life as a College Security Guard
text: Canterbury, England — A wallet soaked in urine with nothing inside except a driver’s license from Bermuda. That’s probably the weirdest thing I’ve had to file in the lost and found, the handling of which I help oversee as a security guard at Canterbury Christ Church University in England.

headline: Undoing All the Good Work on Cuba
text: To the long list of Barack Obama’s major initiatives that President Trump is obsessed with reversing, we may soon be able to add Cuba. In 2014, Mr. Obama opened a dialogue with Cuba after more than a half-century of unyielding hostility, leading to an easing of sanctions. Mr. Trump promised in his campaign to return to a more hard-line approach. If he does, as seems likely, he will further isolate America, hurt American business interests and, quite possibly, impede the push for greater democracy on the Caribbean island.

headline: New York City Should Grade Buildings on Energy Efficiency
text: As President Trump retreats from his predecessor’s efforts to tackle climate change, it is more important than ever that our cities and states develop tools to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions responsible for the planet’s warming. In New York City, this means first and foremost cutting energy use in buildings, which accounts for over two-thirds of the city’s emissions.

headline: Uncompromising Music Survives on the Brooklyn Waterfront
text: There is so much new life and affluence crowding the Brooklyn waterfront that traditionalists like Mark Peskanov, the master violinist who runs the Bargemusic concerts of chamber music aboard a handsomely converted coal barge, hard by the Brooklyn Bridge, might be tempted to move. Which he has no intention of doing.

headline: Trump’s Incredible Shrinking America
text: My whole life I have taken for granted America’s leadership in the world. America’s might and majesty were cornerstones of international relations, cooperation and diplomacy. We were a beacon and balance to the world. America has been imperfect — sometimes disastrously so — but it always seemed to me bent toward the belief that America and the world could be made more perfect.

headline: Making Ignorance Great Again
text: Donald Trump just took us out of the Paris climate accord for no good reason. I don’t mean that his decision was wrong. I mean, literally, that he didn’t offer any substantive justification for that decision. Oh, he threw around a few numbers about supposed job losses, but nobody believes that he knows or cares where those numbers came from. It was just what he felt like doing.

headline: On the Other Side of Terror’s Boom
text: The terror attack in London on Saturday night — the third in as many months, the second in as many weeks — demonstrated the persistence of the threat we face and the ease with which terrorists can carry out their schemes. Three men, with nothing more than a rental van, knives and fake bomb vests intended to keep both regular citizens and law enforcement at bay, killed at least seven and wounded a couple dozen more. This was a terrifying event for which ISIS has now claimed responsibility, but it was hardly a sophisticated act: a vehicle, some knives and ruthless determination.

headline: Black Soldiers: Fighting America’s Enemies Abroad and Racism at Home
text: After visiting Fort Hood Army base in Texas, the journalist Ray Suarez observed that as much as it represented a separate military culture, with distinct rules and protocols, it was also a microcosm of the nation. “One of the most attractive aspects of the people I met at Fort Hood was their very ordinariness,” Mr. Suarez wrote in 2010. “They are tall, short, men, women, rural, urban, skinny, buffed, chubby, provincial, worldly, with accents and life experience from every corner of the country.”

headline: 5 Arab Nations Move to Isolate Qatar, Putting the U.S. in a Bind
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For years, the tiny, energy-rich country of Qatar has carved out a niche in the Arab world by trying to be everything to everyone. It housed an American military base and flooded the region’s airwaves with its influential media, all while keeping close ties to Iran and a wide selection of Islamist movements.

headline: Forced From Their Village by Violence
text: In northwest Central African Republic, an armed rebel group has burned villages to the ground, displacing thousands. Listen to the voices of those who fled the violence.

headline: For Undocumented Mom, Somewhere to Shelter, but Nowhere to Run

Supporters of these churches say they keep families together. Opponents say they harbor criminals at the expense of citizen parishioners who could use their aid.

headline: Running With the Herd

The first was thinking it would be fun to take our pet donkeys out for a moonlight run with Vella Shpringa, our local Amish running club.

The debate is over whether their increased cost is accompanied by better patient outcomes.
