headline: Apple’s Big Event
text: It’s that time of year again: Apple is holding its annual developer conference.

headline: Under Trump, Worker Protections Are Viewed With New Skepticism
text: The victory was so sweet that the head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration sent thank-you notes to his employees.

headline: Getting Alerts From a Digital Pill Box
text: Q. I need an iPhone app that reminds me to take my medicine, and if I’m late taking it, helps me readjust the time between doses. Setting an alarm on the phone won’t work because I may be in a meeting. What apps might help me?

headline: How Does an (English) Garden Grow?
text: Q. How can the famous English gardens grow so well with the cloud cover that always seems to be hanging over them?

headline: Jimmy Buffett’s ‘Margaritaville’ Musical Sets Broadway Opening
text: Jimmy Buffett’s tropical paradise will land in a chilly New York this winter with the opening of the musical “Escape to Margaritaville” on Broadway.

headline: Hank Williams Jr. Is Coming Back to ‘Monday Night Football’
text: The rowdy friends are coming back.

headline: Go Ahead, Wear a Pair of High Black Socks With Those Shorts
text: A look once typical of the style-challenged is suddenly fashionable.

headline: Women With Aggressive Breast Cancer Are Living Longer
text: Women with metastatic breast cancer are living longer.

headline: Put a Price on Carbon
text: To the Editor:

headline: The London Attack Victims: What We Know
text: LONDON — Here is what we know so far about the eight people killed in an attack in London on Saturday night, when three men in a van drove into pedestrians on London Bridge before stabbing several people in nearby Borough Market.

headline: Bob Dylan Delivers His Nobel Prize Lecture, Just in Time
text: After Bob Dylan was named the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature last October, the literary commentariat wrestled with a fundamental question: Can song lyrics be literature? For some, the thought carried an unkind implication: Does something from the galaxy of pop music belong anywhere near the almighty pantheon of Great Lit?

headline: Street Style: Governors Ball
text: Music fans showed off their festival style in the rain and sun at the Governors Ball on Randalls Island this weekend.

headline: How Cold Brew Changed the Coffee Business
text: Summer officially starts this year on June 21, but that’s only the solstice, the day when the sun reaches its highest position in the sky. Down on street level, summer really begins on the first humid, sun-streaked day, when even the thought of sipping a hot cup of coffee is too much to bear. It’s as if, just as birds know instinctively when to migrate, we wake up one bright morning and agree that it’s iced coffee season.

headline: In London: ‘We Won’t Be Intimidated’
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Amaro From Galliano Makes Its American Debut
text: Galliano, the Italian liqueur in the tall, slender bottle, is best known as a sweet golden quaff with a glint of chartreuse. But there are variations, including Galliano Ristretto, infused with strong coffee, and an amaro, Galliano L’Aperitivo, which has been available in Europe since the fall. It has just been introduced in the United States, hitching onto a newfound appreciation of amaro drinks. It is ruby-colored, bittersweet and good in a Negroni or mixed with prosecco: $16.99 for 375 milliliters, drinkupny.com.

headline: Ask the Sketch Guy: Should I Finally Buy Some Bitcoin?
text: Last week, I announced the beginning of a semiregular “Ask the Sketch Guy” service. Send me your questions, but not just any questions. I want to explore the deep, dark conversations that we don’t hear on the financial pornography network, like how we feel about money and how money makes us feel.

headline: Governor Struggles to Lead as Texas Republicans Splinter Into Factions
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — When he took office two years ago, Gov. Greg Abbott represented a series of firsts for Texas.

headline: Bryson Tiller Earns His First No. 1 Album With ‘True to Self’
text: Another surprise release has debuted at the top of the Billboard album chart.

headline: Modi’s Push for a Hindu Revival Imperils India’s Meat Industry
text: MEERUT, India — When Uttar Pradesh’s state government began a crackdown on unlicensed slaughterhouses in March, Sanjay Chaturvedi, a local veterinary inspector, celebrated. For years, Mr. Chaturvedi said, the government had protected the lucrative, predominantly Muslim-owned buffalo meat business, making it difficult for him to enforce environmental codes.

headline: Satay Bar Opens at Gansevoort Market
text: A signature dish at the Chinese restaurants Jue Lan Club, Mr. Chow and Philippe is a satay skewer, usually chicken, served with a creamy peanut sauce. The chicken is a bright neon-orange. These satays are now in the spotlight at a new stand in the Gansevoort Market owned by Jesse Baer, and operated by Stratis Morfogen, an owner of the Jue Lan Club who had been involved with Philippe. The skewers are also made with seared beef, tempura shrimp, lobster, tofu or vegetables. Salad bowls and fried chicken nuggets on a stick are other options. All come in creative boxes and containers. Branches are also coming to the Queens Center and the Dumbo Market at Empire Stores: Skinny’s Satay Bar, Gansevoort Market, 353 West 14th Street, 646-678-3231, skinnyssatay.com.

headline: Trump Will Not Block Comey From Testifying, White House Says
text: WASHINGTON — White House officials said on Monday that President Trump would not invoke executive privilege to try to block James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director he fired, from testifying before Congress this week, clearing the way for a hearing that may be the most anticipated in Washington in months, if not years.

headline: A Dilemma for Diabetes Patients: How Low to Push Blood Sugar, and How to Do It?
text: Heart disease is the leading cause of death for people with Type 2 diabetes. Surely, then, the way to dodge this bullet is to treat the disease and lower blood sugar.

headline: Tahini Is at the Heart of These Vibrant Spreads
text: Gadi Friedman, an Israeli entrepreneur in Colorado, produces colorful tahini spreads flavored with fruits and vegetables, mostly from the Mediterranean. These sesame dips are definitely a change of pace from Nutella and peanut butter. The seeds are stone-ground, and the spreads are flavored with beet, carob-chocolate, date, fig, pomegranate or strawberry: Sesame Kingdom Tahini Spreads, $13 for nine ounces, $78 for all six flavors, 800-460-3037, sesamekingdom.com.

headline: How Ariana Grande’s Manchester Benefit Came Together So Quickly
text: In the days after a terrorist bombing at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, England, killed 22 people and injured more than 100 last month, Ms. Grande struggled with how to respond.

headline: SpongeBob SquarePants Musical to Open on Broadway
text: This fall, SpongeBob SquarePants will live not in a pineapple under the sea, but in the Palace Theater on Broadway.

headline: Challenges to Insider Trading Convictions Take Aim at Evidence
text: We are used to watching television programs about cases being solved by DNA evidence, a fingerprint or even a timely confession.

headline: At Governors Ball, Good Style Is Weatherproof
text: The weather wasn’t perfect over the weekend on Randalls Island, but the style was on point. See some of the standout looks from the Governors Ball Music Festival here.

headline: 2 Men Charged With Manslaughter in Deadly Oakland Fire
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Two men were charged on Monday with 36 counts of manslaughter in a deadly fire at an Oakland warehouse in December.

headline: Truckers’ Message for You: Chill Out, Stop Texting, and Have Respect
text: After a May 22 Times article about the plight of America’s long-haul truckers elicited a great deal of interest, we asked truck drivers what they would say to drivers of four-wheeled vehicles if they got the chance.

headline: In High Style, Obama Returns to the World Stage
text: Now that the internet has turned us all into middle-school kids shooting Snapchat spitballs and gossiping in homeroom about the burning issues of the day — How come Melania pulled the “got to fix my hair” trick to get out of holding Donald’s hand in Rome? Was that moony look Justin gave Emmanuel at the G7 summit in Sicily proof the Canadian prime minister is crushing on his French counterpart? Did you notice that Francis smiled at the first lady and gave the 45th president papal side-eye? — it is almost a step up to devote a column to Barack Obama’s open-necked shirt.

headline: Thoreau’s Empathy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fear of a Monopoly Will Help Amazon’s Cloud Rivals
text: Fear of no choice is starting to help Amazon’s cloud rivals.

headline: Denying Care to Millions
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 5: Watched It All? Let’s Discuss
text: The republic is in crisis, the good guys are dead or disempowered, and the bad guys just keep winning. Netflix’s “House of Cards” has always distinguished itself among political thrillers by a worldview so cynical it’s practically cartoonish, but the show’s fifth season was perhaps its darkest yet. Now that we’ve watched all 13 episodes, it’s time to assess the damage.

headline: One Guantanamo, Two Worlds
text: We know about the prison, but what about the picturesque community next door?

headline: Mr. Trump: Stop Tweeting and Go Back to Bed
text: It’s no secret that President Trump prefers tweeting over talking to the public — particularly when nearly everyone else in the country is fast asleep. Monday mornings are bad enough for everyone; pity the administration lawyers and aides who woke up today to find that their boss had undone months of their efforts to get his executive order barring travel to the United States from a number of Muslim-majority countries through the Supreme Court.

headline: How Frédéric Malle Makes a New Perfume
text: If there were fragrance royalty, Frédéric Malle, the founder of Editions de Parfums Frédéric  Malle, would have a title. His grandfather Serge Heftler-Louiche founded Parfums Christian Dior, and his mother, Marie-Christine Sayn-Wittgenstein, worked at Dior for 47 years and helped create Eau Sauvage. But it took Mr. Malle quite some time, with detours into art dealing and advertising, before he claimed his sweetly scented birthright. After learning the trade at the perfume house Roure Bertrand Dupont, he struck out on his own in 2000. His brand is based on a unique model: It functions like a publishing house, with Mr. Malle, 54, as the editor and the perfumers the authors. This month he is introducing his first men’s grooming products, a shaving cream ($80) and an after-shave balm ($120), both made in his Vetiver Extraordinaire scent. He spoke with Men’s Style at his Madison Avenue office in Manhattan.

headline: What’s in Your Attic? Baseball Cards May Help a Collection Fetch Nearly $1 Million
text: A collection of 1948 baseball cards discovered in an attic in unopened packs, and in exceptional condition, are part of a trove of sports trading cards that an auction house said could fetch nearly $1 million.

headline: Learn to Make Pies With Former Gourmet Editors
text: As tempting as an apricot-raspberry pie, a tomato-corn biscuit pie, a wineberry mascarpone pie or a zucchini-Cheddar puff pie may be, they taste even better when baked in a farmhouse kitchen with seasonal bounty from nearby orchards and fields. At the Farm Cooking School, on the Roots to River Organic Farm in New Jersey, monthly hands-on pie-making classes are taught by Ian Knauer and Shelley Wiseman, former Gourmet magazine editors. The types of pies vary according to the harvest, and each class includes instruction in making different kinds of pastry. The school offers other classes, including five-day and weekend sessions: Pies, June 16, July 7, Aug. 12, each from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., $95, the Farm Cooking School, 67 Pleasant Valley Road, Titusville, N.J., thefarmcookingschool.com.

headline: London Attack Suspect Known as Abs Appeared in Film About Extremists
text: LONDON — Everyone called him “Abs.” He gave out Halloween candy to children and taught them how to play Ping-Pong. He invited his neighbors to barbecue.

headline: London, Qatar, Theresa May: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Solidarity at an All-Female Screening of ‘Wonder Woman’
text: One woman said she came to feel a sisterhood. Another said she was there because in her years as a comic book geek, she had only ever watched superhero movies surrounded by guys. Yet another came because she didn’t want to overhear fanboys cracking wise about Gal Gadot’s physique, or, for that matter, that of any other woman onscreen.

headline: What We Lose by Barring Refugees
text: President Trump’s eruption of tweets in response to the London terror attacks doubled down on his self-described travel ban: “We need the courts to give us back our rights. We need the travel ban as an extra level of safety!”

headline: Cocktail Stirrer Celebrates Signature Move of Bartender
text: Gary Regan, the cocktail writer, bartender and bitters maker known as Gaz, once had to stir Negronis for 20 people, and to speed things up, he used his finger for the task. The crowd loved it, and it became his signature. Now, Cocktail Kingdom, a bar tool company, sells a 13¾-inch stainless-steel bar spoon made with a cast of Mr. Regan’s index finger at one end and his rooster logo on the other: Gaz Regan Negroni Finger Stirrer, $26.99, Cocktail Kingdom, cocktailkingdom.com.

headline: The Chef George Mendes Offers His Egg Tarts to Go
text: You could call pasteis de nata the national pastry of Portugal. The tidy little tarts made of flaky pastry and filled with custard are sold and served all over the country. In Lisbon, traditional bakeries sell them in clever geometric boxes. The chef George Mendes serves them at his Portuguese restaurant, Lupulo. He has had the distinctive boxes made for the restaurant and is selling the tarts to take away. The boxes are decorated with the pattern on the restaurant’s wall tiles: Pasteis de Nata, $5 for two, $15 for six, Lupulo, 835 Avenue of the Americas (29th Street), 212-290-7600, lupulonyc.com.

headline: Review: ‘Les Indes Galantes,’ a Baroque View of Colonial Relations
text: Rameau’s “Les Indes Galantes” contains one of the great hits of French Baroque music, the “Dance of the Peace Pipe,” so catchy and spry as to make grown men want to skip. This rondeau made a welcome appearance on Friday, toward the end of Opera Lafayette’s performance of “Les Sauvages,” the fourth and final part of this opéra-ballet, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But it did little to redeem a flat-footed production.

headline: Arundhati Roy’s Long-Awaited Novel Is an Ambitious Look at Turmoil in India
text: THE MINISTRY OF UTMOST HAPPINESSBy Arundhati Roy449 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $28.95.

headline: 17 Years Later, ‘The Man Who Killed Don Quixote’ Completes Shooting
text: It wasn’t clear whether the windmill would ever turn into a giant, but after almost two decades, the director Terry Gilliam has finally finished shooting “The Man Who Killed Don Quixote.” The film had experienced so many stops and starts that there was even a documentary, “Lost in La Mancha” (2002), about its struggles to get made.

headline: Asia’s Illegal Wildlife Trade Makes Tigers a Farm-to-Table Meal
text: BOKEO PROVINCE, Laos — The tiger paced back and forth in its cage, groaning mournfully. A second big cat slept soundly in the corner, while a third stared blankly at the bars.

headline: Mickey Drexler Steps Down as Chief of J. Crew, Ending an Era
text: At J. Crew, the other ballet flat has dropped.

headline: Dakota People Are Debating Whether to Burn ‘Scaffold’ Fragments
text: The four-day public dismantling of Sam Durant’s sculpture “Scaffold,” overseen by Dakota traditional and spiritual leaders, is nearly complete in the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden, after a week of protests, apologies and mediation involving the artist, the Walker Art Center and the Dakota people. But in an interview on Monday, the Walker’s executive director, Olga Viso, said the Dakota were debating whether the wood fragments would indeed be burned, as previously announced.

headline: Governors Ball’s 10 Best Sets: Gospel-Rap, Kiss-Off Pop and More
text: The Governors Ball Music Festival, which took over Randalls Island for three days last weekend, sets itself modest goals: just enough headliners, just enough variety, plenty of beer. Instead of tough choices, it puts on only two acts at a time; anyone truly torn can sample both in close proximity. Its lineup is, by and large, a straightforward assortment of what’s current, overground and generally full of positive thinking: pop, hip-hop, electronic dance music and rock, along with a handful of performers who got their start back in the 20th century. And it does have the ultimate New York City asset: location, just across the East River from Manhattan, as close as many performers on this summer’s festival circuit will be.

headline: Kushner Companies Seeking $250 Million to Pay Off Chinese Backers
text: The real estate company owned by the family of Jared Kushner, son-in-law and senior adviser to President Trump, is seeking $250 million to pay off its partners and lenders in a Jersey City apartment tower financed by Chinese investors through a program criticized as offering United States visas for sale.

headline: It’s Groundhog Day! Time to Put on That Costume (Again)
text: Things are pretty hectic backstage at “Groundhog Day,” the Tony Award-nominated musical based on the 1993 hit movie. After all, the show depends on its characters reliving the same day over and over, and that means getting in and out of the same costumes.

headline: Trump Backs Air Traffic Control Privatization
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump endorsed a proposal on Monday to privatize air traffic control, seizing on a decades-old idea as proof that he is advancing the ambitious infrastructure rebuilding plan he promised during his campaign but is still months from delivering.

headline: Trump Organization to Go Budget Friendly With ‘American Idea’ Hotel Chain
text: On the campaign trail, President Trump’s children rolled through dozens of small towns across the country, reveling in the adoration of the crowds. But they were less enamored of the budget-friendly hotels along the way, an assortment of run-of-the-mill offerings that were barely distinguishable from one another.

headline: Breitbart News Editor Says She Was Fired After Anti-Muslim Tweets
text: A Breitbart News editor said on Monday that she had been fired from the conservative news site for the anti-Muslim tweets she sent after a terrorist attack in London on Saturday.

headline: Apple, Comey, London: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: An Upstate Lifeblood, Ruled and Disputed From Afar
text: HANCOCK, N.Y. — The cold water that flows out of the reservoirs just north of here does more than chill the muck-sopped waders of fly fishermen. Once strictly reserved for the taps of New York City and neighboring states, the cold flow gives life to a biomass of insects and trout that has turned the region into one of the premier fly-fishing locales in the country.

headline: Al Franken Cancels Appearance on ‘Real Time With Bill Maher’
text: Senator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota, said on Monday that he was canceling a guest appearance, scheduled for Friday, on the HBO late-night show “Real Time With Bill Maher” after an incident last Friday in which Mr. Maher used a racial epithet during an interview with Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska.

headline: Canadian Women’s Hockey League to Add a Team From China
text: The Canadian Women’s Hockey League announced on Monday that it would expand to China, beginning next season, becoming one of the first North American professional sports leagues to field a team in Asia.

headline: Director of Ukrainian Library in Moscow Receives Suspended Term
text: MOSCOW — A Russian court on Monday sentenced a former director of the Library of Ukrainian Literature in Moscow to a four-year suspended prison term for inciting hatred toward Russians and embezzling public funds, in a case that her lawyers described as an attack on cultural figures with ties to Ukraine.

headline: Corrections: June 6, 2017
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Jack O’Neill, Surfer Who Made the Wetsuit Famous, Dies at 94
text: Jack O’Neill, who popularized the neoprene wetsuits that defied the cold, the calendar and the continents to create an endless summer for surfers around the world, died on Friday at his home in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Neil Gordon, Academic and Author of Cerebral Political Novels, Dies at 59
text: Neil Gordon, whose cerebral novels about radical politics, most famously “The Company You Keep,” challenged readers with biblical parables and ethical dilemmas, died on May 19 in Manhattan. He was 59.

headline: Las Vegas Police Officer Charged in Death of Man Put in Chokehold
text: A Las Vegas police officer has been charged in the death of a man whom he chased last month from a hotel, shocked with a stun gun seven times and held for more than a minute in an unauthorized chokehold, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Western Nations Worry That Children Won’t Be Better Off
text: The present is getting better. The future, not at all.

headline: Economy Candy Endures
text: Dear Diary:

headline: If Wonder Woman Can Do It, She Can Too
text: “She’s so strong,” the little girl seated next to me at a Brooklyn screening of “Wonder Woman” kept repeating to her mother, occasionally shielding her eyes. It was the first fight scene of the movie, and I was trying not to sob.

headline: ISIS Says It’s Behind Hostage Siege and Killing in Australia
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian authorities are treating an abduction and a killing here in Melbourne on Monday, which ended with the gunman dead, as a terrorist attack.

headline: A Jilted Paris Has Pined for the Olympics, but the Long Wait May End in 2024
text: PARIS — On a warm and sunny day at the French Open, Tony Estanguet was shivering.

headline: Student Opinions on Climate Change? Unpredictable
text: When I arranged to visit Wellston High School for a story about how the culture war over climate change was erupting in science classrooms, I had a pretty good idea of what I would find.

headline: China Looks to Capitalize on Clean Energy as U.S. Retreats
text: LIULONG, China — China’s devastating pollution problems began here, in coal country, where legions of workers toiled and often died to exhume the rich deposits that fueled the country’s sooty rise to economic power.

headline: Led by Rachel Maddow, MSNBC Surges to Unfamiliar Spot: No. 1 in Prime Time
text: The last time that MSNBC was No. 1 in prime-time cable news, Bill Clinton was president, Madonna led the Billboard charts and “Friends” still ran new episodes on TV.

headline: Pain Lingers as Lake George Boater Is Sentenced for Killing a Girl
text: QUEENSBURY, N.Y. — There are the physical scars from the horrific collision on Lake George: a permanent bruise and indentation on Courtney McCue’s thigh, where her 8-year-old daughter Charlotte was resting her head.

headline: White House Turmoil Makes It Harder to Stay Focused, Trump Aide Says
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s point man on Capitol Hill conceded on Monday that controversy over the firing of James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and open investigations into Russian election meddling made it harder to stay “focused” on ambitious Republican tax cut and health care plans.

headline: Reality Leigh Winner Criminal Complaint
text: Reality Leigh Winner, an intelligence contractor, was charged with sending a classified report about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election to the news media, the Justice Department announced Monday, the first criminal leak case under President Trump.

headline: Intelligence Contractor Is Charged in First Leak Case Under Trump
text: WASHINGTON — An intelligence contractor was charged with sending a classified report about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election to the news media, the Justice Department announced Monday, the first criminal leak case under President Trump.

headline: Some U.S. Diplomats Stage Quiet Revolt Amid Tensions With Trump
text: WASHINGTON — As President Trump strains alliances and relationships around the world, some of the nation’s top career diplomats are breaking publicly with him, in what amounts to a quiet revolt by a cadre of public servants known for their professional discretion.

headline: Trump Grows Discontented With Attorney General Jeff Sessions
text: WASHINGTON — Few Republicans were quicker to embrace President Trump’s campaign last year than Jeff Sessions, and his reward was one of the most prestigious jobs in America. But more than four months into his presidency, Mr. Trump has grown sour on Mr. Sessions, now his attorney general, blaming him for various troubles that have plagued the White House.

headline: P.R.I. Closes In on Narrow Victory in State of Mexico Governor’s Race
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s most powerful political party was on the verge of a clear victory in the closely fought race for the governorship of the nation’s most populous state, according to a nearly completed preliminary vote count on Monday night.

headline: Trump’s Lawyer, Marc Kasowitz: ‘The Toughest of the Tough Guys’
text: When James B. Comey, the former director of the F.B.I., testifies in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday about his ousting by President Trump, one man is likely to be watching perhaps even more intently than the president — and taking notes on a legal pad.

headline: Dueling Frenchwomen Show Signs of a Thaw After a Chilly Match
text: PARIS — A cool breeze blew north to south across Court Philippe Chatrier throughout its final match Monday, complicating an already chilly meeting.

headline: Toronto’s Kevin Pillar Is Using an Ugly Word as a Catalyst for Change
text: TORONTO — Baseball teams have long used the ceremonial first pitch to celebrate a player from their past, or a current cause. So the Toronto Blue Jays commemorated the start of pride month in the city by inviting Michelle Cherny, the treasurer of Pride Toronto, a gay-rights advocacy group, to throw out the first pitch last Thursday.

headline: U.S. Wants Inquiry Into Deaths of U.N. Investigators in Congo
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States on Monday called for an international inquiry into the gruesome murders of two United Nations investigators in the Democratic Republic of Congo in mid-March.

headline: No. 1 Hit
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If you are just joining us, The New York Times is celebrating the 75th anniversary of its crossword puzzle and, as part of that celebration, Will Shortz is periodically running collaborations between celebrities who have never made a crossword and veteran puzzle constructors throughout the year.

headline: Lisa Loeb Hears Music in the Creation of a Crossword Puzzle
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — For the singer Lisa Loeb, an exposure to crossword puzzles came from her older brother, Ben. As her brother zipped through them, Ms. Loeb’s curiosity — and perhaps a bit of sibling rivalry — got the better of her, and a love of crossword solving was born.

headline: Review: In Matthew Perry’s First Play, a Chandler Gone to Seed
text: Matthew Perry, the author and star of “The End of Longing,” doesn’t list “Friends” in his program bio, but he doesn’t need to. That hit television series, on which he played the wiseacre Chandler Bing for 10 seasons, sticks to him like a sweaty shirt.

headline: Boy Is Critically Wounded on His 5th Birthday by a Stray Bullet in the Bronx
text: A 5-year-old boy celebrating his birthday with his father in the Bronx was critically injured on Monday after he was struck in the head by a stray bullet, the police said.

headline: Quotation of the Day London Rampage Shows the Flaws In Stopping Plots
text: “What’s got through is just the tip of the iceberg, and it’s an enormous iceberg.”

headline: Actually, de Blasio Says, He Fought Against Puerto Rican Parade Honor
text: For weeks, Mayor Bill de Blasio was unwavering in his public statements: He would march in the Puerto Rican Day Parade in New York on June 11 even though it was giving a hero’s honor to a former leader of a bomb-planting Puerto Rican nationalist group.

headline: A Record-Setting Climb Up El Capitan, Without Ropes
text: On Saturday, the professional climber Alex Honnold became the first to climb the nearly 3,000-foot El Capitan, Yosemite’s iconic granite wall, without ropes, called free soloing.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 3, Episode 8: ‘What Have I Done?’
text: Well, this is the darnedest thing. On some psychic level, Jimmy and Chuck appear to be trading places. Jimmy used to be the life-loving extrovert. Chuck was the bitter shut-in. Now, look at them.

headline: In Killing by Police, a Jury Sees What the Dash Camera Saw
text: ST. PAUL — The fatal shooting of a black motorist by a police officer just outside this city drew national attention last summer largely because the driver’s girlfriend began livestreaming the graphic scene on Facebook moments after it happened. On Monday, as prosecutors began outlining their case against the officer, they presented a different video for the first time in public: dashboard camera footage of the shooting itself.

headline: What if Your Environmentally Correct Shoes Were Also Cute?
text: While waiting to board a flight from Los Angeles to San Francisco, Dr. Karli Cleary was approached by two 20-something women. They wanted to know, needed to know, where her pointy-toe red camo flats came from.

headline: Mourners Gather at London Bridge
text: Hundreds came out to honor the victims of Saturday’s terror attacks at London Bridge and Borough Market. Stand among them in 360 video.

headline: London, Qatar, Donald Trump: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Word + Quiz: benison
‘Wonder Woman’
text: Who is your favorite superhero? Why?

headline: Are You Being Raised to Pursue Your Dreams?
text: Are boys and girls raised differently?

headline: Where Are the United States Attorneys?
text: Three months after President Trump abruptly fired half of the nation’s 93 United States attorneys, following the resignations of the other half, he has yet to replace a single one.

headline: Selling Doctors on Cutting Drug Costs
text: As a drug salesman, Mike Courtney worked hard to make health care expensive. He wined and dined doctors, golfed with them and bought lunch for their entire staffs — all to promote pills often costing thousands of dollars a year.

headline: The Secret to My Success? Antidepressants
text: A few months ago, I gave a reading at a local bookstore. A small but enthusiastic crowd attended, and I confessed to the audience filled with emerging writers that I had, in my 20s and early 30s, stopped writing for eight years, and that I had accepted I’d never write again. Then someone asked, “How did you return to writing?”

headline: The Polar Bear in the Room
text: Bret Stephens: Gail, the choice of topic belongs to you this time. Not to coin a phrase or anything, but … we’ll always have Paris.

headline: The Unexpected Afterlife of American Communism
text: The Communist, in the American imagination, has always been the ultimate outside agitator.

headline: The Women Who Fought for Hanoi
text: Thirty-six years after she last took aim with her AK-47 assault rifle, Ngo Thi Thuong’s phone rang.

headline: The Lawless Presidency
text: Democracy isn’t possible without the rule of law — the idea that consistent principles, rather than a ruler’s whims, govern society.

headline: Help Poor New Yorkers Buy Transit Passes
text: The City Council of New York spoke to an urgent problem with its recent proposal to subsidize transit fares for low-income workers who now must choose between putting food on the table and spending $121 on monthly transit passes.

headline: Giving Away Your Billion
text: Recently I’ve been reading the Giving Pledge letters. These are the letters that rich people write when they join Warren Buffett’s Giving Pledge campaign. They take the pledge, promising to give away most of their wealth during their lifetime, and then they write letters describing their giving philosophy.

headline: Questions for: ‘Climate Science Meets a Stubborn Obstacle: Students’

It could be that everything is up to chance. Or it could be that your neighbor, who has always been jealous of you, is doing something sinister to your crops.

headline: What You Need to Know About Your Passport
text: Last year, more than 72 million Americans traveled abroad, according to the National Travel and Tourism Office. Yet many international travelers are turned away at the airport because even though they have a valid passport, its expiration date does not extend long enough to meet the rules of the country they plan to visit.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘The World to Come,’ by Jim Shepard
text: This sentence occurs in the middle of a short story but is basically its own little devastating poem: the ecology of an estranged marriage. The narrator is a 19th-century farmer’s wife who has fallen in love with another farmer’s wife — a love that is brutally denied by the men involved. Her sentence feels, in its elemental simplicity, like something from feudal Japan. Its opening clause posits an almost mathematical balance between the social and the natural world — “my heart : him :: pond : crane.” And yet that precision describes a situation of deep, unsolvable human sadness. The narrator’s heart-pond is destined to remain terminally neglected, its depths unexplored, its most precious resources unconsumed.

headline: The Teenage Life, Streamed Live and for Profit
text: On a recent afternoon in Los Angeles, 15-year-old Bryce Xavier went to the Olive Garden with his mom, pulled out his phone and broadcast lunch. Across the country, teenagers’ phones lit up with a push notification: Bryce was live.

headline: Are Pets the New Probiotic?
text: Scientists are paying increasing attention to the “indoor microbiome,” the billions of bacteria, viruses and fungi that we share our homes and offices with. But not all those micro-organisms are bad for us, experts note. And exposure to a rich array of indoor germs may actually be salutary, helping stave off a variety of illnesses.

headline: Aid Coordinator in Yemen Had Secret Job Overseeing U.S. Commando Shipments

The arrangement with Special Operations forces has never been made public.

headline: The Internet Is Where We Share — and Steal — the Best Ideas
text: In April, a photograph of Rihanna and Lupita Nyong’o taken at a Miu Miu fashion show three years ago began recirculating online. Their friendly body language and chic clothes (Rihanna wore thigh-highs, fur and leather; Lupita a plum jacket with a jeweled collar) caught the imagination of the internet. A Twitter user named @1800SADGAL suggested that “Rihanna looks like she scams rich white men and Lupita is the computer-smart best friend that helps plan” the scams. People began talking about an “Ocean’s 11”-type film written by and starring black women. Issa Rae was nominated to write the script and Ava DuVernay to direct. All four women chimed in on Twitter, announcing their support, though what that meant seemed unclear. Like any other online frenzy, it disappeared after a few days.

headline: America’s Hidden H.I.V. Epidemic
text: Early on a balmy morning last October, Cedric Sturdevant began his rounds along the bumpy streets and back roads of Jackson, Miss. Sturdevant, 52, has racked up nearly 300,000 miles driving in loops and widening circles around Jackson in his improvised role of visiting nurse, motivational coach and father figure to a growing number of young gay men and transgender women suffering from H.I.V. and AIDS. Sturdevant is a project coordinator at My Brother’s Keeper, a local social-services nonprofit. If he doesn’t make these rounds, he has learned, many of these patients will not get to the doctor’s appointments, pharmacies, food banks and counseling sessions that can make the difference between life and death.

headline: Apple Needs to Reinvent Itself. It Just Might Be Doing So.
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — One of Apple’s greatest strengths is timing. The company that’s hailed for innovation does not often invent things first — it didn’t create the first personal computer, the first digital music player or the first smartphone. Instead, Apple reinvents, slipping in and producing something more original than what we used to use.

headline: A Hot Mess for F-Train Subway Riders Trapped in Cars

headline: Cote, an Upscale Korean Barbecue Steak House, Opens in the Flatiron District
text: COTE Simon Kim, an owner of Piora in the West Village, is opening an updated, high-style version of a Korean barbecue steakhouse in a couple of subdued gray and black rooms. “It’s more appealing to both non-Koreans and Koreans with a finer experience, good service and wines,” he said. Japanese gas grills have been fitted into the sleek matte soapstone surface of every table, where customers will cook their own meat. There are 24 grills, each costing $4,000, and as Mr. Kim’s director of operations, Thomas Brown, pointed out, they are smokeless. The menu’s focal point is the butcher’s feast, at $45 per person. It includes assorted cuts of beef, condiments, salads, stews, other accompaniments and dessert. À la carte appetizers, meats, fish and side dishes are also served. The chef, David Shim, worked at M. Wells, and Victoria James, who is also at Piora, is in charge of wines. There’s a lounge area at the entrance and a marble-topped bar in the center, dividing the space into two dining rooms. (Opens Thursday): 16 West 22nd Street, 212-401-7986, cotenyc.com.

headline: Soul of a Scrapyard
text: Across the street from Citi Field in Queens there is a hidden corner of New York known as the Iron Triangle. It’s a shantytown of scrap yards and auto body shops, flanked by three intersecting streets that form a triangle. In the morning hours, as people convene on the dirt roads while sea gulls flock overhead, the neighborhood of Willets Point seems a world away from what many of us think of New York City, with its upswell of luxury apartments and gentrification.

headline: Ruling May Be Death Knell for $3 Billion Queens Development
text: The grand plan hinged on a barren patch of asphalt used to park cars during Mets games. But on Tuesday, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled that the lot — actually a city-owned piece of Flushing Meadows Park — could not be taken for development, dealing a potentially fatal blow to a nearly two-decade old project to turn a run-down area of Queens into a supermall, hotel and, eventually, housing.

headline: A ‘Fauxdega’ Where the Real Bodegas Have Been Priced Out
text: Today’s public art demands research. You don’t show in an old sugar factory without studying plantation labor. You don’t install in an abandoned prison without reading up on inmates’ lives. When the British artist Lucy Sparrow was preparing for her first New York installation, “8 ’Till Late,” a mock convenience store that just opened in a storefront beside the Standard, High Line, hotel in New York, she spent days exploring how the American version of Spam came in such un-British flavors as “teriyaki” and “hickory smoke”; how corner stores in the United States sell hot dogs and pizza as well as groceries; how such businesses do not include Marmite and Digestive biscuits.

headline: China on the Rise, While America Pulls Back
text: To the Editor:

headline: Air Travel Woes: What Can Be Done?
text: To the Editor:

headline: London, Qatar, Saudi Arabia: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: An Ingredient Yotam Ottolenghi Can’t Do Without
text: There are 10 or so things in my kitchen that I can’t do without. Olive oil and lemons. Red wine vinegar and tomatoes, when they’re in season. Coffee to start the day. Wine, bread, cheese and chocolate to end it. Tahini is there, too, ready to be drizzled on toast or whisked into a sauce or dressing.

headline: Go Ahead. Eat Pink Slime.
text: Of all the gross-out stories about food that have broken the Internet in recent years — maggots in mushrooms, “wood chips” in shredded cheese, bug bits in chocolate bars — nothing has captured the public imagination more than “pink slime.”

headline: 6 Cabana Shirts With Throwback Appeal
text: Just in time for summer, the vintage-inspired cabana shirt is upgraded in subdued solids and muted prints. And there’s not a kitschy poolside motif in sight.

headline: Police Are Less Respectful Toward Black Drivers, Report Finds
text: Police officers are significantly less respectful and consistently ruder toward black motorists during routine traffic stops than they are toward white drivers, a paper released this week found.

headline: Scuff, Patter, Chug, Poke, Swim: Expanding Definitions of Dance
text: Anyone who thinks that Irish dance is a necessarily rigid form, defined by a stiff upper body and dancers moving in militaristic unison, should spend some time watching Colin Dunne. New Yorkers had the chance to do so when the singular Mr. Dunne, who has long moved past his flashier days as a star of “Riverdance,” appeared on the small, no-frills stage of Irish Arts Center last weekend with the fiddler Tola Custy, the harpist Maeve Gilchrist and the piper David Power.

headline: An Intimate Duet for Not-Quite-Retired Ballerinas (and Friends)
text: You’re a choreographer. You have access to two of the world’s most ravishing dancers. And though both had recently retired as principals at major ballet companies, they were back in the studio.

headline: Soft Children Confront a Hard World in Maile Meloy’s New Novel
text: DO NOT BECOME ALARMEDBy Maile Meloy342 pages. Riverhead Books. $27.

headline: Review: ‘Maps for a War Tourist,’ Rewritten by a Real Tragedy
text: “Maps for a War Tourist,” presented by the experimental company Sister Sylvester at Dixon Place, is an atlas with half its pages blank, a diagram of a play you’ll never see. The piece originated with the troupe’s interest in Ayse Deniz Karacagil, a young Turkish woman arrested during the 2013 Gezi Park protests in Istanbul and charged with membership in a terrorist organization, an allegation largely based on the color of her scarf.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: London, Qatar, Saudi Arabia: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: As Many as 4 Are Dead in Drug Overdoses in Georgia
text: A wave of drug overdoses in Georgia has killed as many as four people and hospitalized dozens over two days, health officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Would You Buy a Plastic Suit From Stella McCartney?
text: The newest luxury material to hit high-fashion rails has nothing to do with centuries of artisanal tradition or rare and exotic animals, and everything to do with ... garbage. And it is coming soon to a Stella McCartney store near you.

headline: The Taliban Still Control Large Parts of Afghanistan and ISIS Has Established a Foothold
text: Afghanistan continues to struggle to maintain security in the face of the Taliban insurgency and a growing Islamic State presence.

headline: Oskar Eustis: The First Time I Burned Money (and Found My Calling)
text: One evening in May 1975, I stood outside a bank in Ann Arbor, Mich., and lit every dollar in my wallet on fire. As the bills burned, I held them up to the sky, tears streaming down my face.

headline: How Bots Are Inflating Instagram Egos
text: I posted a picture in March of the New York Times headquarters looking serene before a snowstorm to my Instagram account. The photo attracted 11 comments, all from strangers. “Very nice!” a monthly cocktail delivery company in San Francisco wrote. A cosmetic tattoo artist in Vancouver, British Columbia, posted three fire symbol emojis, and a vintage furniture seller in San Jose, Calif., left an emoji of a heart with a bow around it.

headline: Review: ‘Ascent’ of Mount Fuji, Guided by Over 4,000 Images
text: I have only seen Mount Fuji from the window of a train traveling from Tokyo to Kyoto. Its instantly recognizable silhouette conveys a feeling not just of majesty, but also of stillness. It is therefore apt that “Ascent,” written, directed and partly narrated by Fiona Tan, is announced as a “photo film.” All the images in this 80-minute feature are still. They are largely photographs of the mountain itself: in broad daylight, in the dark, covered in snow, in the background of bright panoramas of sunflowers or cherry blossoms.

headline: An Emissary From the Golden Age of Tango
text: PHILADELPHIA — By common consent, Argentine tango had a golden age from the 1930s to the 1950s. New music (Juan d’Arienzo, Osvaldo Pugliese and other composers) inspired dancers to new peaks of brilliantly rhythmic elegance. Innumerable classic audio recordings remain. But what’s left of the dance?

headline: Corrections: June 7, 2017
text: NATIONAL

headline: Public-Private Projects Where the Public Pays and Pays
text: Faster, better, cheaper.

headline: London Attackers: What We Know
text: Khuram Shazad Butt, Rachid Redouane and Youssef Zaghba killed seven and left scores injured on Saturday night. Two of them had been flagged by the authorities and one had even appeared in a TV documentary about Muslim extremism in Britain.

headline: Without Obama as a Unifier, Republicans Are Fragmented
text: WASHINGTON — A Republican-only attempt in the Senate to repeal the health care law is limping along, hobbled by giant divisions within the party over how to deal with Medicaid, among other issues.

headline: De Blasio and Council Agree, and Disagree, on Immigrants
text: With a handshake last week and then a vote on Tuesday, the New York City Council passed an $85.2 billion city budget. But one glaring issue remains undecided.

headline: Inside the Comey Memos: A Plea for Protection From Trump
text: Michael S. Schmidt reports on new revelations about James B. Comey's appeal to Attorney General Jeff Sessions to ward off pressure from the White House.

headline: Comey Told Sessions: Don’t Leave Me Alone With Trump
text: WASHINGTON — The day after President Trump asked James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, to end an investigation into his former national security adviser, Mr. Comey confronted Attorney General Jeff Sessions and said he did not want to be left alone again with the president, according to current and former law enforcement officials.

headline: Donald J. Vidrine, Supervisor on Ill-Fated Deepwater Horizon Rig, Dies at 69
text: Donald J. Vidrine, who faced prosecution as one of two BP supervisors on the Deepwater Horizon oil drilling rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, died on Saturday at his home in Baton Rouge, La. He was 69.

headline: Texas Governor Revives Stalled Transgender Bathroom Bill
text: HOUSTON — Gov. Greg Abbott reignited one of the most divisive issues in Texas politics on Tuesday, calling lawmakers back to the Capitol for a special session of the Legislature in part to consider a bill that would reinforce the state’s effort to regulate bathroom use by transgender people in public buildings.

headline: Ponzi Scheme Meets Ransomware for a Doubly Malicious Attack
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The first message to pop up on the computer screen let the victims know they had been hacked. The second message gave them a way out.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Service Lets Riders Share (Yes, Share) a Cab
text: “It’s a way to meet people. You might even meet the love of your life in a taxi, you never know.”

headline: Sergei Vikharev, Russian Ballet Master Who Revived the Past, Dies at 55
text: Sergei Vikharev, a Russian ballet master and former dancer in the Mariinsky Ballet who sparked a continuing debate over how to stage 19th-century works when he stunned international audiences with a four-hour spectacular production of “The Sleeping Beauty” in 1999, died on Friday in St. Petersburg. He was 55.

headline: In a Hurry, Maybe
text: Dear Diary:

headline: In Court, Diamond Reynolds Recounts Moments Before a Police Shooting
text: ST. PAUL — Last summer, only seconds after watching a Minnesota police officer shoot her boyfriend during a traffic stop, Diamond Reynolds pulled out her phone and started recording.

headline: Mexico Agrees to Sugar Trade Deal, but U.S. Refiners Remain Unhappy
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexico agreed to demands from the United States to cut exports of refined sugar, striking a deal on Tuesday in a contentious trade negotiation that was closely watched as a prologue to talks on renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Struggles in an Ominous Sign for the Yankees
text: The promise of summer heat is a beacon for teams without power. They can always tell themselves that the home runs will fly just as soon as this cold, rotten weather disappears.

headline: Justice Department Weighs In Against Wells Fargo in a Whistle-Blower Suit
text: Fresh woes for Wells Fargo and a victory for two of its whistle-blowers occurred late Tuesday when the Justice Department filed a friend-of-the-court brief in a lawsuit brought against the bank by two former employees, who were fired after they tried to report misdeeds they had observed to their supervisors.

headline: Sessions Is Said to Have Offered to Resign
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions offered to resign in recent weeks as he told President Trump he needed the freedom to do his job, according to two people who were briefed on the discussion.

headline: In Trump Country, Renewable Energy Is Thriving
text: Two years ago, Kansas repealed a law requiring that 20 percent of the state’s electric power come from renewable sources by 2020, seemingly a step backward on energy in a deeply conservative state.

headline: What You Get (and What You Don’t) From a $50 Amazon Fire
text: What can $50 buy? An inexpensive pair of sneakers, maybe dinner for two in San Francisco or a couple of tickets to the ballgame. But few ever imagined that it could also buy a tablet computer capable of running apps and streaming Netflix.

headline: Phil Murphy and Kim Guadagno Win Primaries in New Jersey Governor’s Race
text: NEWARK — Philip D. Murphy, a former Goldman Sachs executive, cruised to the Democratic nomination for New Jersey governor on Tuesday while Kim Guadagno, the state’s lieutenant governor, easily turned away a spirited challenge to claim the Republican nomination, setting the stage for a November battle to replace Chris Christie, the deeply unpopular incumbent.

headline: After Reality Winner’s Arrest, Media Asks: Did ‘Intercept’ Expose a Source?
text: Journalism in the Trump era has featured a staggering number of leaks from sources across the federal government, providing bombshell revelations about everything from clandestine meetings with Russian officials to petty infighting at the White House.

headline: How the Cavaliers Might Scrape Together a Win in the Finals
text: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland Cavaliers are in trouble. Overwhelming, intimidating trouble. Even LeBron James, whose vast postseason repertory includes some previous escape acts, does not dispute that fact.

headline: Reality Winner, N.S.A. Contractor Accused of Leak, Was Undone by Trail of Clues
text: WASHINGTON — In the months after President Trump was elected, Reality Leigh Winner frequently expressed outraged political views about him on social media, in between photos of her cats and favorite quotations. But on the afternoon of May 9, she posted an unusually anodyne message on Facebook, noting that she would be teaching two yoga classes that evening.

headline: Meet the Former Extremist Who Flagged a London Attacker in 2015
text: Jesse Morton, a former Al Qaeda recruiter who became an informer, knew the London attacker Khuram Shazad Butt and flagged him to the F.B.I. in a report in 2015.

headline: London Attackers Slipped By Despite an Avalanche of Warnings
text: LONDON — Islamic State propaganda had been found in the bag of one attacker while he was trying to board a flight in Italy. An F.B.I. informant said he had raised alarms about the second attacker two years ago. The third attacker, denied asylum in Britain, appeared to have sneaked in from Ireland.

headline: Alois Mock, Austrian Who Helped Tear Down Iron Curtain (Literally), Dies at 82
text: Alois Mock, the longtime Austrian foreign minister who snipped open the Iron Curtain with a wire cutter months before the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, died last Thursday. He was 82.

headline: Safely Running Down the Clock
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — What is going on in the field of crossword construction these days? Over the weekend, we had a diagramless crossword by Brendan Emmett Quigley where the theme involved shattering someone’s face. Today, Timothy Polin returns to thematically beat the tar out of us.

headline: Review: A Virtuoso of Depression Broods Again in ‘Animal’
text: When Rebecca Hall is depressed, attention must be paid. In recent years, this British-American actress has become one of our foremost interpreters of the mood abject, bringing a stinging brightness to pitch-black corners of despair.

headline: Ossoff and Handel Joust Over Health Care and Who’s the Real Georgian
text: The special election for Georgia’s Sixth Congressional District feels like it has been going on forever, which might explain why both candidates know their rehearsed lines so well.

headline: Pinterest Raises Valuation to $12.3 Billion With New Funding
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest, the digital scrapbook company, has raised $150 million in a funding that raises its valuation to $12.3 billion.

headline: Cuomo Assails Six New York Congressional Republicans
text: ALBANY — During his once-occasional but now overt flirtation with national politics, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has been careful in his choice of targets: Washingtonian dysfunction, for example, or federal meddling in his state’s affairs. He rarely mentions President Trump’s name but can get cantankerous with “the White House” or “the administration.”

headline: Canada Will Pursue a More Robust Global Role, Minister Says
text: OTTAWA — Canada will increase its military spending and its activities in international organizations as the United States seems to be stepping back from its international role, the country’s foreign affairs minister said on Tuesday.

headline: Long-Awaited Plan for Integrating Schools Proves Mostly Small-Bore
text: For months, New York City had promised to deliver what Mayor Bill de Blasio called a “bigger vision” for integrating the city’s racially divided public schools. Activists pressed their ideas. Students rallied on the steps of City Hall to demand a voice.

headline: Deadline for States to Meet Obama-Era Emissions Rule Is Extended
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will extend by one year a deadline for states to comply with a major Obama-era regulation on emissions of a smog-causing pollutant that spews from tailpipes and smokestacks.

headline: With Injured Starters Returning, Mets Contemplate 6-Man Rotation
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — A frustrated Jacob deGrom sat in the visitors’ dugout at Globe Life Park on Tuesday evening, appearing close to tears as Terry Collins, his manager, draped his arm over his shoulder and provided encouragement after his second ragged start in a row.

headline: Scooter Gennett Hits Four Home Runs, Joining an Exclusive Club
text: It is accurate to say that Scooter Gennett was unlikely to hit four home runs in a game. His team, the Cincinnati Reds, claimed him off waivers in March. Before Tuesday, he had 38 homers in five seasons. He takes his name from the “Muppets” character.

headline: Inside a Renovated Midcentury Masterpiece
text: Trina Turk, a designer of clothing and home goods, gives a tour of her recently renovated midcentury home, in the hills of Echo Park in Los Angeles. Step inside in 360 degrees.

headline: Can a Fake Tan Make You Look Thinner?
text: Rather than roast in the sun, and in all likelihood bring on sun damage, sun spots and other hot weather woes, self-tanner has become a reliable solution for faking a bronzed glow. The formulas have been improved so much — less streaky! less orange! — that, with some practice, you can use them to contour.

headline: A ‘Lost’ John Lautner House Is Found and Restored
text: LOS ANGELES — Three years ago, Trina Turk, a fashion and housewares designer who channels the sunny optimism of California, logged onto the real estate website Curbed.com and felt her blood pressure spike. On that day, the site ran an item about a house designed by the late midcentury architect John Lautner that had mysteriously slipped off the radar for 65 years.

headline: Pet Insurance Is the Latest Work Perk
text: Jessica Parsons, an intensive-care nurse in Indianapolis, had given little thought to pet insurance. But when her employer, Indiana University Health, offered it as part of the company’s regular benefits package several years ago, she signed up, the $40 monthly premium coming out of her paycheck automatically.

headline: Word + Quiz: ambience
Qatar, Theresa May, Paris: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Struggles of Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka Deepen Against Red Sox
text: If beating the surging Boston Red Sox were not difficult enough these days, the Yankees tried to do it Tuesday night with one arm seemingly tied behind their back — the one belonging to their putative ace, Masahiro Tanaka.

headline: Auction of Rockefeller Art Is to Benefit Charities
text: The personal art collection of Peggy and David Rockefeller will end up at Christie’s — no surprise, given the return to that auction house from Sotheby’s of Marc Porter, who has a long working relationship with the Rockefellers.

headline: Jack Trout, Who Fought for Consumers’ Minds and Money, Dies at 82
text: Jack Trout, a marketing strategist who viewed business as a Clausewitzian battlefield in which companies outflank their rivals in part by embedding their messages in consumers’ minds through a concept known as positioning, died on Sunday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 82.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Queen Sugar’ and the CMT Music Awards
text: Catch up on “Queen Sugar,” Oprah Winfrey and Ava DuVernay’s sexy, sudsy drama, before the second season arrives on OWN. And listen to the Gregg Allman tribute at the CMT Music Awards.

headline: A Comic Take on the News
text: Last weekend, The Times Magazine published its first-ever all-comics issue, with 12 tales of the city based on stories from The Times’s Metro desk.

headline: Right and Left Respond to Trump’s Remarks on the London Attacks
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and the left that you might not have seen.

headline: Questions for: ‘The Empathetic Dog’
text: Article: The Empathetic Dog

headline: How Do You Photograph Lions? Be as Boring as Possible.
text: Michael “Nick” Nichols has been photographing wildlife for four decades.

headline: I Lost My Voice, but Help Others Find Theirs
text: NASHVILLE — I can tell you the exact moment I realized my voice was broken.

headline: India’s Battered Free Press
text: Press freedom in India suffered a fresh blow on Monday when the country’s main investigative agency raided homes and offices connected to the founders of NDTV, India’s oldest television news station. The raids mark an alarming new level of intimidation of India’s news media under Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

headline: Yoga Teachers Need a Code of Ethics
text: I was relieved when Bikram Choudhury, the 73-year-old founder of Bikram yoga, was finally served a warrant for his arrest late last month, after failing to pay nearly $7 million in legal fees he owes for a sexual harassment lawsuit. Many in the yoga world had been waiting for that moment, after years of rape and assault claims against Mr. Choudhury, the millionaire creator of a 26-posture “hot yoga” sequence and studio system. But the news brought only a grim satisfaction; many of us wish he’d been arrested for the assault claims themselves.

headline: Privacy in the Cellphone Age
text: Odds are you need to use that phone in your pocket many times a day — and doing so leaves you no choice but to constantly relay data revealing your location and movements to Verizon, AT&T or whatever cellphone company you pay for the service. For most people, most of the time, that’s not a concern, if they’re aware of it at all. But how easy should it be for the government to get its hands on that data?

headline: Donald Trump Is Never to Blame
text: Poor Donald Trump, so late to the lesson that so many plutocrats before him learned: You can’t find good help.

headline: Trump Lies. China Thrives.
text: One of the many dangers posed to our society by having a president who’s a serial liar — and who doesn’t behave like an adult, let alone a president — is that we more easily ignore him even if he happens to say something true.

headline: A Very British Radical
text: The next Donald Trump — the next populist insurgent, the next outsider riding a wave of anti-establishment discontent, the next dangerous extremist with a chance to grab the reins of state — was supposed to be Marine Le Pen. In the Western press and Western capitals, there was a summons to the barricade when Le Pen reached the French presidential runoff. The liberal order was in the balance, the whiff of fascism was in the air, the entire French political system was expected to do its duty and keep her out of power.

headline: States and Cities Compensate for Mr. Trump’s Climate Stupidity
text: President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Paris compact on climate change was barely four days old when more than 1,200 governors, mayors and businesses promised to do whatever they could to help the United States meet the climate goals President Barack Obama had committed to in the agreement. In a letter, titled “We Are Still In,” they declared that global warming imposes real and rising costs, while the clean energy economy to which the Paris agreement aspires presents enormous opportunities for American businesses and workers.

headline: Who Is Dangerous, and Who Dies?
text: The death penalty, like abortion, is one of those hot-button topics that keeps popping up into the public consciousness, a roach motel for meretricious ideas and bad public policy — including racism. I would bet that if it involved putting white people to death for killing black people, it would have been abolished years ago. Still, it persists. Except our society — until recently — has come to believe that overt expressions of racism might not be a good thing. Better to keep a fig leaf over it than to explore its underbelly.

headline: Congress Must Reauthorize Foreign Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — Congress will hear testimony on Wednesday on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, part of which is set to expire at the end of the year. It will be debating the fate of an authority — the FISA Amendments Act — that has helped thwart terrorist attacks around the world.

headline: How Do You Photograph Wild Lions? Be as Boring as Possible.
text: Michael “Nick” Nichols has been photographing wildlife for four decades, mostly for National Geographic. Now, Aperture Foundation has published “A Wild Life: A Visual Biography of Photographer Michael Nichols” by Melissa Harris. Mr. Nichols spoke with James Estrin about his life with gorillas, elephants and lions. Their conversation has been edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: North Korea Fires More Missiles as Seoul Puts Off U.S. Defense System
text: TOKYO — North Korea fired several cruise missiles from its east coast on Thursday, the South Korean military said. It was the country’s fourth missile test in four weeks, and it occurred just a day after South Korea’s new president said his government was suspending the deployment of an American antimissile system.

headline: What Song Lyrics Do You Consider Literature?
text: Can song lyrics be literature? That’s the question many asked after Bob Dylan was named the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature last October, receiving the same award previously given to literary greats like T. S. Eliot, Gabriel García Márquez, Toni Morrison and Samuel Beckett.

headline: Murder Victim’s Earliest Arrests in New Jersey
text: In one of her earliest arrests known to the state police, a woman identifying herself as Evelyn Moore was charged with embezzlement in Atlantic County, N.J. That name, and others the woman used in later arrests, would form the trail of breadcrumbs that led to her likely true identity and background far from where she was killed in New York.

headline: Praise for Fingerprint Find in Unsolved Murder
text: In a thank-you letter, a police captain commended a medical examiner's techniques in lifting usable fingerprints from a decomposed body in the 1970 investigation of a Jane Doe murdered in upstate New York.

headline: Santander Rescues Troubled Rival in Test of Europe’s New Rules
text: After the global financial crisis, Europe built a system designed to contain the collateral damage from failing banks. That new system appeared to pass its first test on Wednesday, as authorities efficiently dispatched a troubled Spanish lender.

headline: ‘This Is Still All About Brexit’: Readers on the British Election
text: On June 8, Britain goes to the polls in a snap election unexpectedly called by Prime Minister Theresa May. Originally predicted to be a landslide victory for the Conservative Party, polls show the Labour Party, under Jeremy Corbyn, closing the gap. Could there be an electoral upset of Trump-like proportions?

headline: 1968 Arrest in Harlem in Unsolved Murder Case
text: A woman using the name Fannie Hill was arrested in 1968 in Harlem when she was caught carrying a loaded pistol. The name and others the suspect used over the years would help lead to the likely true identity of a 1970 murder victim found in the woods in upstate New York.

headline: Arrest Report Offers Names of Murder Victim's Associates
text: The woman who gave various names when she was arrested offered another one in this 1969 drug case in Harlem — one that belonged to someone close to her. The name of a companion in the vehicle that day has been partially redacted by The New York Times at his request, as the murder of the arrested woman remains unsolved.

headline: 1938 Map of Birthplace of Murder Victim
text: A map of Orangeburg County, S.C., in 1938, with what was then called Old Reevesville Road highlighted. The road has since been moved in places and renamed, and gone are any trace of the houses on its north end in 1940, when a census worker visited. Among those living there was a 4-month-old named Evelyn Moore.

headline: 1940 Census Report With Moore Family
text: A 1940 census report in Orangeburg County, S.C., listed Fanny Moore, a first and last name used in previous arrest reports, and Elvin Moore as 4 months old — corresponding to the date of birth of Dec. 3, 1939, that was given by the woman arrested in 1968. The report also detailed pay history for families.

headline: In a New Crime Lineup, a Supine Swede and Private Eyes With Bad Habits
text: Mycroft Holmes, Sherlock’s older, fatter, smarter brother, was renowned for solving mysteries without leaving his armchair at the Diogenes Club. In Josephine Tey’s “The Daughter of Time,” Inspector Alan Grant of Scotland Yard was confined to a hospital bed when he tackled the historical crime of the murdered princes in the Tower. And Rex Stout’s corpulent genius, Nero Wolfe, investigated criminal cases without budging from his elegant Manhattan townhouse.

headline: In Washington, a New Appreciation of American Gardens
text: The United States has a rich yet relatively unknown tradition of beautiful gardens, said Cindy Brown, the education and collections manager at the Smithsonian Gardens in Washington. “Gardens in this country date back to the 17th century and continue to be an attraction today,” she said, “but most people aren’t aware of how many of them there are and don’t necessarily think of them as destinations.”

headline: Marc Maron Is Coming Around to Being Famous
text: You’ve been hosting your interview podcast for eight years. How has it changed you? It has helped me become a more fully realized adult. Talking to other people so often, for such a long time, in such a relatively deep way, has taught me how to be a lot more reconnected with my empathy and not be so self-involved.

headline: How Russian Propaganda Spread From a Parody Website to Fox News
text: A false report claiming a Russian warplane took out the communications systems of an American warship spread with alarming ease.

headline: She Had Never Suffered From Anxiety. Was She Having Her First Panic Attack?
text: She didn’t have any urgent medical problems, the woman told Dr. Lori Bigi. She was there because she had moved to Pittsburgh and needed a primary-care doctor.

headline: Your Guide to All the Comey News Heading Into His Testimony
text: • James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, is set to testify in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday, starting at 10 a.m. Watch Mr. Comey’s testimony and follow live coverage and analysis throughout the day.

headline: Even After Landslides, You Can Still Visit Big Sur
text: Following a series of landslides and a bridge collapse in early February, which led to the temporary closing of many hotels and restaurants and put tourism to the region at a standstill, much of Big Sur in California is once again welcoming travelers.

headline: Feminism Takes Form in Essays, Questions and Manifestos
text: DEAR IJEAWELE, Or, A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions By Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie 63 pp. Knopf, $15.

headline: Does My Ex Owe Something to Our Grown Children?
text: After 25 years of marriage and three children, my husband and I divorced. He was a former seminarian and a pro-life Catholic when we married. He insisted on no birth control. When we divorced, he was a lawyer and vice president of a Fortune 500 company. I did not receive any spousal support, but he promised he would always be there for the children. I worked hard and was always able to take care of myself. I felt guilty about the divorce and never asked for more.

headline: Can a New Generation in the Banlieues Change French Politics?
text: On Feb. 2, around a quarter to 5 in the afternoon, just as the day began to darken, police officers approached four young men outside a recording studio in the Rose des Vents, an agglomeration of chalky cités, or public-housing projects, that covers a remote expanse of the northeast Paris suburb Aulnay-sous-Bois. The police asked to see one man’s identity papers. Within minutes, another was on his stomach. The officers put handcuffs on the 21-year-old, whose family, of Congolese origin, lived nearby. When they arrived at the station, staff members noticed that he was in a lot of pain. He was rushed to a hospital, where an examination revealed a 10-centimeter tear in his rectum. It had been caused by a police baton.

headline: How Student Loan Forgiveness Changed Graduates’ Paths
text: For Dr. Charles Phillips, the government’s public service loan forgiveness program meant he could spend his days researching childhood cancer, rather than starting a lucrative pediatrics practice.

headline: Robot Cars Can’t Count on Us in an Emergency
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Three years ago, Google’s self-driving car project abruptly shifted from designing a vehicle that would drive autonomously most of the time while occasionally requiring human oversight, to a slow-speed robot without a brake pedal, accelerator or steering wheel. In other words, human driving was no longer permitted.

headline: At Bill Cosby Trial, Andrea Constand Battles Defense Lawyers

headline: Edgewater, N.J.: A Riverside Borough, With Quirks
text: Hugging the Hudson River, Edgewater is home to a colony of Quaker parrots, an exotic Japanese food hall and a swamped historic ferryboat.

headline: Clues to a Jane Doe’s Beginning 30 Years Before Her Violent End
text: BOWMAN, S.C. — Weathers Farms grows corn, cotton, soybeans and peanuts off a dirt road called Wayside Drive. I stood at a gate alongside the property, peering past trees toward where a house once would have stood, teeming with three generations of a family now long gone.

headline: Edgewater, N.J.: A Riverside Borough, With Quirks
text: Five years ago, Aline and Jack Tabibian moved from Tenafly, N.J., to Edgewater, a borough in Bergen County that is proportioned like a rasher of bacon. Three and a half miles long, and a few blocks wide at its broadest, Edgewater skims the west side of the Hudson River, from North Bergen to Fort Lee.

headline: Solved: The 47-Year Mystery of a Murder Victim’s Many Identities
text: She was buried Nov. 7, 1970, in plot No. 537 of a potter’s field in Middletown, N.Y. In the cemetery’s record book, where her name should have been, someone wrote a single word.

headline: At Least 12 Killed in Pair of Terrorist Attacks in Iran

headline: The Telltale Data That Can Identify College Students at Risk
text: WASHINGTON — Administrators at the University of Kansas knew they had a problem: Many of their most vulnerable students — largely low income and often the first in their families to go to college — were not graduating. The administrators needed to figure out why students like this were struggling. So they did something that those in higher education rarely do: They looked to a competitor for help.

headline: Helping Students Avoid the ‘Trap’ of College Costs
text: Student loan debt is the second-fastest growing type of debt in the United States, behind only home mortgages. After more than doubling in a decade, it now exceeds $1.2 trillion, with the average borrower owing about $30,000, according to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. More than a quarter of student loan borrowers are delinquent or in default.

headline: Preparing ‘Emerging Adults’ for College and Beyond
text: Rachel Ginsberg is a clinical psychologist at the NewYork-Presbyterian Youth Anxiety Center, a research and clinical program that brings together experts from NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University Medical Center and Weill Cornell Medicine. She is part of its Launching Emerging Adults Program aimed at teenagers and young adults.

headline: At Ithaca College, a President Focused on Diversity
text: Students at Ithaca College who sign up for intergroup dialogues in the coming semesters may have some interesting classmates: their professors.

headline: Honing a Vision for Higher Education
text: Some of the nation’s most influential leaders in higher education met last week at the Higher Ed Leaders Forum hosted by The New York Times. They discussed an array of issues facing colleges and universities today, including high costs, free speech, addressing the skills gap, using big data and leading in a time of crisis. The excerpts below have been edited. Videos of the full sessions can be found online at www.nythigheredleaders.com.

headline: Where to Turn to When You’re First in the Family to Go to College
text: Dennis Di Lorenzo’s parents never went to college. They were blue-collar people who believed in hard work but not necessarily the hard work of higher education.

headline: Germany to Withdraw Forces From Incirlik Base in Turkey

Chris Christie of New Jersey in the so-called Bridgegate scandal to lead an agency under a harsh political spotlight.

headline: How the Iran Terror Attacks Unfolded at Two Sites

text: PARIS — Sitting courtside at the French Open on Wednesday, close enough to hear the ball bouncing off the damp red clay, you were also close enough to sense the hunger gap.

headline: A Human Rights Defender, Facing the Death Penalty
text: Dr. Mudawi Ibrahim is a globally renowned human rights defender, risking his life to protest killings in Darfur and to ease the suffering of others around Sudan. Now he is in prison in Sudan, facing charges that could lead to the death penalty. Here, his family speaks out.

A vocalist began to cry out a song of pain or lost love — folk melodies in harsh quarter-tones, like a muezzin issuing a call to prayer at a mosque.

headline: The Comey Testimony: When, Where and How to Follow

headline: The Mayors of Pittsburgh and Paris: We Have Our Own Climate Deal
text: Last week, President Donald Trump tried to pit our two cities against each other when he announced, in pulling out of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, “I was elected to represent the citizens of Pittsburgh, not Paris.” As the mayors of Pittsburgh and Paris, we’re here to say that we’re more united than ever.
