headline: The London Fire: What We Know
text: LONDON — A fire tore through a 24-story West London apartment building early Wednesday, killing at least 30 people and injuring more than 70. The authorities said that the death toll was expected to rise, and that some bodies might never be identified.

headline: Dancers Welcome Summer by Moving About Outdoors
text: It’s a sure sign that summer is looming when dancers are suddenly all over town, leaping across grassy parks and sandy beaches. The latest setting for moving bodies can be found among Josiah McElheny’s glass-tile sculptures in “Prismatic Park,” the outdoor public art project presented by Madison Square Park Conservancy’s Mad. Sq. Art. In “Desire Lines,” Rashaun Mitchell and Silas Riener create a two-week slate of improvisation that explores ideas about change and connection. Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Riener, along with 13 others — including Eleanor Hullihan, Cori Kresge and Mina Nishimura — will perform solos or in small groups. Other programs are dedicated to music and poetry, but the dance part of “Prismatic” is curated by Judy Hussie-Taylor of Danspace Project. (danspaceproject.org, madisonsquarepark.org.)

headline: Digable Planets at SummerStage in Brooklyn
text: Of all the great 1990s rap groups, few went more silent than the jazz-rap giants Digable Planets, which disbanded in 1995 and stayed that way for years. But a decade later, the group — Ishmael Butler, known as Butterfly; Mary Ann Vieira, called Ladybug Mecca; and Craig Irving, a.k.a. Doodlebug — had a brief reunion, and beginning in late 2015, the trio has been performing more regularly, including on Wednesday, June 21, at Coffey Park in Red Hook, Brooklyn, as art of a week of free SummerStage concerts there.

headline: Two Histories, of Aesthetics and Diasporas, at Bard College
text: Two exhibitions opening on Saturday, June 24, at the conjoined Center for Curatorial Studies and Hessel Museum at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., promise unfamiliar artists and revisionist viewpoints. The larger of the two, “Picture Industry,” is a sprawling show organized by the artist Walead Beshty that spans from the late 19th century to the present. It will represent some 80 artists with photographs, slide projections, film, historical documents and more. Through Dec. 15.

headline: Steve Scalise, Wounded Lawmaker, Takes Pride in Baseball and Politics
text: WASHINGTON — As the majority whip in the House, Representative Steve Scalise is known among his Republican colleagues as a pleasant, persistent force, who gently checks back to see whether a lawmaker who has repeatedly said “nope, not with you” on a coming vote has had a change of heart.

headline: Sam Gold Brings His Touch to ‘Hamlet’
text: The director Sam Gold has made his name with contemporary plays, and of the two shows he brought to Broadway this spring, only the new one — Lucas Hnath’s “A Doll’s House, Part 2” — caught fire with critics. The other, his bracingly stripped-down revival of “The Glass Menagerie,” was a hard sell — coming too soon, it seemed, after John Tiffany’s stunner of a production. Yet Mr. Gold’s interpretation, which gave us a lovely Laura (Madison Ferris) in a wheelchair, made sense of that play in a way that felt powerfully necessary. It succeeded at the job of every revival: justifying its own existence. Now Mr. Gold, who staged a starry “Othello” Off Broadway last fall, has a “Hamlet” on the horizon. With Oscar Isaac as Hamlet and Charlayne Woodard as Gertrude, it begins previews on Tuesday, June 20, at the Public. What dreams may come? We’ll see. (publictheater.org)

headline: The ‘Legends of Chamberlain Heights’ Is Back, and Still Raunchy
text: Admirers of Comedy Central’s ribald “Legends of Chamberlain Heights” might have watched the 10th episode in December and assumed it was the last. The animated series is about three high school freshmen who aspire to basketball glory, and the perks that come with it, but don’t want to do the work of serious athletes. They spent the series riding the bench until, in that first season’s finale, one of them, Grover (voiced by Josiah Johnson), was called upon to shoot a pivotal free throw, which he made.

headline: Women’s Voices of Afghanistan Rise in Gemma Peacocke’s Song Cycle
text: During her travels in Afghanistan, the journalist and poet Eliza Griswold collected dozens of landays, a form of poetry recited by women at village feasts and in refugee camps, as well as on clandestine poetry phone-ins.

headline: Jennifer Jones Animates ‘The Wild Heart’ at MoMA
text: Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s British melodrama “Gone to Earth” — at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday, June 21, as part of “Modern Matinees: Becoming Jennifer Jones” — has a reputation often eclipsed by the drama surrounding its production. The executive producer, David O. Selznick, married Jones before filming and had the film re-edited for its American release, adding scenes directed by Rouben Mamoulian and retitling it “The Wild Heart” (1952).

headline: Too Many Opioids After Cesarean Delivery
text: Doctors may be overprescribing opioids to women who have had cesarean sections.

headline: Using Android to Zoom In for a Closer Look
text: Q. I read your recent answer to a question regarding the magnifier on iPhones. I’m visually impaired, and this helps me and many others, but I have an Android smartphone and tablet. I cannot afford Apple, so what magnifying options are available for Android?

headline: How Pasteur’s Artistic Insight Changed Chemistry
text: If you’ve ever had milk, you’re probably familiar with the work of Louis Pasteur, the 19th-century French chemist and biologist. He prevented diseases, developing a process — widely known as pasteurization — for killing microbes in milk and wine. He also created vaccines for rabies and anthrax. And his ideas led to the acceptance of germ theory, the notion that tiny organisms caused diseases like cholera. Pasteur even helped us brew better beer.

headline: Daily Report: The Perils of Continuing to Use Uber
text: Uber has promised to reform its corporate misbehavior. On Tuesday, the company released a long list of recommendations that it plans to adopt to avoid the workplace scandals that have recently plagued it. Uber’s chief executive, Travis Kalanick, also said he planned to take a leave of absence.

headline: J. Crew Debt Maneuver Can Be a Model for Other Troubled Retailers
text: J. Crew may have found a clever way to mend several tears in its corporate fabric. The flailing clothier owned by TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners is trying to restructure some $567 million of notes by offering holders a deal that runs the risk of irking another set of creditors. So J. Crew has stitched something up for them, too. If it manages to thread the needle, J. Crew may provide a blueprint for other wobbly retailers contemplating bankruptcy.

headline: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Shooting of the G.O.P. Men’s Baseball Team
text: Right Now: Five people have been wounded by a single gunman, who died after he was shot and taken into custody.

headline: The Breakdown: Balenciaga
text: A structural, oversize look, pared back to its fundamental elements.

headline: The Breakdown: How to Wear a Balenciaga Look — Piece by Piece
text: Sometimes when clothes come down the runway, it’s hard to see what they actually look like. Pieces are styled on top of each other, accessories are stacked dizzyingly — shoes and socks, even, are matched in ways you couldn’t imagine in real life. T breaks down runway looks into their most fundamental elements — which, in their simpler forms, are surprisingly easy to wear. Here, a look from Balenciaga with interesting, oversize proportions.

headline: Otto Warmbier Got an Extra Dose of Brutality From North Korea. The Mystery Is Why.
text: SEOUL, South Korea — One American who was held captive in North Korea said he was interrogated up to 15 hours a day by officials who wanted him to confess to plotting to overthrow their government. Another said she was held in a 5-by-6-foot windowless cell. Yet another former American inmate shivered on the concrete floor of a room “no bigger than a dog’s house.’’

headline: Anita Pallenberg, Actress and Muse of Rolling Stones, Dies at 75
text: Anita Pallenberg, the German-Italian actress and model who became best known for her relationships with members of the Rolling Stones, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Chichester, West Sussex, England. She was 75.

headline: Virginia Shooting Suspect Was Distraught Over Trump’s Election, Brother Says
text: WASHINGTON — He lived out of his van in the Northern Virginia suburbs and took showers at the Y.M.C.A. On Facebook, he posted furious criticism of President Trump and pledged allegiance to Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Back home in Illinois, neighbors complained to the police of his practicing his shooting near their home.

headline: U.S. Halts New Rules Aimed at Abuses by For-Profit Colleges
text: The Trump administration is formally reconsidering — and may dismantle — two new rules that were a cornerstone of the Obama administration’s crackdown on predatory for-profit colleges.

headline: 5 Fires That Shaped Modern London
text: The fire that engulfed an apartment tower in London on Wednesday joins a list of disasters that have marked the city’s history. Few were more prominent than the Great Fire of 1666, which wiped out 80 percent of the city and led to a rebuilding that laid the groundwork for London as we know it today. Although modern Londoners live a life relatively sheltered from such destruction, some fires in recent history have shaped it. Here are five examples from the last 100 years.

headline: Harvard President Says She Will Step Down Next Year
text: Drew Gilpin Faust, the first woman to be Harvard’s president, announced on Wednesday that she would step down next year after 11 years of service, a period in which she oversaw ambitious fund-raising, expansion of academic programs and increases in student and faculty diversity.

headline: Russian Lawmakers Approve Plan to Relocate 1.6 Million Muscovites
text: MOSCOW — At least 16 protesters were detained in front of the Russian Parliament building on Wednesday as legislators approved a plan that could uproot up to 1.6 million Muscovites from their aging Soviet-era residences and move them into newly built apartments.

headline: America 'Was Born to Serve Mankind,’ Wilson Says
text: The Trump administration says its compass is set to “America first.” A century ago, President Woodrow Wilson, standing at Arlington Cemetery on Memorial Day, told the nations of Europe: “We did not set this government up in order that we might have a separate and selfish liberty, for we are now ready to come to your assistance and fight out upon the field of the world the cause of human liberty.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Man in the Ceiling,’ Jules Feiffer Adapts Himself
text: SAG HARBOR, N.Y. — Lots of family-friendly musicals don’t aim very high; they rely on lightweight songs and simple storytelling that any kid could grasp. “The Man in the Ceiling,” a new work with some impressive names behind it that is receiving its premiere at the intrepid Bay Street Theater here, wants to be more challenging. This is a show best suited to children born with the theater-nerd gene and to parents curious to see how the source material, Jules Feiffer’s 1993 book, translates to the stage.

headline: Despite Tony Wins, ‘Indecent’ Announces Its Broadway Closing
text: Paula Vogel’s “Indecent,” a well-respected play that received three Tony Award nominations and two wins, will close on Broadway after struggling to gain traction at the box office.

headline: The Virginia Shooting: The Scene and Reaction
text: Witnesses describe the scene of the shooting that injured Representative Steve Scalise and others Wednesday morning. President Trump and Senator Bernie Sanders made statements.

headline: Tenement Museum in New York Names Its New President
text: Kevin Jennings, a history teacher turned nonprofit leader who is also a former Obama official, has been named the next president of the Tenement Museum in Manhattan.

headline: Uber Investigation Leads to Shake-Up
text: An investigation into Uber’s troubled company culture has led to changes in leadership. The chief executive has taken a leave of absence and several others have been fired over the past two weeks.

headline: How Uber’s Brash Approach Backfired
text: A series of scandals have toppled executives, including Travis Kalanick, Uber’s co-founder.

headline: A.R. Gurney, Playwright Who Explored Upper-Crust Anxieties, Dies at 86
text: A. R. Gurney, a prolific playwright who dissected the fading folkways of the Northeast’s traditional white Anglo-Saxon Protestant society, of which he himself was a member, in plays like “The Middle Ages,” “The Dining Room” and “The Cocktail Hour,” died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Where to Score Summery Staples This Week
text: On Thursday, Arjé, a label designed by Bessie and Oliver Corral, the husband-and-wife duo who previously were head designers at Donna Karan’s Urban Zen, will open a summer pop-up. The gallerylike space is filled with warm-weather basics such as a sweater knit from the softest linen twisted yarn and merino wool ($670) and featherweight cotton poplin trousers ($470) — appropriate considering the shop’s name is taken from a Greek word philosophers used to describe “the essence of everything.” At 262 Mott Street.

headline: Activists Sue Police Dept. Over ‘Can’t Confirm or Deny’ Tactic
text: In the early 1970s, the reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes undertook a covert operation with the Central Intelligence Agency: He built a salvage ship, the Hughes Glomar Explorer, for a secret mission to raise a Soviet submarine that had sunk a few years earlier in the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Accusations About Bob Dylan’s Nobel Prize Lecture Rekindle an Old Debate
text: Perhaps it was just a matter of time.

headline: 4 Shot at Baseball Field, Including a Republican Congressman
text: Steve Scalise, the No. 3 Republican in the House of Representatives, was among those wounded when shots were fired in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Your Summer Style, Sorted
text: On “Seinfeld,” George Costanza dreamed of one day being able to drape himself in velvet, if it were socially acceptable. Not to rain on his parade, but linen or cotton would be a far savvier — not to mention, socially sanctioned — choice, particularly as summer begins to heat up. Certainly it is the preferred fabric for fashionable castaways in the city who must face the challenge of dressing appropriately for the office or crowded subway commute without dissolving into a puddle of sweat. Lightweight linen and cotton offer maximum breathability while keeping one covered — and, being natural, have added appeal to eco-minded shoppers. It’s no wonder, then, that so many new and under-the-radar labels have chosen to work almost exclusive with these materials. Here are five that are sure to become your new warm-weather go-tos.

headline: Gunman Kills 3 and Then Himself at San Francisco UPS Building
text: Three people were fatally shot and two were wounded when a co-worker opened fire on Wednesday inside a United Parcel Service complex in San Francisco, the authorities said. The gunman then shot himself to death.

headline: Two Parisian Creatives, at Home in the Countryside
text: “I just asked Gesa to marry me this morning!” Charles Compagnon said. He was driving to the verdant village of Courances, about 20 miles south of Paris, where he and his fiancée, the German-Danish furniture designer Gesa Hansen, just bought and refurbished a 19th-century country home. “And we found out that we’re having a baby girl. Things are good.”

headline: Criticism Builds as Theresa May Prepares to Form New Government
text: LONDON — Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain still hangs by a thread.

headline: Solemn Trump Calls for Unity After Congressman’s Shooting
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump, a political agitator pressed into the unfamiliar new role of soothing a nation, called for bipartisan unity in his first statement responding to the shooting  Wednesday morning of a congressman and three others on a suburban Virginia baseball diamond.

headline: An Attack on Congress and Baseball
text: A congressman was shot  early Wednesday morning while playing baseball with his colleagues in Virginia. The congressman, Steve Scalise, the majority whip of the House of Representatives, is in critical condition, and two other people were also critically wounded. It wasn’t just an attack on members of Congress and their staff and police protective details but on one of the few vestiges of bipartisanship left in Congress: baseball.

headline: San Francisco to Develop Treasure Island as Major Cultural Site
text: Earlier this year, George Lucas rejected Treasure Island in the San Francisco Bay as the home for his new Lucas Museum of Narrative Art. But San Francisco arts officials remain committed to developing the island as a major cultural destination and this week are releasing their Treasure Island “arts master plan” to the public.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Mastering a Master: How a Small Gallery Put On a Big Rodin Show
text: LONDON — Millions of dollars of insurance. Transport logistics. Paperwork. Labor. Movement sensors. Export duties. Artwork passports.

headline: Rodin Celebrations Around the World
text: RODIN: THE CENTENNIAL EXHIBITION, the Musée Rodin and Réunion des Musées Nationaux, Grand Palais, Paris. Over 200 Rodin works, as well as sculpture and drawings by Brancusi, Picasso, Matisse, Gormley and other artists. Through July 31.

headline: Instant Pot, the Latest Prized Kitchen Gadget, Has Staying Power
text: I’m a sucker for the latest kitchen technology. Vegetable spiralizers, smoke guns, you name it, especially if it has an LED light. And sometimes there are truly useful ones. I asked Lesley Stockton, staff writer for The Wirecutter and Sweethome, The New York Times’s product testing sites, for advice on a latest craze: the Instant Pot, a combination slow cooker/pressure cooker.

headline: No Strategy on Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Griffin Dunne Reads ‘Before the Web, Hearts Grew Silent’
text: On this week’s podcast, the actor Griffin Dunne reads “Before the Web, Hearts Grew Silent.” In it, the author David Vecsey writes about love in the time of no cellphones or social media.

headline: Mixed-Marriage Pioneers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘Cars 3,’ Lightning McQueen Faces an Existential Crisis
text: The conventional reviewers’ wisdom about Pixar’s “Cars” movies is that they are colorful and engaging but hardly as breathtaking as much of the other output from that animation studio. There are some who think Pixar should aim for awe-inspiring every time, because why not? Then there are crankier critics who will point out that driverless talking cars just aren’t terribly interesting, and can be a little goofy.

headline: Staubitz Market in Brooklyn: 100 Years of Sawdust, Steaks and Chops
text: A screen door slams, and a customer’s shoes shuffle across a hardwood floor sprinkled with sawdust. Behind a polished glass counter filled with carefully arranged steaks, lamb chops and other pristine cuts of meat stand several butchers, thick through the shoulders and hands, shiny with confidence and wearing aprons as white as copy paper. If the men are not in the middle of preparing an order, they are chatting with the regular customers. It’s 1917 in Staubitz Market on Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Or is it 2017?

headline: JW Anderson: Spring 2018
text: The label’s Men’s 2018 collection.

headline: Turtles Bred for Food in Asia Can Transport Cholera
text: Soft-shell turtles raised for food in Asia can infect people with cholera and spread the lethal bacteria from place to place, according to a new study.

headline: Rangers Are Buying Out Dan Girardi’s Contract
text: The Rangers said goodbye to a key member of their veteran core on Wednesday, buying out the remaining three years of defenseman Dan Girardi’s contract.

headline: ‘A Horse Walks Into a Bar’ Wins Man Booker International Prize
text: LONDON — “A Horse Walks Into a Bar,” a novel that centers on a stand-up routine that goes off the rails as a comic dredges up ghosts from his past, won the Man Booker International Prize, for work written in a language other than English, on Wednesday night.

headline: W.N.B.A. Players Union Leader Takes a Thoughtful Approach
text: As a five-time W.N.B.A. defensive player of the year, Tamika Catchings was adept at predicting how situations should unfold.

headline: United Airlines Apologizes After 2015 Video Shows Worker Shoving Customer
text: United Airlines has again been sued by a passenger for mistreatment, after he was pushed to the floor by a United employee in 2015 at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston. The airline issued an apology, but only after video of the episode was made public.

headline: A New Lure for Spa Customers? A Salt Cave
text: Two young women in white chamois robes exited the Himalayan salt sauna at Premier57, a spa in Midtown Manhattan, looking rosy and happily spent.

headline: Global, With Local Flavor: Restaurant Critic Pete Wells in Sydney
text: The restaurant world may be getting smaller but the actual distance between the earth’s major land masses hasn’t changed much. And so I found myself, once I’d landed in Sydney after a trip that was supposed to last about 20 hours but took much longer (delays, cancellations, rerouted planes) eating in a lot of restaurants that wouldn’t have been out of place in New York or any number of other cities where people take food seriously.

headline: Turkish Guards Will Be Charged in Embassy Protest, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials plan to announce charges Thursday against a dozen members of the Turkish president’s security detail for their involvement in a brutal attack on protesters outside the Turkish ambassador’s residence here last month, two American officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Wells Fargo Is Accused of Making Improper Changes to Mortgages
text: Even as Wells Fargo was reeling from a major scandal in its consumer bank last year, officials in the company’s mortgage business were putting through unauthorized changes to home loans held by customers in bankruptcy, a new class action and other lawsuits contend.

headline: Janet Yellen and the Case of the Missing Inflation
text: Inflation has stubbornly stayed lower than the Federal Reserve has desired for the past eight years, and it has been falling in the last few months. In a move that could well define her chairmanship of the central bank, Janet Yellen is betting that falling prices are a temporary blip that will soon be forgotten.

headline: Review: A Corrupt Cop Is Up Against the Wall in Don Winslow’s ‘The Force’
text: THE FORCE By Don Winslow 479 pp. William Morow. $27.99.

headline: London Fire Shows Why Britons Don’t Trust the System
text: LONDON — Helicopters are not unusual in London, but the intense buzzing from the sky at 5 a.m. roused me early. From my balcony, I could see a huge plume of smoke billowing up from behind trees. It came from a blaze at Grenfell Tower, a 24-floor residential building, not far from where I live in West London. The authorities declared it a major incident as more than 200 firefighters battled the fire, with an unknown number of people trapped inside.

headline: Street Style: Pitti Uomo
text: The Pitti Uomo fashion fair in Florence brings out the best dressed.

headline: They Know Robert Durst the Best. But They’re Not Talking.
text: Stewart and Emily Altman have been friends with Robert A. Durst for decades, even as he has faced numerous charges, including murder, over the years. Now they are engaged in a cross-country legal battle over whether they can be compelled to testify in a pretrial hearing in Mr. Durst’s Los Angeles trial in the killing of another close friend 17 years ago.

headline: Street Style: Pitti Uomo
text: New and old-world suiting styles faced off at the Pitti Uomo fashion fair in Florence, Italy.

headline: Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather Jr. Agree to Fight
text: Two years after Conor McGregor declared in an Esquire interview that he would “kill” the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. in “less than 30 seconds,” it appears that McGregor, a mixed martial arts star, will get his chance.

headline: Beth Ditto on Her New Time Capsule: Her First Solo Album
text: Beth Ditto did not set out to make her first full-length solo album. When she went into the studio a few years ago, Ms. Ditto, the powerhouse singer and feminist glamazon, planned to make another record for Gossip, the Portland, Ore., disco-punk trio she had fronted since 1999.

headline: Patricia Knatchbull, a Grande Dame of Britain’s Elite, Dies at 93
text: LONDON — Patricia Knatchbull, a grande dame of Britain’s titled elite, whose life embraced a fabled childhood between two world wars and deep personal tragedy after her father and a teenage son were killed in a bomb attack at sea, died on Tuesday at her home in England, in Mersham, Kent. Lady Mountbatten, as she was known, was 93.

headline: Fox News Drops ‘Fair and Balanced’ Motto
text: Fox News is “Fair and Balanced” no more.

headline: Civil Rights Groups Sue Chicago Over Abuses by Police
text: Hoping to step into the breach left by the end of the Obama administration’s aggressive approach to civil rights abuses by the police, a coalition of civil rights groups filed a federal lawsuit against the City of Chicago on Wednesday.

headline: Despite Public Outcry, Egypt to Transfer Islands to Saudi Arabia
text: CAIRO — The fate of Tiran and Sanafir, a pair of small, barren islands in the Red Sea, is one of the most politically sensitive issues facing Egypt’s president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.

headline: New York Adding Shelter Options for Homeless Victims of Domestic Abuse
text: Domestic violence continues to drive homelessness in New York City, ahead of evictions and overcrowding, at a time when the city’s primary shelter system is so taxed that Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to open 90 new facilities over five years.

headline: De Blasio Makes a Rare Underground Appearance
text: There were plenty of seats on the uptown C train as it creaked its way from Pennsylvania Station to Times Square. But one patron, standing 6-foot-5 in a shiny blue suit and clutching a leather folder, opted to stand.

headline: Ronald Markman, an Artist Who Conjured His Own Kingdom, Dies at 86
text: The artist worked to break free of the confines of classical art, and wasn’t afraid to poke fun at society.

headline: Finding Bravado, and Worry, at an Iranian Shrine Where ISIS Struck
text: TEHRAN — I had visited the sprawling mausoleum of the founder of the Islamic republic multiple times, trying to blend in with pilgrims.

headline: Moving a Mezuza
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Bunkers at U.S. Open Course Give New Meaning to ‘Sand Hazard’
text: ERIN, Wis. — The 138 bunkers that will be in play at this year’s United States Open have nothing remotely routine about them.

headline: Shooting Shines Light on an Annual Baseball Game and a Bipartisan Pastime
text: WASHINGTON — It was an attack on politicians in the least political of venues: a baseball field.

headline: Shaken Lawmakers Soften Partisan Tone While Uniting in Concern
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Chuck Fleischmann stood just outside the House chamber in the Capitol on Wednesday morning recounting his harrowing survival of a shooting rampage aimed at a group of lawmakers practicing for an annual charity baseball game. He was still wearing his cleats and red jersey with “Republicans” emblazoned across the front.

headline: Georgia Escapees Steal Second Vehicle as Manhunt Continues
text: The two escaped inmates who the authorities say killed two Georgia prison guards stole a second vehicle overnight as they began their second day on the run, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Their Own Targeted, Republicans Want Looser Gun Laws, Not Stricter Ones
text: WASHINGTON — Shaken and angry, Republican members of Congress seized on the brazen daytime shooting of their colleagues on Wednesday to demand that existing restrictions on gun access be loosened so that people facing similar attacks are able to defend themselves.

headline: Saudi Arabia Tries to Ease Concerns Over Civilian Deaths in Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia is engaging in a $750 million, multiyear training program through the American military to help prevent the accidental killing of civilians in the Saudi-led air campaign against Houthi rebels in Yemen.

headline: ‘Trump’ Named Children’s Word of the Year. That’s Trumpwinningtastic.
text: LONDON — It’s the greatest word. The best.

headline: Senate Backs Measure Limiting President’s Power to Lift Sanctions
text: The Senate voted nearly unanimously on Wednesday to allow Congress to strip the president of the power to unilaterally lift existing sanctions against Russia, a matter that had many of President Trump’s allies siding with his harshest critics.

headline: A Finger Exercise On Hyperglobalization
text: The days when surging world trade was the big story seem like a long time ago. For one thing, trade has stopped surging, and seems to have plateaued. For another, we have more pressing issues, like the rise of authoritarianism and the attempt to sabotage health care.

headline: The Fall and Rise of Australian Culture
text: (Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.)

headline: U.S.-Led Airstrikes in Syria Killed Hundreds of Civilians, U.N. Panel Says
text: GENEVA — Airstrikes by the American-led coalition against Islamic State targets have killed hundreds of civilians around Raqqa, the militant group’s last Syrian stronghold, and left 160,000 people displaced, a United Nations panel said on Wednesday.

headline: The Universal Phenomenon of Men Interrupting Women
text: For women in business and beyond, it was an I-told-you-so day.

headline: Mueller Seeks to Talk to Intelligence Officials, Hinting at Inquiry of Trump
text: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel examining Russia’s meddling in the 2016 election, has requested interviews with three high-ranking current or former intelligence officials, the latest indication that he will investigate whether President Trump obstructed justice, a person briefed on the investigation said on Wednesday.

headline: Robert S. Leiken, Political Scientist Who Defied Labels, Dies at 78
text: Robert S. Leiken, a maverick political scientist who stunned fellow liberals in the 1980s when he denounced the leftist Sandinista government in Nicaragua, died on June 7 in Boston. He was 78.

headline: America’s Lethal Politics
text: America’s elected representatives enjoying America’s pastime on a ball field just across the Potomac from the Capitol: A particularly American form of terror changed that idyll early Wednesday morning into what Senator Rand Paul, who was there, called “basically a killing field.”

headline: 39 Members of MS-13 Are Arrested, Authorities Say
text: Thirty-nine members of MS-13, a brutal gang with roots in Central America, were arrested by the immigration authorities in New York in the past month, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Shooting Is Latest Eruption in a Grim Ritual of Rage and Blame
text: The violence has come regularly for years, in one politically charged spasm after another. A member of Congress shot through the head in Tucson. Assaults on the Holocaust Museum, a Planned Parenthood office and the Family Research Council, a socially conservative group. Gunmen targeting black churchgoers in South Carolina, Indian immigrants in Kansas and police officers in New York and Texas.

headline: Attack Tests Movement Sanders Founded
text: WASHINGTON — The most ardent supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders have long been outspoken about their anger toward Republicans — and in some cases toward Democrats. Their idol, the senator from Vermont, has called President Trump a “demagogue” and said recently that he was “perhaps the worst and most dangerous president in the history of our country.”

headline: Company Lost Secret 2014 Fight Over ‘Expansion’ of N.S.A. Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — An American communications company in 2014 balked at an “expansion” of the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program, but was ordered to comply by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, a newly declassified document shows.

headline: Something That Might Be Bleeped
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Occasionally, we get mail from people who are shocked, absolutely shocked, at an entry or clue that appears in the puzzles, and that is always interesting because everyone’s mileage for what is “appropriate” in a newspaper crossword puzzle varies significantly.

headline: Shabab Kill 31 and Take Hostages in Somalia’s Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Militants began an assault in the capital, Mogadishu, on Wednesday evening with a car bombing at the gates of a hotel popular with foreigners, and continued with gunfire at a nearby restaurant.

headline: Dustin Johnson Is Favored at a Major Again. Just Watch the Stairs.
text: ERIN, Wis. — Which poses the greater obstacle to Dustin Johnson’s chances of successfully defending his United States Open title: the diabolical fescue grass that frames the fairways at Erin Hills or the double-spiral staircase in his rental house?

headline: Home Runs by Curtis Granderson and Lucas Duda Help Mets Rally Past Cubs

headline: Sabathia Looks Headed to D.L. as Struggling Yankees Lose to Angels

headline: A Blue Note Jazz Club Is Coming to Brazil
text: The music of Brazil has exerted an outsize influence on jazz in the United States since at least the early 1960s, but its impact has come at a remove — largely from recordings, and the renown of a few Brazilian stars, rather than through immigration and interaction.

headline: Leonard Cohen Exhibition Is Planned for Museum in Montreal
text: Leonard Cohen’s life and career as a visual artist, poet and musician will get the exhibition treatment at the Musée d’Art Contemporain de Montréal.

headline: The Dutch Have Solutions to Rising Seas. The World Is Watching.
text: In the waterlogged Netherlands, climate change is considered neither a hypothetical nor a drag on the economy. Instead, it’s an opportunity.

text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘The Tunnel: Sabotage’ and a Salute to Diane Keaton
text: “The Tunnel” returns with a fresh investigation — and without the baggage of “The Bridge.” Diane Keaton is honored by the American Film Institute. And Cate Blanchett, Heath Ledger and others channel various aspects of Bob Dylan in Todd Haynes’s musical essay, “I’m Not There.”

headline: Word + Quiz: anthropologist
Found Poem Favorite | ‘Glasses’
text: We are honoring the top winners of our Eighth Annual Found Poem Student Contest by publishing their work from June 13 to July 3. You’ll be able to read the whole collection here as we go.

headline: Daughters Will Suffer From Medicaid Cuts
text: Nearly one in five adult children at some point provide care for at least one elderly parent, according to a new study by the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College. The burden is particularly demanding for daughters, who spend as much time on such care as spouses of older adults, and as much time as sons, in-laws, grandchildren and other relatives combined.

headline: Trump’s Imminent Cuba Problem
text: Soon — maybe as early as Friday — President Donald Trump, with Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, is expected to announce a presidential initiative that will roll back the Obama-era efforts that loosened the 56-year-old United States embargo on Cuba. How far will the president go?

headline: Regulatory ‘Reform’ That Is Anything But
text: After decades of failed efforts to enact “regulatory reform” bills, Congress appears to be within a few votes of approving reform legislation that would strip Americans of important legal protections, induce regulatory sclerosis and subject agencies that enforce the nation’s laws and regulations to potentially endless litigation.

headline: How ISIS Grew in the Philippines
text: While President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines was bragging about his brutal war on drugs, the Islamic State was consolidating its sway over Islamist rebel groups on the island of Mindanao. The extent to which ISIS has succeeded is now alarmingly evident, as a pitched battle between Philippine troops and Islamist militants for control of the largely Muslim city of Marawi enters its fourth week.

headline: Rhetoric and Bullets
text: In 2011, after Representative Gabby Giffords of Arizona was gravely injured and six others were killed by a shooter in Tucson, I was moved to commit an entire column to condemning the left for linking the shooting so closely to political rhetoric.

headline: Where Democrats Can Find New Voters
text: The relentless focus on the white working class in the aftermath of the election of President Trump has overshadowed a much larger bloc of voters, the roughly 65 million service sector workers whose partisan loyalty is up for grabs.

headline: Play Ball, and Then Gunfire
text: When a gunman opened fire on a congressional baseball practice Wednesday, everyone in Washington looked for a positive message. There had to be a point to something so awful. The consensus was for Coming Together.

headline: Questions for: ‘Steve Scalise Among 4 Shot at Baseball Field; Suspect Is Dead’
text: Article: Steve Scalise Among 4 Shot at Baseball Field; Suspect Is Dead

headline: The Children of ‘1984’: Dystopia Down the Decades
text: The stage adaptation of “1984” opening on Thursday, June 22, may be George Orwell’s Broadway debut. But his novel — and coinages like Big Brother, thought police and double-think — have never been far from the cultural stage. Here’s a partial history of the prophetic year that somehow never passes into the past.

headline: Do You Have ‘Emerging Adult’ Skills?
text: Do you feel prepared to enter the world of adulthood? What sorts of skills and habits do you think you need to be a successful, self-sufficient adult?

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Canadian Football League
text: In November 1989, the Saskatchewan Roughriders met the Hamilton Tiger-Cats at the SkyDome in Toronto for the Canadian Football League’s championship game. I was 9 years old, and I had already developed a tortured relationship with the Roughriders, familiar to any of the million-odd people who live in the province where I grew up. Until that point in the club’s 79-year history, the Riders had taken home just one title; in an eight-team league, this fact seemed to defy the laws of statistics.

headline: A Whimsical Wordsmith Charts a Course Beyond Twitter
text: There are a few things we should clear up about the Twitter humorist known as “jomny sun.” Although sun’s Twitter bio describes him as an “aliebn confuesed abot humamn lamgauge,” and his avatar is a line drawing of a smiling alien in a T-shirt, he is, in fact, a real person, and that really is his name. Also, he knows how to spell.

headline: 36 Hours in Birmingham, Ala.
text: This quintessential Southern city with a complex past is ready to surprise you.

headline: For Sale: A $7 Million Wild West Town
text: As a family-owned amusement park opens for the summer, its owners of 43 years ponder its future. Step inside Donley’s Wild West Town in Union, Ill. in 360-degree video.

headline: As Female Elk Age, They Learn to Evade Hunters
text: If you come across an old elk in southwestern Canada, chances are it is female.

headline: The Pleasure of a Chilled Soup on a Sweltering Day
text: Back when it used to snow in winter and bloom in spring, and when the dog days of summer came reliably in August and not weirdly in April or June, I used to drink ice-cold schav to keep from falling completely apart. In those days, we languished in our East Village or Hell’s Kitchen railroad apartments — the kind with floors that sloped and a tub in the kitchen from which you could reach a wet hand out of the morning shower to turn off the gas under the hissing pot of Café Bustelo. You’d throw your key down in a balled-up tube sock to friends below on the sidewalk — because the buzzer never worked — and you’d sit out on the fire escape at night to try to stay cool.

headline: With ‘1984’ on Broadway, Thoughtcrime Hits the Big Time
text: A British adaptation of George Orwell’s “1984,” first staged in 2013, had three successful runs in the West End and national and international tours, including stops in Boston, Los Angeles and Washington. There was talk of bringing it to New York, but no sense of urgency.

headline: Explaining Executive Privilege and Sessions’s Refusal to Answer Questions
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions repeatedly refused to answer senators’ questions on Tuesday about his conversations with President Trump, even though Mr. Trump had not asserted executive privilege to keep them secret. That raises questions about whether Mr. Sessions had any legal basis to stonewall Congress.

headline: Packages for New ‘Pandora-The World of Avatar’ in Orlando
text: Pandora — the World of Avatar opened in May at Disney’s Animal Kingdom in Orlando, Fla., and travel companies that specialize in Disney vacations were ready and waiting with Pandora packages.

text: • Read updates from Day 10 of the Bill Cosby trial.

headline: When Mom and Pop Can’t Sell the Farm (or in This Case, the Theme Park)
text: UNION, Ill. — It’s not easy selling a Wild West Town theme park located 60 miles northwest of Chicago, as Larry and Helene Donley have discovered.

headline: More Space, and More Projects, in a Place Upstate
text: Though Sean Hanna and Scott Melcher were happy in their two-bedroom rental in Astoria, Queens, they longed for outdoor space.

text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.
