headline: Slipping Into Prom Outfits, and Soon, They Hope, Out of Flint
text: From our home base of The New York Times’s Midwest bureau in Chicago, my fellow correspondents and I have logged dozens of trips to Flint, Mich., to cover the city’s most urgent and troubling issue: its water.

headline: A Grudge Match With the Big Man
text: LONDON — My flight to Nairobi, Kenya, landed before 6 a.m., but even at that hour the pulsating heat hit like a sucker punch. Half awake, I was struck by the frenetic activity on the tarmac, a blur of uniforms, crowds, cameras and bustle. I assumed there must be a preening bwana mkubwa, or big man, at the front of the plane, readying himself to be met with pomp, chaos and a convoy.

headline: Read the Commission's Statement on Civil Rights Enforcement
text: The U.S. Civil Rights Commission voted on Friday to launch a two year examination into the Trump administration's enforcement of civil rights laws. The commission then released its decision in a statement.

headline: Education Dept. Says It Will Scale Back Civil Rights Investigations
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Education is scaling back investigations into civil rights violations at the nation’s public schools and universities, easing off mandates imposed by the Obama administration that the new leadership says have bogged down the agency.

headline: Spectator, 94, Dies at the United States Open
text: ERIN, Wis. — A 94-year-old man watching the United States Open died Friday afternoon, according to the United States Golf Association.

headline: Mets Add to Loss Column, but Disabled List Doesn’t Grow
text: This is what passes for good news at Citi Field these days: On Friday, all the Mets lost was a baseball game.

headline: Rooted in Counterculture, Whole Foods’ Founder Finds an Unlikely Refuge
text: Since John Mackey co-founded a precursor to Whole Foods in 1978, he has taken a hands-on management approach to the organic grocery chain. He personally oversaw each step of its national expansion. During a takeover battle 10 years ago, Mr. Mackey used a pseudonym to write anonymous blog posts attacking a competitor.

headline: Woman Sentenced in Texting Suicide Case
text: Michelle Carter, who was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter for urging her boyfriend to commit suicide through text messages and phone calls in 2014, was sentenced to 15 months in jail.

headline: A Campus Argument Goes Viral. Now the College Is Under Siege.
text: OLYMPIA, Wash. — It started with a suggestion that white students and professors leave campus for a day, a twist on a tradition of black students voluntarily doing the same.

headline: Playing Tricks With Dodd-Frank
text: When President Trump vowed in January to do “a big number on Dodd-Frank,” the post-crisis law passed in 2010 to rein in Wall Street, it was possible to hope, however naïvely, that he would offer alternative bank reform. During the campaign, he denounced Wall Street for having “robbed our working class,” a reference to the jobs, wages, savings and home equity wiped out in the financial crash. In addition, both Mr. Trump and the Republican platform called for a modern version of Glass-Steagall, the law, repealed in 1999, that had separated staid commercial banking from risky investment banking.

headline: Juneteenth Word Search
text: Monday is the 152nd anniversary of Juneteenth, the day slavery in the United States effectively ended. To help you commemorate the holiday, we created a puzzle to recognize a small slice of the African-American experience.

headline: Border Patrol Raids Humanitarian Aid Group Camp in Arizona
text: PHOENIX — The Border Patrol raided a humanitarian aid group’s base camp in the Southern Arizona desert on Thursday and arrested four men who had crossed into the United States illegally, officials with Customs and Border Protection said.

headline: A Cynical Reversal on Cuba
text: Fans of Cuban rum and cigars can rest easy. So can the Starwood chain, which has a deal to manage a historic hotel in Havana. But Americans who want to vacation in Cuba or start doing business there will find it harder as a result of President Trump’s misguided decision to slam the brakes on a two-year-old diplomatic opening with the island.

headline: Beyond Blades of Grass
text: The other night, mowing my lawn for the first time this spring, I was instantly transported back to my childhood. “I love that smell,” I later said to my fiancée, and didn’t have to explain; we were two suburban-raised Minnesota kids for whom the scent of freshly cut grass has long confirmed winter’s end. Like many an American teenager, I had a monopoly on mowing my neighborhood’s lawns, coming home most summer days with inch-long clippings clinging to socks and grass-stained shoes. I learned to see the perfect lawn as a lush monochrome carpet of Kentucky bluegrass, trimmed and deep green.

headline: The Black Sea Turned Turquoise, Thanks to a Phytoplankton Bloom
text: The Black Sea isn’t black, and it’s not usually turquoise either. But a huge bloom of phytoplankton has illuminated it — and the connected Bosporus and the Golden Horn of Istanbul — with beautiful swirls of milky blue-green. This aquatic artwork appears every summer, but this year’s bloom is one of the brightest since 2012, according to Norman Kuring, a NASA scientist. It’s so bright, it can be seen from space.

headline: Only Mass Deportation Can Save America
text: In the matter of immigration, mark this conservative columnist down as strongly pro-deportation. The United States has too many people who don’t work hard, don’t believe in God, don’t contribute much to society and don’t appreciate the greatness of the American system.

headline: Day of Doom
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Yesterday, we talked about the difference between constructing a themed versus a themeless crossword, and today we have a puzzle that is not only a very impressive debut, but is also a great example of why constructors (and their solvers) benefit from choosing fun and sparkling seed entries. Seed entries are typically longer, flashier entries that a constructor might make note of and say, “Now that would look great/be fun to solve in a crossword.”

headline: Corrections: June 17, 2017
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Name Your Pick for TrumpWorld’s Worst Cabinet Member
text: Who do you think is Donald Trump’s worst cabinet member?

headline: A Lost Chance for Peace in Vietnam
text: Perhaps no question hovers more ominously over the history of the Vietnam War in 1967 than this: If the United States and its Vietnamese adversaries had been able to hammer out an acceptable peace deal before the major escalation of the 1968 Tet offensive, hundreds of thousands of lives would have been saved. Was such a peace possible?

headline: Alexandria Gunman Carried List With Names of 3 Republican Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — The gunman who targeted Republican congressmen this week at a baseball field in suburban Washington was carrying a list with the names of at least three lawmakers, and had pictures of the ballpark stored on his cellphone, two law enforcement officials said on Friday.

headline: Trump Hires Veteran Lawyer With Deep Experience in Washington
text: President Trump has added John Dowd, a veteran lawyer in Washington, to his legal team in the face of investigations related to Russian meddling in the 2016 election, as well as possible obstruction of justice in the firing of the James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.

headline: John Avildsen, Director of ‘Rocky’ and ‘The Karate Kid,’ Dies at 81
text: John G. Avildsen, who as the director of “Rocky” and “The Karate Kid” created pop culture touchstones by telling stories of down-and-out characters finding triumph, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Hiding Christians in the Basement: Fear and Heroism in a Philippine War Zone
text: MARAWI, Philippines — Three Christian civilians said they had cowered in a basement for weeks while militants inspired by the Islamic State went door to door killing non-Muslims in the southern Philippine city of Marawi before fleeing for their lives at dawn on Tuesday.

headline: Two Protesters Disrupt ‘Julius Caesar’ in Central Park
text: A production of “Julius Caesar” in Central Park was disrupted on Friday evening by two protesters who objected to the bloody scene in which the title character, played by an actor costumed and styled to resemble President Trump, is knifed to death.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Conjuring 2’ and the Electric Daisy Carnival
text: Go for chills as the Amityville investigators Lorraine and Ed Warren, played by Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson, take on a case in London. Or dance away the weekend with the Electric Daisy Carnival.

headline: Yankees Lose Fourth Straight as an Athletics Novice Shines
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The way the Yankees have been going — with injuries here, there and everywhere — it hardly seemed a surprise when pitcher Luis Severino banged his right knee while standing near his locker on Friday afternoon.

headline: Can Animals Predict Earthquakes? Italian Farm Acts as a Lab to Find Out
text: PIEVE TORINA, Italy — After a series of powerful earthquakes struck Italy last year, Martin Wikelski rushed here to test a hunch that has tantalized scientists and thinkers for millenniums: Can animals anticipate natural disasters?

headline: After Tragedy, Healing a Charleston Church
text: On June 17, 2015, nine people were shot and killed inside Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C. In this 360° video, stand with the congregation during a Sunday service.

headline: ‘I Have Stopped Taking My Notebooks and Pens to Meetings’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: In Whole Foods, Bezos Gets a Sustainably Sourced Guinea Pig
text: When big tech companies make big moves, it’s natural to see the news in earthshaking terms.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Sexual Assault Case Ends in a Mistrial
text: The judge in the sexual assault trial of Bill Cosby declared a mistrial Saturday after jurors reported being hopelessly deadlocked after six days of deliberations, bringing an inconclusive end to this phase of one of the highest-profile cases in recent history.

headline: U.S. Open Grass Is an Obstacle and a Potential Health Hazard
text: ERIN, Wis. — Jimmy Walker’s wife cringed when, on her social media feed, she saw photographs of players and caddies wading into Erin Hills’s thick fescue grass during practice rounds for the United States Open. She remembered thinking, “Somebody’s going to get sick this week.”

headline: The Decline of the Baronial C.E.O.
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — They bestrode the business world, or at least the suburban corporate campus, like a colossus.

headline: Both Climate Leader and Oil Giant? A Norwegian Paradox
text: OSLO — On an unseasonably warm day in May, Norway’s climate minister, Vidar Helgesen, strolled through a vast parking lot for electric cars, counting Teslas.

headline: Iran Bans Zumba, and Its Fans Fume
text: TEHRAN — To those Iranians shaking their hips and backsides to Latin American music during Zumba exercise classes, Iran’s Muslim clerics — and an American company — have the same message: Stop it. It’s illegal.

headline: Father-Daughter Dance Gets a Makeover in ‘Modern Family’ Era
text: The annual father-daughter dance at Benito Martinez Elementary School in El Paso is a highlight on the school calendar. Candy-color tablecloths camouflage cafeteria tables, and strobe lights transform the gymnasium into a dance floor. The girls, from kindergarten through fifth grade, don dresses and pose for pictures with their dates. Many of the 300 guests stay for the grand finale: a slow dance to Bob Carlisle’s “Butterfly Kisses.”

headline: Al Franken and Olivia Wilde: Calling a Lie a Lie
text: Twenty years before Kellyanne Conway seized the news cycle with “alternative facts” about President Trump’s inaugural crowd size, Al Franken (now, Senator Al Franken) began a satirical cottage industry to expose the seemingly loose grasp on truth of various right-wing pundits in such books as “Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right.”

headline: Trump Is Offering Populism, Minus the Free Candy
text: The thing about populism is it usually involves doing things that are popular.

headline: The Golden State Warriors’ Record-Setting Postseason
text: The Golden State Warriors began the postseason on April 16 and concluded it on June 12, and only once in that time did they make a false step.

headline: As Asian Scorchers Multiply, Records Fall and Attention Rises
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Residents of Turbat, a remote town in southwestern Pakistan, have had to cope with punishingly hot weather for generations. But when the mercury climbed to 129.2 degrees Fahrenheit on May 28 — potentially the hottest temperature ever recorded in Asia — relief proved elusive, partly because Turbat suffers from regular electricity shortages.

headline: A Mother’s Death, a Botched Inquiry and a Sheriff at War
text: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — Rusty Rodgers did not fit everyone’s image of a law enforcement officer, particularly in deeply conservative northeast Florida. One police chief, well ensconced in the local power structure, expressed irritation over what he called the officer’s “Jimmy Buffett look” — long hair, beard, loafers and no socks.

headline: Emporio Armani: Spring 2018
text: The latest men’s designs from the label.

headline: Amazon’s Move Signals End of Line for Many Cashiers
text: Imagine this scene from the future: You walk into a store and are greeted by name, by a computer with facial recognition that directs you to the items you need. You peruse a small area — no chance of getting lost or wasting time searching for things — because the store stocks only sample items. You wave your phone in front of anything you want to buy, then walk out. In the back, robots retrieve your items from a warehouse and deliver them to your home via driverless car or drone.

headline: Farhad’s, Mike’s and Cade’s Week in Tech: More Uber, With a Dash of Amazon
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. This week, Farhad and Mike also talked with Cade Metz, who just joined The Times as a technology reporter.

headline: Airbnb Tries to Behave More Like a Hotel
text: DENVER — For nine years, Jill Bishop enjoyed the camaraderie of renting out her spare bedroom on Airbnb.

headline: In Goma, Lights May Flicker but Looks Stay Sharp
text: The Democratic Republic of Congo is the birthplace of SAPE, a loosely organized cult of dandies known as “les sapeurs.” SAPE is an abbreviation of the group’s name, which in English translates as the Society of Ambience and Elegant People. The contrast between the extravagance of their attire and the hardships of their lives has the effect of highlighting the dignity of their code. Indeed, dressing well is part of the culture there.

headline: Ralph Lauren Purple Label: Spring 2018
text: Mr. Lauren’s latest collection.

headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
text: Travel season is fully upon us! Get out there and see the country, the world, your state or even just your backyard. (The staycation is a wonderful thing.) Still figuring out your plans? We’re here to help.

headline: With This Ring, I Thee Send to the Emergency Room
text: Uzezi Elakeche Abugo and Jacob David Alderdice were married June 17. The Rev. Bijan Mirtolooi, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden in the Randall Manor section of Staten Island.

headline: A First Kiss? Well, First Let Me Lie Down
text: Cyndie Spiegel and Ira James Hudspeth were married June 17 at the home of the groom’s family in Taylors Falls, Minn. Peter Ferko, a friend of the couple, received permission from Chisago County in Minnesota to officiate.

headline: Billing Tenants for Trash Violations
text: Q. I live in a small, rent-stabilized building in the East Village, with garbage and recycling cans unlocked and on the street. Neighbors and passers-by frequently use our bins, causing trash and recycling to overflow and commingle, so the city often tickets our building. Our landlord blames the tenants and now says that whenever the building gets ticketed, he will divide the fine among us. Is that legal?

headline: Bodies of Several Sailors Are Found Aboard Damaged U.S. Destroyer
text: TOKYO — The bodies of several missing American sailors were found in the flooded berthing compartments of the damaged naval destroyer Fitzgerald on Sunday, a day after it was rammed by a container ship four times its size off the Japanese coast, the Navy said in a statement and a Twitter post.

headline: 7 U.S. Soldiers Wounded in Insider Attack in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seven American soldiers were shot and wounded by an Afghan commando on Saturday, the second such insider attack in a week, according to Afghan officials.

headline: 58 Presumed Dead in London Tower Blaze, Police Say
text: The London police said on Saturday that the death toll from the inferno at the Grenfell Tower in west London had risen to 58.

headline: Trump’s Business Ties in the Gulf Raise Questions About His Allegiances
text: LONDON — President Trump has done business with royals from Saudi Arabia for at least 20 years, since he sold the Plaza Hotel to a partnership formed by a Saudi prince. Mr. Trump has earned millions of dollars from the United Arab Emirates for putting his name on a golf course, with a second soon to open.

headline: Marni: Spring 2018
text: The label shows its spring collection.

headline: Grim Echoes for Families: An Officer Shoots and a Jury Acquits
text: ST. PAUL — When the verdict came down on Friday — another police officer found not guilty in the killing of another black man — a father 700 miles away, in Oklahoma, felt as if he were watching a sickening replay of his own son’s fate. Other families of those killed in previous police shootings, who happened to be gathered in Detroit for a conference this past week, felt reverberations of their own pain.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — If the name Fraser Simpson sounds familiar, you are most likely a solver of British-style cryptic crosswords. Mr. Simpson had a single Saturday, American-style crossword in The New York Times in 2001, but readers may recognize him for his cryptic crossword contributions. A native of Toronto, he has made cryptic crosswords for The Globe and Mail for more than 20 years, making him the longest running Canadian “setter” (that’s British for “constructor”) whose work has appeared nationwide, according to Joshua Kosman and Henri Picciotto of “The Nation.”

headline: Rooting for Scalise Through Hospital Ordeal: His 3 Capitol Roommates
text: WASHINGTON — In the hours following the Congressional Baseball Game, after a convincing win by the Democrats and the end of postgame schmoozing, three Republican congressmen returned late Thursday to a rowhouse they share and popped open a bottle of wine.

headline: Whole Foods Deal Shows Amazon’s Prodigious Tolerance for Risk
text: Joke all you want about drone-delivered kale and arugula. Amazon’s $13.4 billion bet to take on the $800 billion grocery business in the United States by acquiring Whole Foods fits perfectly into the retailer’s business model.

headline: Before the Gunfire in Virginia, a Volatile Home Life in Illinois
text: BELLEVILLE, Ill. — Signs of a deeply disturbed family life kept surfacing from the well-kept house with the pale sun awning and the pretty flowerpots off a gravel road here.

headline: Trump’s Cuba Policy Divides Cuban-Americans
text: President Trump says he is reinstating travel and commercial restrictions eased by the Obama administration in an attempt to obtain additional concessions from the Cuban government.

headline: Election Success for Emmanuel Macron May Mask Real Challenges
text: NANTES, France — The parliamentary candidates running under the banner of the newly elected president, Emmanuel Macron, appear poised to win a crushing electoral majority on Sunday that extends from France’s Alpine heights to the Brittany coast and from the Mediterranean to Paris.

headline: Neil Barrett: Spring 2018
text: The label shows its spring collection.

headline: On Death Row, but Is He Innocent?
text: This article was published in 2017. See the latest in-depth article about this case from Nicholas Kristof.

headline: Her ‘Whole Story’: How I Landed an Exclusive Interview With Chelsea Manning
text: On Jan. 17, I was on the phone with Nancy Hollander, a veteran litigator based in New Mexico, when Ms. Hollander abruptly excused herself: The White House was on the other line.

headline: My Dad’s Sudden Outburst: ‘I Love You’
text: “I love you.”

headline: Trump, Uber and the Hazards of Broism
text: WASHINGTON — It’s been a bad week for brozillas.

headline: Admit It. Summer’s Terrible.
text: As I squinted and sweated to the office recently, I realized that summer’s here and it’s too late to work out. This is the body I find myself in, pale as the moon, heavy as the soil after rainfall, the only one I have to get me through to September.

headline: Another, Far Different, Washington Billionaire
text: One famous Washington billionaire has spent years and millions of his dollars building a culture of public service. Yes, it’s not President Trump.

headline: Allies Start Planning a Life Without America
text: Many governments must be thinking along the same lines, but few have spelled it out so clearly. Germany did, when Chancellor Angela Merkel said, “The times in which we could rely fully on others — they are somewhat over.” Now Canada, a country tightly bound to its neighbor by history, alliance and the longest border in the world, has declared the need to recognize that the United States is relinquishing its role as the “indispensable nation.”

headline: Mr. Trump’s Dangerous Indifference to Russia
text: A rival foreign power launched an aggressive cyberattack on the United States, interfering with the 2016 presidential election and leaving every indication that it’s coming back for more — but President Trump doesn’t seem to care.

headline: The Danger of Ignoring Alex Jones
text: Alex Jones, the conspiracy trafficker who runs the website Infowars, believes that Sept. 11 was an “inside job” and that the massacre of children at Sandy Hook was faked. These are cruel falsehoods that most people don’t want to confront on broadcast television. Megyn Kelly’s decision to interview him, for a show to air Sunday night, has been roundly criticized by people who suggest that we would be better off denying this fringe extremist exposure.

headline: Notes on a Political Shooting
text: THE first thing to say about the attempted massacre of congressional Republicans on a baseball field in suburban Virginia is that the motivations of the shooter were unusual. By which I mean that, based on what we know, James Hodgkinson had surprisingly normal political beliefs. He hated Donald Trump, he liked Bernie Sanders, he wanted higher taxes on the wealthy. He was not a Communist or a paranoid knight on a shadowy crusade, but an ordinary Midwestern Democrat with far more rage but the same frustrations as many decent liberals.

headline: I’m O.K. — You’re Pure Evil
text: In denouncing the hatred that brought bloodshed to a baseball diamond in Alexandria, Va., some people went ahead and spread more of it. Rush Limbaugh, take a bow. You called the shooter “a mainstream Democrat voter.” What do I call you? I want to be clear about my disgust, but not disgusting in my expression of it. That’s the hell of American politics and American discourse today, with its 140-character emissions.

headline: The Upside of Bad Genes
text: There’s a well-to-do couple thinking about having children. They order a battery of genetic tests to ensure that there’s nothing untoward lurking in their genomes. And they discover that they each carry one copy of the sickle cell gene.

headline: Is Pride Still for Queer People Like Me?
text: “You going to the parade?”

headline: The Anti-Uber
text: HURON, CALIF. — Carmen Lopez, a retired farmworker, keeps a Bible on the back seat of her silver 2003 Honda and crochet hooks and a Spanish-language potboiler in her purse. In her line of work, she waits a lot.

headline: Liberals in Strange Places
text: GUESS which state has the highest interest in impeaching President Trump.

headline: Trump the Transparent
text: They call it “transparency,” and it’s all the rage in serious circles. Everyone wants more of it, as long as it’s not their own secrets being revealed. Those are much too important. So journalists will go to jail to protect their sources — i.e., keep them secret — to encourage whistle blowers to reveal government secrets.

headline: Religious Liberals’ Moment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Versace: Spring 2018
text: Dontella Versace presents her spring collection.

headline: A Skewed Lens on Terror
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Chasing the Stratford Streak, 80 Years After He Left the Ice
text: STRATFORD, Ontario — Howie Morenz wept when he finally agreed to join the Montreal Canadiens in 1923, abandoning his family and a budding career as a railway machinist in Stratford to become the world’s greatest hockey player.

headline: Why Couldn’t the Cosby Jury Reach a Verdict? Legal Experts Assess
text: As the jury’s deliberations extended into this weekend, the possibility of a verdict in Bill Cosby’s sexual assault trial seemed to dim, though legal experts cautioned against drawing any conclusions. But when the judge in the case, Steven T. O’Neill, declared a mistrial on Saturday morning after the jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked, some criminal law experts who had been closely following the proceedings suggested that the conclusion was hardly unexpected.

headline: Kiwis, After Rewinding a Painful Loss in Their Minds, Hit Fast Forward
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — The last time Glenn Ashby sailed against Oracle Team USA in an America’s Cup match, it ended in crushing disappointment. The United States had stormed back from an overwhelming deficit to finish off an unlikely 9-8 comeback victory over New Zealand to retain the Cup in San Francisco in 2013.

headline: #MyOCanada: Canadians, Let’s Hear Your Voices in Your Anthem
text: We’d like to hear you sing “O Canada.”

headline: 300 Wins? Today, Try 200 Innings
text: Jon Lester reached the major leagues at 22 years old. For nearly a decade, he has made all his scheduled starts. He almost always plays for good teams and wins much more often than he loses.

headline: As Uber Leaders Step Aside, Arianna Huffington’s Influence Grows
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In April, Wan Ling Martello, the head of Nestlé in Asia, found herself seated across from Arianna Huffington, an Uber director and a founder of The Huffington Post, at the Union Square Cafe in Manhattan.

headline: Marcelo Burlon County of Milan: Spring 2018
text: The label shows its spring collection.

headline: William J.L. Sladen, Expert on Penguin Libidos, Is Dead at 96
text: William J. L. Sladen, a physician by training and zoologist by choice who became a leading expert on the libido of Antarctic penguins and the migratory patterns of endangered birds in North America, died on May 29 at his home in Warrenton, Va. He was 96.

headline: In Houston, an Original Juneteenth Celebration Site Reborn
text: HOUSTON — In 1872, a group of African-American ministers and businessmen in Houston purchased 10 acres of land south of downtown, in the city’s predominantly black Third Ward neighborhood, and created Emancipation Park. Acquired for $800, the park was intended as a permanent site for the city’s annual Juneteenth celebration, which memorializes June 19, 1865, the day the Union Gen. Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston and belatedly put the Emancipation Proclamation into effect across Texas two and a half years after it became official.

headline: He Sued Police 75 Times. Democrats Want Him as Philadelphia’s Top Prosecutor.
text: PHILADELPHIA — Larry Krasner has sued the Philadelphia Police Department 75 times. He has promised not to seek the death penalty. He has even called law enforcement “systemically racist.”

headline: Ben Finney, Anthropologist Who Debunked Theory on Island Settlement, Dies at 83
text: On June 4, 1976, the Hokulea, a double-hulled sailing canoe of ancient design, glided into Papeete Harbor in Tahiti, greeted ecstatically by a crowd of 17,000 — more than half the population of the city of Papeete. For the first time in six centuries, a traditional Polynesian sailing vessel had made the voyage from Hawaii to Tahiti, covering more than 2,700 miles without instruments.

headline: Silent Treatment
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s always a little disconcerting when a constructor decides to give us the silent treatment, but the silent treatment is what we are getting from Sam Trabucco.

headline: Justin Thomas’s 63 Breaks a U.S. Open Record as Brian Harman Seizes the Lead
text: ERIN, Wis. — Justin Thomas sat on the end of his golf bag, like a hiker resting on a log, and extended his arms. As he suspected, they were quivering. With eight feet left to navigate on Erin Hills’s undulating 7,741-yard layout, Thomas had United States Open history in his sights and food on his mind.

headline: Corrections: June 18, 2017
text: SPORTS

headline: Bill Cosby and the Year of the Hypocrite
text: After 52 hours of jury deliberation, the case against Bill Cosby on charges of drugging and sexually assaulting Andrea Constand in 2004 ended on Saturday in a mistrial. But at least the public verdict on Mr. Cosby is clear: He will be remembered as a very low sort of hypocrite — the self-styled exemplar of conservative family values exposed as a sexual predator.

headline: Stonewall Inn Project to Preserve Stories Behind a Gay Rights Monument
text: The little park outside the Stonewall Inn in Manhattan, the site of a major turning point in the gay rights movement nearly 50 years ago, became a permanent beacon last year when it was named a national historic monument.

headline: Camille Cosby and Others React to the Bill Cosby Case Mistrial
text: It started with a comedy routine. Hannibal Buress was doing a stand-up set in Philadelphia in 2014 in which he excoriated Bill Cosby, alleging that he was a hypocrite for criticizing the lifestyle of African-Americans despite having been accused of sexual assault.

headline: As Masahiro Tanaka Continues to Flail, So Do the Yankees
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — If Aaron Judge decides to participate in the home run contest next month at the All-Star Game, he will not have to look far for someone to groove pitches he can smash out of the park. His teammate Masahiro Tanaka has perfected that art this season.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Efforts to Rescue Migrants Caused Deadly, Unexpected Consequences
text: “If you have a dinghy with 170 people on board, these boats can capsize in seconds. And it really takes seconds for people to drown. Many people who are coming from Africa have never seen the sea in their lives before.”

headline: Jordan Spieth, Inside His Own Head, Struggles to Get Out
text: ERIN, Wis. — For most of Saturday, it seemed as if the most visible part of Jordan Spieth was the top of his golf cap. Five missed birdie putts of 12 feet or less and two missed par putts from inside 6 feet will make any golfer drop his chin to his chest.

headline: Scalise’s Condition Upgraded to Serious After Shooting
text: Representative Steve Scalise continued to improve on Saturday, and doctors upgraded his condition from critical to serious, according to a statement released by MedStar Washington Hospital Center.

headline: Mets Lose to Nationals in a Familiar Fashion
text: The Mets and the Nationals both wore an unaccustomed hue on Saturday at Citi Field, a nod to Father’s Day weekend.

headline: Protesters Outside ‘Julius Caesar’ in Central Park, and Laughs Inside
text: Pauline Pujol arrived early to the production of “Julius Caesar” in Central Park on Saturday, but she was not there to see the play.

Dick Howard, who taught the couple at the University of Virginia School of Law.

text: Christina Lee Padden and Declan Dominic Kiely were married June 17. Mary C. Johnson, a celebrant of the Humanist Society, officiated at the Fells, a house museum and events space in Newbury, N.H.

headline: Carly Bernstein, Adam Gross
text: Carly Melissa Bernstein, the daughter of Nancy G. Bernstein and Dr. Guy T. Bernstein of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married June 17 to Adam Jeremy Gross, a son of Jennifer B. Gross and Dr. Frederic R. Gross of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz officiated at the Pierre hotel in New York.

headline: Brooke Ambler, Alexander Feldman
text: Catherine Brooke Ambler and Alexander David Feldman were married June 17 at Blooming Hill Farm in Blooming Grove, N.Y. Jennifer Holcomb, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Amanda Bauer, Jason Manzella
text: Amanda Michele Bauer and Dr. Jason Michael Manzella were married June 17 at Oceanbleu Resort and Beach Club in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. The Rev. Marie April Gismondi, who was ordained by the Church of Ancient Ways, officiated.

headline: Emmanuel Macron’s Party and Allies Win Big in France
text: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France won a crucial stamp of approval on Sunday as voters gave him and his allies a decisive majority in parliamentary elections, but a record-low turnout cast a shadow over his victory, pointing to the hurdles he will face as he seeks to revive the country’s economy and confidence.

Weissman of Mount Kisco, N.Y., is to be married June 18 to Rabbi Avram Chaim Schwartz, a son of Judith Rosenthal Schwartz of Richmond, Calif., and Marshall E. Schwartz of Oakland, Calif. Rabbi Aaron Brusso is to perform the ceremony at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains, with Rabbi Dov Lerea participating.

text: Cathryn Ann Clüver and Tom Ashbrook were married June 17 in Lincoln, Mass. Patricia Clifford, the acting town clerk of Concord, Mass., officiated at the Gropius House, the home built there by the architect and founder of the Bauhaus School, Walter Gropius.

text: Lucy Haley Pollack and Richard Sage Passer were married Saturday at the William Vale Hotel in Brooklyn. Rabbi Daniel Reiser officiated.

headline: Caroline Cannon, John Martin
text: Caroline Gordon Cannon and John Arthur Martin were married June 17. Andrew W. Hoffmann, an uncle of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Country Club of Virginia in Richmond.

headline: Milwaukee County Sheriff Says He Will Not Join Homeland Security Department
text: WASHINGTON — David A. Clarke Jr., the polarizing Milwaukee County sheriff and a vocal supporter of President Trump, has said he would not accept a senior position that he had been offered at the Homeland Security Department.

headline: Allison Davis, John Tuck
text: Allison Cristine Davis and John Chatfield Tuck III were married on June 17 at the Great House, a museum and events space at the Crane Estate in Ipswich, Mass. The Rev. Bret B. Hays, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Langton, Arthur Zeckendorf III
text: Elizabeth Renwick Langton and Arthur William Zeckendorf III were married June 17 at St. Luke’s Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y. The Very Rev. Denis C. Brunelle, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

text: Sara Christine Randazzo and Christopher Randall Kirkham were married June 17 at the Ruby Street, a wedding and event space in Los Angeles. Brendan McCarthy, a friend of the couple who was with them the night they met, officiated.

headline: Kathryn Sowinski, Thomas Lisofsky
text: Kathryn Anne Sowinski and Thomas John Lisofsky were married June 17 at Our Lady of the Mount Roman Catholic Church in Warren, N.J. The Rev. Paul G. Bootkoski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Marisa Floriani, Michael Macrides
text: Marisa Claire Floriani and Michael Alexander Macrides were married June 17 in New York. Justice Barbara R. Kapnick of the New York State Supreme Court Appellate Division officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers.

headline: Kathryn Pickett, Andrew Davis
text: Kathryn Hartwell Pickett, the daughter of E. Louise Hartwell of New York and the late John M. Hartwell, was married June 14 to Andrew Adams Davis, a son of Wendy Adams McCain of New York and Shelby M. C. Davis of Jackson Hole, Wyo. The Rev. Ryan Fleenor, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James’ Church in New York.

headline: Sara Schlegel, Roy Schoenberg
text: Sara Anne Schlegel and Dr. Roy Schoenberg are to be married June 18 on Nantucket, Mass. Rabbi David Kudan is to officiate at Galley Beach, a restaurant there.

headline: Morgan Clark, Michael Brennan
text: Morgan Jill Clark, a daughter of Fredda L. Clark of Manhattan and the late Sterling K. Clark, was married June 17 to Michael Martin Brennan, the son of Sandra L. Ehlinger of Belmont, Mass., and Kevin M. Brennan of West Roxbury, Mass. Matthew W. DeCoste, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at Harding’s, a Manhattan restaurant.

headline: Russia Renewed Unused Trump Trademarks in 2016
text: Amid a broadening investigation of Russian contacts with his associates and his own role in trying to stop it, President Trump fired off another angry tweet this past week repeating his assertion that he has no business interests in Russia.

headline: Abbey Niezgoda, Richard Feindel
text: Abbey Elaine Niezgoda and Richard Kibling Feindel Jr. were married June 17. Nathanael H. Berends, a friend who received permission from the State of Massachusetts to perform the wedding, officiated at the Harbor View Hotel in Edgartown, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard.

headline: Erica Frenkel, David Klein
text: Erica Weinstein Frenkel and David Aaron Klein were married June 17 at Tarry a While Resort in Bridgton, Me. Rabbi Darah R. Lerner officiated.

headline: Nicole Osorio, Oliver Liao
text: Nicole Osorio and Oliver Daniel Ledesma Liao were married June 16. The Rev. Gilbert Martinez performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, where he is the pastor.

headline: Deland Chan, Michael Huang
text: Deland Chan, a daughter of Wai Chun Chan and Chung K. Chan of New York, was married June 17 to Michael Chih-Chiang Huang, a son of Sik-Lin Huang and Hui-Zhen Y. Huang of Katy, Tex. Bosco So, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Trocadero Clubhouse in Stern Grove in San Francisco.

headline: Erica Jain, Ricky Shah
text: Erica Ambika Jain and Ricky Bharat Shah were married June 17. Pandit Ravi Trivedi, a Hindu priest, officiated the ceremony at the Monarch Beach Resort in Dana Point, Calif.

headline: Phoebe White, Divya Narendra
text: Phoebe Aase Grethe White and Divya Kumar Narendra were married June 17 at the Wainwright House, an event space in Rye, N.Y. Devbala Ramanathan, an aunt of the groom who is a Vedic scripture and culture specialist and is authorized to perform rites, officiated.

headline: Adelina Hung, Raj Chovatiya
text: Dr. Adelina Hung and Dr. Raj Jitendra Chovatiya were married June 17 at the Highland Park Country Club in Highland Park, Ill. Pandit Krishna Jois officiated. On Friday, the couple also had a traditional Chinese tea ceremony.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Grantchester’ and ‘Undocumented on Campus’
text: It’s Christmastime in “Grantchester,” and there’s an extra bundle under the tree. And “Undocumented on Campus” follows a first-year college student who came illegally to the United States.

headline: Taliban Attack Major Base in Eastern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Five Afghan police officers were killed and 18 people were wounded in a Taliban attack Sunday on a major base in the eastern province of Paktia, Afghan officials said.

headline: Writers on the Right and Left React to the Senate Health Care Bill and Trump’s Cuba Policy
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: Visiting Dad in Prison
text: Derek Smith has been incarcerated for most of his daughters’ lives after robbing a jewelry store. In this 360° video, make the trip from Miami with his daughters and his mother to visit him in prison.

headline: Homes That Sold for Over $1 Million
text: 110 Livingston Street, No. 12D, Downtown Brooklyn

headline: How Michael Flynn’s Disdain for Limits Led to a Legal Quagmire
text: WASHINGTON — Michael T. Flynn was a man seething and thwarted. In the summer of 2014, after repeatedly clashing with other Obama administration officials over his management of the Defense Intelligence Agency — and what he saw as his unheeded warnings about the rising power of Islamic militants — Mr. Flynn was fired, bringing his military career to an abrupt end.

headline: Bill Cosby, Grenfell Tower, Whole Foods: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Portugal Fires Kill More Than 60, Including Drivers Trapped in Cars
text: MADRID — A raging forest fire in central Portugal this weekend killed more than 60 people, including at least 30 motorists who were trapped in their cars when the flames enveloped a stretch of road.

headline: Sleeping Sailors on U.S.S. Fitzgerald Awoke to a Calamity at Sea
text: As an American destroyer cruised off the waters of Japan in clear weather in the early hours of Saturday, only a few dozen of the crew of 350 were likely to be awake: standing watch, keeping the engines running, manning the bridge.

headline: MSGM: Spring 2018
text: Massimo Giorgetti presents his spring collection.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Spring 2018
text: Guillaume Meilland, the newly appointed design director, presents his second collection for this spring.

headline: High-Stakes Referendum on Trump Takes Shape in a Georgia Special Election
text: ATLANTA — Taking the stage in a half-filled airplane hangar to rally supporters of the Republican candidate Karen Handel, Health Secretary Tom Price could not help but point to the record-shattering surge of liberal money that has flooded into the special House race here.

headline: Before You Pay for Financial Advice, Read This Guide
text: Many people turn to a professional for financial advice when they have a big problem to solve: How much do I need to save for my children’s college? Can I afford the bigger house? Will I run out of money in retirement?

headline: New Energy at Versace, Ralph Lauren and Emporio Armani
text: MILAN — Often as fascinating as what designers show on the runways here is doping out the business plays behind the fashion. Take the case of Versace.

headline: At the Marni Show, a Sense of Childlike Wonder
text: MILAN — Francesco Risso, less than a year into his tenure at the helm of Marni, is very much the new kid on the block at the men’s shows in Milan. It’s a position he seems to relish, or at least to remind you of.

headline: Iraqi Forces Begin Assault on Mosul’s Old City
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Iraqi forces on Sunday began penetrating the narrow streets and warrens of Mosul’s heavily populated old city, in the last phase of a monthslong battle against the Islamic State militants that American commanders have described as one of the toughest in urban warfare since World War II.

headline: Rowhouse Residents Want Historic District Expanded
text: “What we have is 12 houses,” Matthew Spady said, walking down a ski-slope-steep street in Washington Heights, in Upper Manhattan — 12 houses that have stood together in an unbroken row since the president was William McKinley and the mayor was Robert Van Wyck, who tends nowadays to figure in rush-hour rants on the expressway named after him in Queens.

headline: How to Speak Fashion Week
text: MILAN — Every industry has its jargon. Hollywood loves its “arcs” and “beats,” and business offices are full of managers using “effort” as a verb.

headline: Sunnei: Spring 2018
text: The 2-year old indie menswear presents its spring collection.

headline: Moving Past Scandal, Oregon State Starts Strong at College World Series
text: OMAHA — Practice day at the College World Series began Friday as it usually does for the participating teams. In the morning, Oregon State’s players, who were set to play in the first game on Saturday, ambled off the team bus toward the Road to Omaha sculpture in front of TD Ameritrade Park. After posing for goofy selfies and group photos beside the bronze image of four celebrating players, they headed inside for a light session of batting and fielding.

headline: Trump ‘Is Not Under Investigation,’ His Lawyer Insists
text: WASHINGTON — A member of President Trump’s legal team said on Sunday that the president was not under investigation by the special counsel looking into Russia’s election-year meddling, contradicting Mr. Trump’s assertion in a Friday morning tweet that he is a subject of the widening inquiry.

headline: Damir Doma: Spring 2018
text: In the past this collection explored contemporary masculinity, here is its spring collection.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: N.B.A. Teams Covet a New Breed of Big Man in the Draft
text: Ten years ago, the big question before the 2007 N.B.A. draft was which of two players the Portland Trail Blazers would select with the top overall pick. One option was Greg Oden, the 7-footer out of Ohio State who was a traditional center playing near the basket. The other was Kevin Durant, a spindly, less classifiable big man out of Texas.

headline: After Surge in Orders, Airlines Now Balk at Wide-Bodies
text: At the International Paris Air Show this week, much of the excitement at the aerial displays will come from the latest souped-up versions of the smaller Airbus and Boeing planes. But the chatter at the lavish dinners is likely to focus on a more worrisome topic: a recent slowdown in orders for the companies’ largest and most expensive jets.

headline: Officials Point Fingers as Lake Ontario Spills Into Neighborhoods
text: GREECE, N.Y. — The wind blowing in from Lake Ontario was picking up, and Evon Dunham knew she needed to be on alert. On her road lined with homes perched on the lake’s edge, the breeze appeared to barely rustle the American flags hanging from every utility pole. But it had the lake churning, slamming water into the barrier behind her home.

headline: Mongolian Warriors and Communist Soldiers: A Frontier Town in China
text: WENQUAN, China — Wenquan means “hot springs,” and the town, nestled in a fertile swath of Central Asia, certainly has its share. Alpine forests cloak the surrounding mountains. To the south is a wide lake where azure waters lap at stony shores. Horses and sheep roam the pastures.

headline: China, Where the Pressure to Marry Is Strong, and the Advice Flows Online
text: BEIJING — Every evening, Liang Xuemeng goes online to read the latest postings from Ayawawa, one of China’s most popular advice columnists.

headline: Diverse Crowds Fuel ‘Cars 3’ and ‘All Eyez on Me’ at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — With a new vehicular heroine, Cruz Ramirez, taking center stage in “Cars 3,” and Tupac Shakur’s life dramatized in “All Eyez on Me,” Latino and African-American moviegoers turned out in force over the weekend, demonstrating once again the power of multiculturalism on screen.

headline: North Korea Accuses U.S. of ‘Mugging’ Its Diplomats in New York
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Sunday accused United States officials of “mugging” its diplomats at Kennedy International Airport by seizing a diplomatic package they were carrying.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival Expands Residencies for Choreographers
text: Jacob’s Pillow, the annual summer dance festival in Becket, Mass., is planning to extend its reach through year-round residencies for choreographers and other initiatives.

headline: Prada: Spring 2018
text: Miuccia Prada presents her spring collection.

headline: Victoria and Albert Museum to Unveil Expansion
text: LONDON — The Victoria and Albert Museum, the world’s largest museum of decorative arts and design, is completing its biggest building project in a century: a new courtyard entrance and foyer, opening on June 30, that’s intended to make it easier for the public to gain access. The museum is also inaugurating a vast exhibition gallery.

headline: Oracle Team USA Is Racing the Clock to Find an Edge
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — Oracle Team USA is back in deep trouble in the America’s Cup against Emirates Team New Zealand. And in contrast to last time in San Francisco, Oracle will not be able to call on the nautical knowledge of Ben Ainslie to bail it out.

headline: Indigenous Canadians Challenge an Exclusive American Fishing Camp
text: When a group of local Innu showed up recently at an exclusive, private fishing camp on the Moisie River in northern Quebec, it had more than fishing in mind.

headline: Maldives, Tourist Haven, Casts Wary Eye on Growing Islamic Radicalism
text: MALÉ, Maldives — This island paradise made news recently for a reason other than its pristine beaches and high-end resorts: the gruesome killing of a liberal blogger, stabbed to death by multiple assailants.

headline: Moncler-Gamme-Bleue: Spring 2018
text: Known in the past for his outerwear classics, Mr. Thom Browne presents his spring collection.

headline: London, U.S.S. Fitzgerald, Japan: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: 'The Handmaid’s Tale’ Showrunner Bruce Miller on the Season 1 Finale
text: When Hulu hired Bruce Miller as the showrunner for a television adaptation of Margaret Atwood’s classic dystopian novel “The Handmaid’s Tale,” he didn’t have to start from scratch. Ilene Chaiken, now the showrunner of the Fox series “Empire,” first developed the project for Showtime, Mr. Miller said, and she “deserves a lot of credit for incredible endurance and tenacity, for keeping it alive.” Ms. Chaiken’s pilot script, although scrapped, gave him a starting point as he grappled with how to tell the story. “Her script spread out to different points of view early on,” he said, “and I don’t think she used voice-over.”

headline: Pakistan Upsets India to Claim Its First Cricket Champions Trophy
text: LONDON — Pakistan’s players embraced, delirious, while grabbing stumps from the ground as mementos of a remarkable day. Their national team secured a scintillating upset on Sunday, defeating India, the defending titlist, to win its first International Cricket Council Champions Trophy.

headline: Pakistan Defeats India in Cricket Final
text: The victory in London over their archrivals, who held the International Cricket Council’s Champions Trophy, produced intense emotions on the field and in South Asia.

headline: Ernestina Herrera de Noble, Media Mogul in Argentina, Dies at 92
text: Ernestina Laura Herrera de Noble, the publisher of Argentina’s largest-circulation daily, Clarín, who was instrumental in turning her husband’s newspaper into one of the largest media conglomerates in the Spanish-speaking world, died on Wednesday in Buenos Aires. She was 92.

headline: Little but Palace Intrigue as Legislative Session Winds Down
text: ALBANY — Meh.

headline: British Cycling Cultivated ‘Culture of Fear,’ Report Finds
text: Over the last three Olympic Games, British Cycling has delivered an astounding 22 gold medals; no other nation has managed more than four in the same time. The organization has become a poster child for Britain’s Olympic success; its philosophy of marginal gains — breaking down each aspect of performance to identify a series of possible small improvements — was celebrated in sports, business and beyond.

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: ‘The End of Advertising’
text: Andrew Essex believes that “the end of advertising as we know it” is “somewhere between five minutes and five years” away. That’s what this former chief executive of the influential creative agency Droga5 writes in “The End of Advertising: Why It Had to Die, and the Creative Resurrection to Come” (Spiegel & Grau).

headline: U.S. Fighter Jet Shoots Down Syrian Warplane
text: WASHINGTON — An American fighter jet shot down a Syrian warplane on Sunday after it dropped bombs near local ground forces supported by the United States, the first time the American military has downed a Syrian aircraft since the start of the civil war in 2011, officials said.

headline: Review: ‘Loch Ness’ Has a Monster, and an Alluring Mystery
text: If you didn’t figure out from the title that “Loch Ness” was going to be one of those what-lies-beneath-the-surface mystery series, the first image you see after the credits certainly leaves no doubt. It’s of a dead man floating vertically deep in murky water, feet bound and tied to a weight that’s keeping him submerged.

headline: Jimi Hendrix Park Opens at Last, With a Purple Flourish
text: SEATTLE — Jimi Hendrix’s looping signature greets visitors at the park bearing his name, here in his hometown. The eye-catching purple script is among many personal touches that pay homage to the musician in Jimi Hendrix Park, which was formally christened in 2006 but didn’t open until Saturday, after a decade of permit delays and financial woes.

headline: As U.S. Adds Troops in Afghanistan, Trump’s Strategy Remains Undefined
text: WASHINGTON — When President Trump made his first major decision on the war in Afghanistan, he did not announce it in a nationally televised address from the White House or a speech at West Point.

headline: Review: ‘Invincible’ Brings Class and Conflict to the Party
text: At the start of Torben Betts’s “Invincible,” part of the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, Emily and Oliver, incomers to a northern English town, are expecting the couple next door for drinks and snacks. The party isn’t nice. The gesture isn’t really neighborly.

headline: Gunmen Kill Two in Attack on Mali Camping Resort
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Four gunmen stormed a camping resort outside Mali’s capital on Sunday, killing two people before escaping in a shootout with soldiers from an antiterrorism unit, a security ministry official said.

headline: Women’s Voices Are Still Not Being Heard
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Stemming the Rise in Opioid Deaths
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘(Not) Water’ Offers Too Much to Drink In
text: The storm made landfall five days ago. The power grid went down almost immediately. Cellular service lasted a little longer. Airdrops have ceased, food has become scarce and the corner bodega now sells bottles of water for a cool $20 each. So when the woman in the lab coat pulls you into the bathroom and offers you a paper cup of clean H2O, you take it. Don’t you?

headline: The Price of Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Think About Bill Cosby and ‘The Cosby Show’
text: To the extent that America still has a collective cultural memory, it’s comforting to have the happy stuff to hold on to. And it’s depressing to arrive at a juncture that forces us to let some of that stuff go. For much of its eight seasons, “The Cosby Show” (which ran from 1984 to 1992) was foolproof happiness, and the primary source was Bill Cosby. Now, at the close of a depleting, inconclusive criminal trial, we’re back to reckoning with what to do with him and whether it’s still possible to laugh at his comedy.

headline: Performances by Two Singers
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ah, Mondays. Some people see Mondays as the end of their weekend, a depressing day when they have to climb back on the hamster wheel of Earning a Living Doing Whatever.

headline: Smaller Brewers Relied on RateBeer.com. Now Bud’s Maker Owns a Stake.
text: From the rooftop patio of his growing brewery in the southwestern elbow of Brooklyn, Shane C. Welch, the founder and “chief visionary” of Sixpoint Brewery, appeared to have staked a nice corner of an intensely competitive beer market.

headline: Dsquared2: Spring 2018
text: Dean and Dan Caten, twin brothers, present their spring collection.

headline: For the 2nd Time in a Week, a Cyclist Is Killed by a Bus in Chelsea
text: An 80-year-old man on a bicycle was struck and killed on Saturday by a charter bus in the Chelsea section of Manhattan — the second time in a week that a cyclist has died in a bus accident in the neighborhood.

headline: Some Global Investors See Fresh Worries in an Old Problem: China
text: BEIJING — While investors have been preoccupied with President Trump and chaos in Washington, nerve-rattling elections in Europe and the uncertainty created by Federal Reserve policy and Britain’s decision to leave the European Union, a once-familiar — and possibly bigger — risk to global markets has been bubbling in the background.

headline: Sónar 2017: 15 of the Best Sets From the Barcelona Music Festival
text: BARCELONA — People danced past dawn at Sónar, the annual festival of electronic-oriented music, which had its last D.J.s pumping out bass propulsion until 7 a.m. Sónar unites Spain’s late-night culture with the euphoric stamina of fans of techno, house and other varieties of music that use machines to generate sweaty motion. This year’s festival, which ran from Thursday through Sunday, was the 24th annual Sónar and the largest, with 123,000 visitors.

headline: One Ohio Town’s Immigration Clash, Down in the Actual Muck
text: WILLARD, Ohio — Migrant workers arrive here every spring to work in the “muck,” which is what everybody calls the fertile soil that makes this part of Ohio the perfect place to grow radishes, peppers, cucumbers and leafy greens. The temporary workers can be seen planting, weeding and, later in the season, harvesting crops that will be sold at national supermarket chains.

headline: The Car Was Repossessed, but the Debt Remains
text: More than a decade after Yvette Harris’s 1997 Mitsubishi was repossessed, she is still paying off her car loan.

headline: Univision’s Urgent Sense of Purpose: A Newsroom and a Lifeline
text: DORAL, Fla. — Earlier this year, a rumor rippled through the large Hispanic community in northeast Miami, delivered through the WhatsApp text-messaging service: Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents were hauling undocumented immigrants off to detention centers in buses. The “deportation force” President Trump promised during the campaign had finally arrived, it seemed.

headline: Navy Identifies Sailors Killed in Ship Collision
text: The Navy released the names on Sunday night of the seven sailors aboard the Fitzgerald who were killed in a collision with a container ship early Saturday morning. They were all located in flooded berths, the Navy said.

headline: Welcome to New York, Parking Edition
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Judges for Love Offers Commitments, While Hoping for No Appeals
text: For a long time, people dreaded seeing Justice Alan D. Marrus.

headline: Brooks Koepka Wins U.S. Open for His First Major Title
text: ERIN, Wis. — Fred Couples was 32 years old when he won the Masters for his first, and only, major. Tom Kite was 10 years older when he won the 1992 United States Open, his first and only major. Couples and Kite ended up in the World Golf Hall of Fame, but if they were playing today, they would be in danger of being left behind before they got started.

headline: YouTube Sets New Policies to Curb Extremist Videos
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — YouTube has struggled for years with videos that promote offensive viewpoints but do not necessarily violate the company’s guidelines for removal. Now it is taking a new approach: Bury them.

headline: Books by Barack Obama’s Father Come Up for Auction
text: AMSTERDAM — In the late 1950s, a young Kenyan man named Barack Hussein Obama wrote a series of books in his native language, Luo, for a program to promote adult literacy in Africa. The coordinator of that program, Elizabeth Mooney, singled him out as particularly talented, and helped him apply to an international study program at the University of Hawaii. There he met and married a student of cultural anthropology, Ann Dunham. Their only child would become an American president, sharing his father’s name.

headline: Stephen Furst, Who Played Flounder in ‘Animal House,’ Dies at 63
text: Stephen Furst, whose early role as the hapless, lovable fraternity pledge Flounder in the hit 1978 comedy “National Lampoon’s Animal House” earned him lasting recognition, died early Friday at his home in Moorpark, Calif. He was 63.

headline: Van Hits Pedestrians Near a Mosque in London, Killing One
text: LONDON — A van drove into a group of pedestrians early Monday near a mosque in London, killing one person and injuring 10 in what the mayor called a “horrific terrorist attack” that struck Muslims as they finished prayers.

headline: Paris Air Show Faces Head Winds, and Britain Looks at Fox’s Bid to Buy Sky
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: Casper, Mattress Maker, Raises $170 Million and Plans I.P.O.
text: Several months ago, Casper, the most prominent of a new generation of mattress makers that rose to prominence through e-commerce, held talks to sell itself to Target.

headline: U.K. Government Takes Control of London Fire Response Amid Criticism
text: LONDON — Chastened by a wave of public indignation, the British government on Sunday took direct control of the response to a deadly apartment tower fire in London, sidelining local officials whose response has been criticized as slow and disorganized.

headline: Behind Jacob deGrom’s First Career Homer, Mets Avoid a Sweep
text: When the first-place Washington Nationals arrived in Flushing on Thursday, the Mets’ season appeared to be on the upswing.

headline: In Cosby Case, First Trial Is a Guide for the 2nd
text: The fatigue from Saturday’s mistrial has hardly faded for either side in the Bill Cosby sexual assault case, but both need to begin preparing almost immediately for a new trial that the prosecution has vowed to bring.

headline: Yankees End West Coast Trip With Another Defeat in Oakland
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — On the Yankees’ West Coast swing, two of their pitchers had gone on the disabled list, their cleanup hitter had missed a game because of an allergic reaction to breakfast, two of their hottest hitters had left a game with injuries and — oh, yes — they were mired in their longest losing streak of the season.

headline: Fire Kills More Than 60 in Portugal
text: A forest fire swept through central Portugal this weekend, becoming the country’s worst such blaze in more than a half-century.

headline: The Path of the Container Ship That Struck a U.S. Navy Destroyer
text: An animation of the route of the cargo ship that struck a U.S. Navy vessel.

headline: Kushner Is Said to Be Reconsidering His Legal Team
text: Representatives of Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, have quietly contacted high-powered criminal lawyers about potentially representing him in the wide-ranging investigation into Russia’s influence on the 2016 election, according to three people briefed on the matter.

headline: Quotation of the Day: President Cedes Afghan Strategy to the Pentagon
text: “The president doesn’t have the time or interest to make these decisions, so they want to leave the decision making to Mattis.”

headline: Rickie Fowler, a Major Within Reach, Leaves Empty-Handed Again
text: ERIN, Wis. — Rickie Fowler has been here before. Has he ever. And he doesn’t need to be reminded.

headline: Megyn Kelly Presses Alex Jones on Conspiracy Theories in NBC Interview
text: For viewers who had never heard of Alex Jones before Sunday evening, Megyn Kelly’s much-hyped interview with him on NBC did not paint a flattering picture.

headline: No Corrections: June 19, 2017
text: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 19, 2017.
