headline: 20 Years of L.G.B.T.Q. Lit: A Timeline
text: Once you have read James Baldwin’s “Giovanni’s Room” and Larry Kramer’s “Faggots,” both classic gay novels, here are 25 recent works that have shaped the L.G.B.T.Q. literary genre over the last two decades.

headline: When Shots Ring Out From One Ball Field, a Reporter Practicing on Another Races to Cover Them
text: In this diary, Emmarie Huetteman, who covers Congress for The Times, shares her own window onto the shooting of Representative Steve Scalise — as a reporter, a spectator and finally a participant in a similar charity softball game.

headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
text: As Pride Month enters its last week,

headline: How Medicaid Works, and Who It Covers
text: One of the biggest flash points in the debate over Republican legislation to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act is the future of Medicaid. Here are some basic facts about the 52-year-old program.

headline: A.T.F. Memo Indicates Agents’ Off-the-Books Account Was Against the Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives were running a multimillion-dollar, off-the-books bank account in Virginia to fund undercover operations at a time when the bureau had imposed strict rules about the use of such accounts.

headline: Does It Matter Who Runs New York City’s Schools?
text: The State Legislature’s failure to pass a bill extending mayoral control of New York City’s schools before the end of the term on Wednesday had no immediate effect on the city’s 1.1 million schoolchildren: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s hold on education policy in the city continues through June 30. After that, Mr. de Blasio has warned of “chaos and corruption” that could return if control reverts to the Board of Education.

headline: Google Will No Longer Scan Gmail for Ad Targeting
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google plans to abandon its longstanding practice of scanning user email in its Gmail service to serve targeted advertising.

headline: Maritime Mystery: Why a U.S. Destroyer Failed to Dodge a Cargo Ship
text: There should have been lookouts on watch on the port, starboard and stern of the destroyer Fitzgerald — sailors scanning the horizon with binoculars and reporting by headsets to the destroyer’s bridge. At 1:30 a.m. last Saturday, off the coast of Japan south of Tokyo, they could hardly have failed to see the 730-foot freighter ACX Crystal, stacked with more than 1,000 containers, as it closed in.

headline: Frank Kush, Hall of Fame Coach of Arizona State, Dies at 88
text: Frank Kush, the college Hall of Fame coach who took Arizona State University to national football prominence, but who was fired midway through his 22nd season when he was accused of trying to impede an investigation into an assault allegation lodged by a player, died on Thursday in the Phoenix area. He was 88.

headline: OSHA to Roll Back Rules on Toxic Mineral at Construction Sites
text: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed on Friday a rollback of some Obama-era rules to protect workers in the maritime and construction industries from beryllium, a potentially deadly mineral.

headline: Trump Signs Bill Meant to Restore Trust in V.A.
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump signed a bill into law on Friday that will make it easier for the Department of Veterans Affairs to remove bad employees and promote whistle-blowing.

headline: Knicks Sign Canyon Barry, a Student of Triangles
text: In the days leading up to his workout with the Knicks last month, Canyon Barry put together a quick cram session. He watched a few Knicks games from last season and studied their triangle offense, hoping to analyze the cuts and movements he would make in it. To test himself, he then explained its intricacies to his agent.

headline: The Times’s Resident Expert for a World on Fire
text: The email landed almost as soon as I woke up on Father’s Day in Phoenix, where I work as bureau chief. Bryant Rousseau, an editor on the International desk, asked if I could help out on a story about the wildfire that killed at least 64 people in Portugal, including many who were trapped inside their cars.

headline: State Dept. Moves to Shut Office Planning Afghanistan Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department is winding down an Obama-era office responsible for developing long-range strategy in Afghanistan and Pakistan — just as the Trump administration conducts a major review of the future of America’s longest war.

headline: Hans Breder, Who Broke Artistic Boundaries, Dies at 81
text: Hans Breder, a German-born artist whose interest in straddling the boundaries between disciplines led him to create the Intermedia Program, the first of its kind, at the University of Iowa in 1968, died on June 18 in Iowa City. He was 81.

headline: Senate Health Plan Falls Short of Promise for Cheaper Care, Experts Say
text: President Trump and the Republicans have promised that their plan to overhaul the federal health care law will make medical coverage much more affordable.

headline: Melania Trump Hires White House Chief Usher From the Family Business
text: WASHINGTON — In the past, White House chief ushers have largely been public servants, military personnel or career staff members who worked their way up the usher ladder over several administrations. But in naming a new chief usher on Friday, Melania Trump elevated someone from within a close network of family employees to be her in-house right hand.

headline: I Picked Prison Over Fighting in Vietnam
text: Growing up in Fresno, Calif., I believed in “my country, right or wrong,” just like everyone I knew. I could not have anticipated that when I came of age I would realize that my country was wrong and that I would have to do something about it. When I did, everything changed for me.

headline: Easiest Path to Riches on the Web? An Initial Coin Offering
text: A new crop of technology entrepreneurs is forgoing the usual routes to raising money. The entrepreneurs are not pitching venture capitalists, selling stock in an initial public offering or using crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter.

headline: How Twitter Pornified Politics
text: This is the column in which I formally forswear Twitter for good. I’ll keep my Twitter handle, and hopefully my followers, but an editorial assistant will manage the account from now on. I’ll intercede only to say nice things about the writing I admire, the people I like and the music I love.

headline: Big Little League
text: Keeping score is ingrained in my soul. Baseball is a game driven by outcomes — results interlocked in a quantifiable puzzle to predict the future, assess the past, even value the present — and I intimately lived that world professionally for almost 15 years. Yet now, having just coached another year of Little League, I question the conclusions we often make when coloring by numbers, especially when dealing with kids so young that unpredictable growth is inevitable.

headline: Taking On the Frat Boys
text: Everybody seems to hate the Senate health care bill, which was created by 13 Republican men meeting behind closed doors.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Mystery: Why Agile Destroyer Failed to Dodge a Cargo Ship
text: “It looks very much like the computer was driving.”

headline: In Defense of the One-and-Done
text: A benefit of living in a small college town with a big-time college basketball team is that in the course of grocery shopping, changing your car’s oil or donating blood, there’s a not-insignificant chance that you’ll meet in real life the hoops stars you watch on TV. That happened last summer: My daughter Georgia and I were running an errand on the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill campus when we bumped into Tony Bradley.

headline: The Torturers Speak
text: It’s hard to watch the videotaped depositions of the two former military psychologists who, working as independent contractors, designed, oversaw and helped carry out the “enhanced interrogation” of detainees held at C.I.A. black sites in the months after the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

headline: New M.T.A. Chairman Is the Right Choice for a Tough Job
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo made the right call this week when he named  Joseph Lhota, a capable administrator, as chairman of the beleaguered Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has been without a permanent leader since January. Mr. Lhota and Mr. Cuomo now need to come up with a credible plan to fix the M.T.A., especially the subway.

headline: The Democrats’ Religion Problem
text: Carrollton, Ga. — Jon Ossoff’s defeat in Georgia’s Sixth Congressional District election on Tuesday wasn’t just a sign that Democrats may have a harder time winning in the Trump era than they had hoped. It is a symptom of a larger problem for the party — a generational and racial divide between a largely secular group of young, white party activists and an older electorate that is more religious and more socially conservative.

headline: Philando Castile, Diamond Reynolds and a Nightmare Caught on Video
text: When Philando Castile was fatally shot by a police officer, the traumatic events were captured by police and security cameras, and his girlfriend's smartphone.

headline: Canada Letter: Trudeau Talks to Us, and a New Name
text: Yes, you’ve come to the right place. As we showcase The New York Times’s expanded coverage of the country over this week and the next, Canada Today has become Canada Letter to reflect a freshened approach.

headline: End With Speed
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you’re gobsmacked by this meaty Saturday puzzle, come sit right here by me. Stu Ockman isn’t wildly prolific (not that there’s anything wrong with that), but his history indicates a leaning toward grids for the end of the week, and a deviousness in cluing and expansive vocabulary to go with it. In other words, a tough little nut to crack, but worth it.

headline: Saudis, at War in Yemen, Give Country $66.7 Million in Cholera Relief
text: The newly elevated crown prince of Saudi Arabia, who as defense minister has led the country’s bombing and blockades of Yemen, showed his charitable side on Friday with a $66.7 million donation to fight the cholera outbreak in that country.

headline: European Central Bank Moves to Wind Down Two Italian Banks
text: The European Central Bank effectively euthanized two small Italian banks late Friday, in another sign that the eurozone financial system remains vulnerable even as the economy improves.

headline: Devils Take Nico Hischier No. 1, Defying N.H.L. Draft Predictions
text: CHICAGO — Nico Hischier was only 10 the first time he slipped a Devils sweater over his head during a youth hockey tournament in his native Switzerland.

headline: Dr. John Sarno, 93, Dies; Best-Selling Author Tied Pain to Anxieties
text: John E. Sarno, a doctor at New York University whose controversial books on the psychological origins of chronic pain sold over a million copies, even while he was largely ignored or maligned by many of his medical peers, died Thursday in Danbury, Conn. He was 93.

headline: Corrections: June 24, 2017
text: NATIONAL

headline: Asked to Switch Positions, Asdrubal Cabrera Asks to Switch Teams
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In many ways, Asdrubal Cabrera represented the Mets’ 2016 season. He gutted his way through knee pain, providing sure-handed defense at shortstop and stout offense at the plate, and came to be seen as the team’s heart and soul. Behind his play, and, leadership, the Mets rallied to earn a National League wild-card berth.

headline: Landslide in China Is Feared to Have Buried Over 140 People
text: BEIJING — More than 140 people in southwestern China are feared to have been buried under an avalanche of mud and rocks when a hillside collapsed on Saturday, Chinese news media reported.

headline: Marion Goldin, Award-Winning ‘60 Minutes’ Producer, Dies at 76
text: Marion Goldin, one of the most respected and prolific producers at CBS’s flagship newsmagazine, “60 Minutes,” died on June 15 at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 76.

headline: Third Former Vanderbilt Football Player Convicted of Rape
text: Four years to the day after prosecutors say a 21-year-old neuroscience major at Vanderbilt University was sexually assaulted by a group of college football players while she was unconscious inside a dorm room, a jury on Friday convicted the third of four defendants in the attack.

headline: Escaping the Inferno
text: Britain’s deadliest fire in more than a century raced from floor to floor, forcing residents to decide: Wait for rescuers or try to escape?

headline: Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka Prevails in a Duel With a Japanese Flavor
text: Waking up on Saturday morning, baseball fans in Japan were able to watch two homegrown pitching idols duel for the first time since 2011, when they still competed in the Nippon Professional Baseball league.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Birth of a Nation’ and the America’s Cup
text: “The Birth of a Nation,” Nate Parker’s directing debut, comes to HBO. And Oracle Team USA defends its title in the 35th America’s Cup.

headline: Humbled by a Rough Season, the Mets Let Their Bats Boast
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Even before Asdrubal Cabrera requested a trade on Friday afternoon, the Mets were already weighing the future of their roster. They arrived here on Friday reeling after a humbling week against the Washington Nationals and the Los Angeles Dodgers, two of the best teams in the National League.

headline: A Key Challenge for America’s Cup Crews: Don’t Fall Overboard
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — Sailors have been falling off boats for as long as there have been boats. Even the world’s best are not immune.

headline: Immigration Moves Front and Center in Italy’s Local Elections
text: COMO, Italy — The center-right candidate for mayor of Como, Mario Landriscina, a doctor who once did United Nations relief work, says that Italy is second to none in rescuing migrants and that rejecting refugees or minors is out of the question.

headline: ‘This Is an Intentional Slap in the Face’ to All Women
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: That Ball Was Hit a Country Mile, or 495 Feet if You’re Into Hard Data
text: Spoiler alert: If you wish to continue enjoying gargantuan home runs in the future with unspoiled pleasure, free of all polynomial equations, read no further. If you persist, however, then there is much math to consider.

headline: A Street Fight Among Grocers to Deliver Your Milk, Eggs, Bananas
text: Every couple of days, Sinclair Browne fights through traffic in Times Square, squeezes his delivery truck into a parking spot, walks up four flights of stairs and delivers groceries to a guy whose order he knows by heart.

headline: Why Grenfell Tower Burned: Regulators Put Cost Before Safety
text: LONDON — The doorbell woke Yassin Adam just before 1 a.m. A neighbor was frantically alerting others on the fourth floor of Grenfell Tower about a fire in his apartment. “My fridge blew up,” the man shouted.

headline: On Campus, Failure Is on the Syllabus
text: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. — Last year, during fall orientation at Smith College, and then again recently at final-exam time, students who wandered into the campus hub were faced with an unfamiliar situation: the worst failures of their peers projected onto a large screen.

headline: How ‘Gay’ Should a Gay Bar Be?
text: The website for the Abbey touts its role as a two-time winner of Logo’s “Best Gay Bar in the World” award. But how gay is it? Some of the regulars believe the increasing number of straight people who go there has diluted its reason for being.

headline: Young Socialites Conjure the Ghost of Leonard Bernstein at the Dakota
text: It was a spring Saturday in March, but winter lingered in Manhattan, glowering and unwelcome, like a lookout at a street corner.

headline: Trump’s Washington News of the Week: Health Care Bill, Karen Handel and James Comey
text: Worried that you missed an important political story this week? You’re not alone. Catch up on a busy week of news from the Trump administration.

headline: Writers Across the Ideological Spectrum Agree: They Don’t Like the Senate Health Bill
text: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: A Self-Proclaimed ‘Tough Cop’ Wants a New Title: Mayor
text: When Stephen K. Bannon got into a dispute with an ex-wife who accused him of domestic violence, he hired a private investigator with a history of digging up embarrassing information about people claiming to have been wronged.

headline: South Korea Leader Hopes for Unified Olympic Team With the North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Moon Jae-in of South Korea proposed on Saturday that his country and North Korea form a unified team to compete in the 2018 Winter Olympics, to be held in the city of Pyeongchang in the South.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Uber Isn’t Everything
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: SSS World Corp: Spring 2018
text: This label’s spring 2018 collection.

headline: Love Is Love Is Love Is … Cut the Mike
text: This week, a video of a 12-year-old girl coming out as gay to her Mormon congregation in Eagle Mountain, Utah, went viral — and it’s easy to understand why. Savannah is adorable. She wears a red tie, which is already a statement, since wearing pants to church as a woman can be controversial. She stands in front of a room of adults delivering her testimony about how her Heavenly Parents “did not mess up when they gave me freckles. Or when they made me gay. God loves me just this way because I believe that he loves all of his creations.”

headline: Addison Schultz and Tal Hirshberg: A Coffee Scion, and a Grande Love Story
text: Addison Schultz, the daughter of Sheri K. Schultz and Howard D. Schultz of Seattle, was married June 24 to Tal Hirshberg, a son of Nurit Hirshberg and Boaz Hirshberg of North Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Geffen officiated at the summer home of the bride’s family in East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: A Crying Baby Next Door
text: Q. I moved into a rental in Murray Hill last November. Unbeknown to me, there is a baby next door who shares a wall with my apartment. I understand that new parents deal with crying babies, but it seems like these parents have decided to let the baby “cry it out,” and don’t try to make the baby stop. The baby cries a lot in the morning and at night when I’m trying to sleep. If I had known about this, I would never have rented the apartment. Is there any action I can take?

headline: Medicaid Cuts May Force Retirees Out of Nursing Homes
text: ORANGE, Va. — Alice Jacobs, 90, once owned a factory and horses. She has raised four children and buried two husbands.

headline: 52 Places to Go: Sikkim, India
text: In the far reaches of northeastern India, Buddhist monks chant and pace through rare funeral customs for a revered teacher.

headline: Dior Homme: Spring 2018
text: This label’s spring 2018 collection.

headline: ‘This Is Appalling’: Evacuated London Residents Try to Cope
text: LONDON — Addise Mekonen was working a night shift on Friday when he learned from television news that his apartment was one of 650 London flats being evacuated in the middle of the night amid fears that it might be as dangerous as Grenfell Tower, which had been incinerated in the  deadliest blaze in Britain in more than a century.

headline: Israeli Competitor Is a First for Nascar’s Top Cup Series
text: Avi Day plans to hand an Israeli flag to his 25-year-old son, Alon, to carry to the podium where he will be introduced on Sunday as a competitor in a stock car race in Sonoma, Calif. The flag handoff has become a race-day ritual for the Days, but Sunday’s version will be anything but routine.

headline: Hopes Fade After Landslide Destroys Chinese Village
text: BEIJING — Hundreds of rescue workers tapped, poked and dug through the earth and rubble left by a landslide that smothered a village in southwestern China on Saturday, looking for signs of survivors among the 100 or more people who were missing. But as night fell and the search continued under lights, hopes of pulling many alive from the rocks and earth dimmed.

headline: Health Law Repeal Leaves Nevada Republican Torn Between Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Dean Heller, Republican of Nevada, is the man everyone wants. This has not been a good thing for him.

headline: For the Kiwis, a Win Could Mean Rewriting Rules for the Next America’s Cup
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — New Zealand is one victory away from repossessing the America’s Cup, which is minimal assurance for Kiwi fans who watched through their fingers as Oracle Team USA put a fist through the top of its own coffin and came from very far down to win in 2013.

headline: Flowers, Flowers and More Flowers: How a Star Ballerina Says Goodbye
text: A ballerina’s farewell — especially at American Ballet Theater — is a time-honored drama. Rose petals fall like rain from the rafters, fellow dancers parade out to deliver bouquets, and audience members crowd the aisles, roaring as if at a rock concert.

headline: To Make Sense of American Politics, Immigrants Find Clues From Lands They Left
text: HOUSTON — Raji Alatassi watched a video clip of that recent cabinet meeting in Washington, in which the top officials in President Trump’s administration took turns heaping worshipful praise upon their leader. He felt he had seen it before.

headline: Philadelphia Phillies’ Rebuild Is a Slow Process
text: On Thursday, for the second year in a row, the Philadelphia 76ers chose first over all in the N.B.A. draft. Their fans have endured years of failure but seem convinced that the team’s highly promoted Process — capital P — will work. The 76ers have already set a franchise record for season-ticket sales, and they expect to sell out all their games.

headline: Yankees’ Youth Movement Suffers a Big Loss to Texas
text: In the 72nd game of their season, the Yankees fielded a starting lineup that would have seemed perfectly reasonable in spring training.

headline: For W.N.B.A.’s Oldest Rookie, a Lot of Persistence Goes a Long Way
text: Hours before her W.N.B.A. debut last month, Yvonne Turner joined her fellow rookies in an elaborate game of fetch.

headline: Angola’s Corrupt Building Boom: ‘Like Opening a Window and Throwing Out Money’
text: LUANDA, Angola — An ambitious reconstruction plan after Angola’s civil war was meant to reach even the country’s most faraway corner, a region known as the Land at the End of the World.

headline: Variety Puzzle: Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Upon solving this acrostic I became acutely aware of how very many Brit-centric clues we had to figure, which is an endearing and enduring sign of Emily Cox’s and Henry Rathvon’s craftsmanship. The quotation is from Rob Temple, an English social (media) commentator, sort of a 21st century Thackeray, I suppose, who began compiling awkward items about his pasty people using the hashtag #VeryBritishProblems under the Twitter handle @SoVeryBritish way back in 2012. His efforts rapidly took off, garnering a legion of followers, and spawning a cottage industry of anachronisms: T-shirts, greeting cards, a board game, books and a television show. How so last era, innit.

headline: British Parliament Hit by Cyberattack, Affecting Email Access
text: LONDON — The British Parliament was the target of a cyberattack that left many legislators unable to connect to their email on Saturday as remote access to accounts was disabled as a security measure.

headline: Nabra Hassanen and the Lost Innocence of Ramadan IHOP Nights
text: I can’t recall a Ramadan in America during my teens and 20s when I didn’t meet my Muslims friends at IHOP at 3 a.m.

headline: Men Don’t Want to Be Nurses. Their Wives Agree.
text: It seems like an easy fix. Traditionally male factory work is drying up. The fastest-growing jobs in the American economy are those that are often held by women. Why not get men to do them?

headline: The Real Threat of Artificial Intelligence
text: BEIJING — What worries you about the coming world of artificial intelligence?

headline: Sacrificing Black Lives for the American Lie
text: Why are police officers rarely charged for taking black lives, and when they are, why do juries rarely convict?

headline: From Worse to Bad on Health Care
text: THE Obamacare replacement that the House sent to the Senate might as well have had a note scrawled across its pages: Save us from ourselves.

headline: I Am Not a ‘Paki,’ Not a Terrorist. I Am Nobody but Myself.
text: TORONTO — In the summer of 2007, I was 17 and suppressing all thoughts of the future. I was facing my last year of high school and had no prospects. College might have been the logical next step, but I had always been a lousy student. Earlier that year, my father had taken a black marker to my report card, circled all the poor grades and written, “WHY?”

headline: President Trump, Meet This 2-Year-Old
text: RIVERCESS COUNTY, Liberia — He’s a 2-year-old boy named Sunday Dahn, lying in a coma in a rural health center with cerebral malaria. Even if Sunday survives, he may suffer permanent brain damage.

headline: Men Can Be So Hormonal
text: “Does being over 40 make you feel like half the man you used to be?”

headline: Islanders, in Revamp Mode, Send Travis Hamonic to the Flames
text: CHICAGO — The Islanders continued to overhaul their roster on Saturday, trading defenseman Travis Hamonic to the Calgary Flames for three high draft picks.

text: Olivier Rousteing shows his latest collection.

headline: How Many Dishes Can There Be To Wash?
text: When Ammar is late coming home, Raghida can't stop thinking about his arrest in Syria.​

headline: If We Lose Our Health Care ...
text: Republicans have demonized the Affordable Care Act for so long that people may have forgotten that nearly one in five nonelderly Americans lacked health insurance before the law was passed. Many of them didn’t get the care they needed because they feared it would bankrupt their families. The A.C.A., or Obamacare, has not solved those problems completely, but it has extended health care coverage to 20 million people.

headline: Red Auerbach Told Bill Russell, ‘I’m the Coach and You’ll Fit’
text: There are decorated athletes, and then there is Bill Russell.

headline: Donald Skunks the Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — YOU know who is really sick and tired of Donald Trump winning, to the point where they beg, “Please, Mr. President, sir, it’s too much”?

headline: She Was Named World’s Ugliest Dog, but ‘She’s Just Darling’
text: Jessica Burkard of Penngrove, Calif., saw a beautiful companion for her St. Bernard when she found Martha, a 125-pound Neapolitan mastiff.

headline: Oracle Team USA Finally Breaks Through at the America’s Cup
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — Jimmy Spithill was back in his element on Saturday: sailing hurt in a rejiggered America’s Cup yacht, with a big deficit to overcome.

headline: Hermès: Spring 2018
text: This label’s spring 2018 collection.

headline: N.H.L.’s Connor McDavid, M.V.P. at 20, Is Still Pursuing His Idol
text: LAS VEGAS — The image marks a single moment in hockey’s long history. A smiling and shaggy-haired Connor McDavid, six weeks removed from his 16th birthday, posing for a photo while standing between the Pittsburgh Penguins star Sidney Crosby and the team owner and Hall of Famer Mario Lemieux.

headline: Cropped
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — In college I spent a weekend picking cucumbers at a farm in Massachusetts, crawling on all fours as fast as I could as someone much more agile than I ran backward in front of me, holding a milk crate that I was supposed to fill with cukes at a rapid clip. Notice that I specify “a weekend” because I didn’t last, but the dream is still alive somewhere in this lily-white corpus officium. Which reminds me of a conversation with a friend, held earlier this week, about her dog’s mood disorder diagnosis and subsequent prescription. “I guess I shouldn’t be surprised that she’s depressed,” my friend said with a sigh. “She’s inside 20 of 24 hours. It’s so unnatural for living things.”

headline: Bruce Davis, a Charles Manson Follower, Has Parole Blocked for Fifth Time
text: A prison inmate who was a member of the Manson family has had his parole blocked by the governor of California for the fifth time.

headline: Red Bulls Herald Robust Rivalry, Then Cower Before N.Y.C.F.C.
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The invasions were successful on all fronts.

headline: A Buddhist Leader on China’s Spiritual Needs
text: YIXING, China — During a visit last fall to the Temple of Great Awakening, the sprawling complex built by the Buddhist organization Fo Guang Shan in Yixing, we were greeted by an unexpected host: the Venerable Master Hsing Yun, the group’s founder and one of modern China’s most prominent religious figures.

headline: Is a Buddhist Group Changing China? Or Is China Changing It?
text: YIXING, China — For most of her life, Shen Ying was disappointed by the world she saw around her. She watched China’s economic rise in this small city in the Yangtze River Valley, and she found a foothold in the new middle class, running a convenience store in a strip mall. Yet prosperity felt hollow.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Accident Waiting to Happen’: Blame in a Deadly London Fire
text: “Anyone who listened to the fire brigade and stayed where they are, they lost their lives.”

headline: Artists’ Cultural Borrowing
text: To the Editor:

headline: DeGrom, a Constant in the Mets’ Rotation, Stymies the Giants
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Despite all that has happened to the Mets’ starting rotation this season, Jacob deGrom has always been there when called upon. While he has endured some inconsistencies that have contributed to the Mets’ disappointing position in the standings, he has not missed a start. And on this team, that is an achievement.

headline: Corrections: June 25, 2017
text: SPORTS

headline: Amy Sulds, Evan Kaplan
text: Amy Cooper Sulds and Evan Hunt Kaplan are to be married June 25 at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Rabbi Eleanor Steinman is to officiate.

headline: Quinn Stuebe, Alexander Hearne
text: Katherine Quinn Stuebe and Alexander Schade Hearne were married June 24 at St. Brigid Church in Peapack, N.J. Msgr. Edward C. Puleo performed the ceremony and the Rev. Louise Kingston participated.

headline: Kristin Donnelly, Rick Bosh
text: Kristin Nicole Donnelly and J. Patrick Barry Bosh were married June 24 in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. Their friend and colleague at NBC News, Joshua Chaffee, officiated at the Inn at Rancho Santa Fe.

headline: Pia Carusone, Leanne Pittsford
text: Pia Dowd Carusone and Leanne Nicole Pittsford were married June 20 in Washington. Muriel E. Bowser, the mayor of the District of Columbia, officiated at the John A. Wilson District Building. Next month, the couple will have a ceremony that will include an exchange of rings and vows, in the mirror hall at Clärchens Ballhaus in Berlin.

headline: Victoria Alekhine, Joshua Harlan
text: Victoria Alekhine and Joshua David Harlan were married June 22 at the Lotos Club, a private literary club in New York. Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson officiated.

headline: Commando Raids on ISIS Yield Vital Data in Shadowy War
text: WASHINGTON — One late afternoon in April, helicopter-borne American commandos intercepted a vehicle in southeastern Syria carrying a close associate of the Islamic State’s supreme leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

headline: Marc Cipullo, Septime Webre

headline: In Pursuit of Millennials, More Fun in Sports. But Still No Twerking.
text: Millennials are forcing us to change the way we think about sports. And it’s a good thing, because the grown-ups have gone plum nuts.

headline: In Towns Already Hit by Steel Mill Closings, a New Casualty: Retail Jobs
text: JOHNSTOWN, Pa. — Dawn Nasewicz comes from a family of steelworkers, with jobs that once dominated the local economy. She found her niche in retail.

headline: Rare G.O.P. Species Runs for New Jersey Governor: A Moderate
text: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J. — The Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey sat on a plush beige couch in the Republican mayor’s condo, surrounded by Republican county officials and politicians, and offered up her plan to stem what is perhaps the state’s most daunting challenge — its deepening property tax crisis.

headline: Global News Quiz: King Salman Shocker, Roman Misbehavior and Indian Sedition
text: Did you stay on top of the most important stories last week from around the world? Test your knowledge of international events with our quick quiz, recapping major news headlines from across the globe. To take the quiz, click on an answer, and the correct response will be revealed after you choose.

headline: Revered and Feared in the Book Review
text: On a recent morning, Marilyn Stasio’s Upper West Side living room contained at least two dozen piles of books — arranged on shelves, peeking from bags and boxes, heaped in precarious leaning towers. “Books to the right of me, books to the left of me, books in front of me, books behind me,” she declared. “It’s terrible!”

headline: L.G.B.T.Q. Pride Around the World
text: Join the celebrations — and reflect on the range of rights — in Dublin, Shanghai, Kiev and other cities during June Pride festivities.

headline: For Grieving Parents, Trump Is ‘Speaking for the Dead’ on Immigration
text: The families could reel off all the times they had called the media and written to Washington, but after all that trying, they had never heard anyone who mattered say anything like it: Most Mexican immigrants, Donald J. Trump declared in his first campaign speech, were “rapists” who were “bringing drugs, bringing crime” across the border.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Sale of Edward Albee’s Art Collection Will Benefit His Foundation
text: Edward Albee is, of course, best known for his plays (the most famous: “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?”). But he was also a collector, and visitors to his TriBeCa loft were often struck by the museumlike array of tribal sculptures and contemporary paintings.

headline: Bloomberg’s Next Anti-Washington Move: $200 Million Program for Mayors
text: Michael R. Bloomberg will throw his financial might into helping beleaguered American mayors, creating a $200 million philanthropic program aimed at backing inventive policies at the city level and giving mayors a stronger hand in national politics.

headline: The Time to Retrieve Time’s Time Capsule Is at Hand
text: Moving day was on the calendar back in 2015, and in the executive suite in the Time & Life Building, someone said: “Oh, there’s a time capsule. We have to figure out at some point what to do with it.”

headline: A Winning Design for a New York Monument to Gay and Transgender People
text: Just as NYC Pride festivities got underway, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had some timely news on Sunday: The artist Anthony Goicolea had been chosen to design the first official monument to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people commissioned by the State of New York.

headline: Senate Leaders Try to Appease Members as Support for Health Bill Slips
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republican leaders scrambled Sunday to rally support for their health care bill as opposition continued to build inside and outside Congress, and as several Republican senators questioned whether it would be approved this week.

headline: White House Pushes Military Might Over Humanitarian Aid in Africa
text: MUA MISSION, Malawi — If ever there was an example of American and African military bonhomie, it was at a recent summit meeting here over glasses of South African Pinotage and expectations of Pentagon largess.

headline: 50 Years After War, East Jerusalem Palestinians Confront a Life Divided
text: JERUSALEM — The smoky alternative music club in downtown West Jerusalem was packed at 12:45 a.m. when a Palestinian hip-hop duo from East Jerusalem took the stage, rapping about the occupation, the police and love, among other things, mostly in Arabic.

headline: Corruption Crackdown Intensifies in Tunisia, and the People Cheer
text: TUNIS — The Tunisian prime minister has embarked on a sweeping crackdown against organized crime, arresting nearly a dozen mafia bosses and smuggling barons in recent weeks in an effort to stamp out what has become a nearly existential threat to the young democracy.

headline: ‘Transformers: The Last Knight’ Is a Box Office Clunker
text: Even star vehicles run out of gas eventually. “Transformers: The Last Knight,” the fifth installment of Michael Bay’s maximalist action series, landed with a thud at the North American box office this weekend, taking in just $45.3 million. However, its disappointing showing — easily the lowest of the franchise — was somewhat salvaged by robust business overseas.

headline: A Battle Over Prayer in Schools Tests Canada’s Multiculturalism
text: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario — The troubles began over sermons.

headline: Where Trump Zigs, Tillerson Zags, Putting Him at Odds With White House
text: WASHINGTON — When Rex W. Tillerson, the former chief executive of Exxon Mobil, arrived in Washington five months ago to become the secretary of state, his boosters said he brought two valuable assets to a job that had usually gone to someone steeped in government and diplomacy: a long history managing a global company, and deep relationships from the Middle East to Russia that enabled him to close deals.

headline: Hard Life Among the Dead in the Philippines
text: MANILA — Manila North Cemetery, opened in 1904, is one of the oldest and largest in the Philippines. Its elaborate mausoleums and endless rows of humble, stacked tombs are home to an estimated one million of the dead — and a few thousand of the living.

headline: 7 Die in India After Falling Tree Sends Gondola Cars Plummeting
text: NEW DELHI — A tree lashed by strong wind crashed onto a gondola cable in northern India on Sunday, sending two cars plunging to the rugged terrain below, the police said. Seven passengers were thrown from the cars and died, and two others were injured.

headline: Los Angeles Collective Honors Plays by Women of Color
text: Since 2014, the independent Los Angeles-based collective the Kilroys has sought to increase representation for female playwrights by publishing a list of new plays by women deemed worthy of production. This year, the group’s list has a more specific focus: female and transgender writers of color.

text: Since Preet Bharara, the former United States attorney in Manhattan, was abruptly fired in March by President Trump, speculation has swirled about what he would do next. Would he join a white-shoe law firm, as many former prosecutors do? Would he run for office?

headline: How Putin Seduced Oliver Stone — and Trump
text: Watching four hours of Oliver Stone interviewing President Vladimir Putin of Russia is not a lesson in journalism. Mr. Stone is an inept interviewer, and he does not get Mr. Putin to say anything the world hasn’t heard from him before. Watching the interviews for entertainment is a questionable proposition, too: The four-part series contains many dull exchanges and even more filler, like footage of the two men watching “Dr. Strangelove” together.

headline: Trump’s Deflections and Denials on Russia Frustrate Even His Allies
text: In the span of 72 hours, President Trump described the email hacking that roiled the 2016 campaign as a Democratic “hoax” and as clear aggression by Russia that his predecessor, President Barack Obama, failed to address.

headline: Financially Ailing CUNY Spent Over $1 Million a Year on Parades and Charities
text: When marchers streamed through Greenwich Village in the NYC Pride parade on Sunday, they did not see the usual rainbow-bedecked float with a banner of the City University of New York. But CUNY, which faces severe financial constraints and state and federal investigations into its spending practices, still paid $27,000 to be a parade sponsor — enough to cover a year’s tuition for four students.

headline: Art Gallery Closures Grow for Small and Midsize Dealers
text: The Lower East Side gallery On Stellar Rays announced in April 2016 that it was expanding into 4,500 square feet, to allow for a more ambitious exhibition program as well as performances in its basement space.

headline: Disputes Over Prince’s Estate Throw the Future of His Vault Into Question
text: Will fans ever get to hear the full depths of Prince’s storied recording vault?

headline: At K-Pop Festival, Korean Stars Align With Their Superfans
text: NEWARK — That K-pop — the pop music scene that dominates South Korea and, increasingly, the rest of the world — has not yet had a chart-topping, cross-cultural “Despacito” moment in this country is vexing. The affinities are natural — the music is thick with references to American pop, hip-hop and R&B. And it’s both decadently visual and relentlessly energetic, in a way that needs no translation.

headline: After Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis, Worries Shift to Virgin Islands
text: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I. — The United States Virgin Islands is best known for its powdery beaches and turquoise bays, a constant draw for the tourists who frequent this tiny American territory.

headline: Review: In ‘Onegin,’ Two Star Ballerinas on Contrasting Arcs
text: One definition of a balletomane is someone who cares more about dancers than about choreography, to or beyond the point of madness. John Cranko’s “Onegin” (1965) — something of a nightmare for connoisseurs of choreography — is balletomane heaven. Last week, American Ballet Theater played it with four casts at the Metropolitan Opera House. New York’s balletomanes were duly clamorous.

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: ‘The Mind of God’
text: In the ever-raging battle between faith and science, the neurologist Jay Lombard is one of those rare emissaries who communicate in the language of both camps. In his new book, “The Mind of God,” he uses his experience studying the brain to ask some of the largest philosophical questions: Does God exist? Does life have meaning? Are we free? Lombard writes that he is interested in a “large faith,” rather than a specific religion — “a faith invigorated and enlightened by science rather than being at odds with it.” Below he discusses the debates over brain and mind, his editor’s unpromising reaction to an early manuscript, his appreciation for Jerry Garcia and more.

headline: Alchemist’s Quest
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Twenty years ago, the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry entered our collective consciousness when “HARRY POTTER and THE PHILOSOPHER’S STONE,” the author J. K. ROWLING’s first novel, was published in Britain by Bloomsbury Publishing on June 26, 1997. American audiences might know the book as “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone,” however, because the publishers originally worried that Americans might not be familiar with the term “Philosopher’s Stone.”

headline: Mets Promote Tim Tebow to a Higher Class A League
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Before the Mets’ game against the San Francisco Giants on Sunday, General Manager Sandy Alderson convened reporters outside the visitors’ clubhouse at AT&T Park to make an announcement.

headline: Indian Technology Workers Worry About a Job Threat: Technology
text: PUNE, India — Last month, Sudhakar Choudhari took the company bus as usual from his one-bedroom apartment to the suburban offices of Tech Mahindra, a major employer of workers in India that powers the global technology machine behind the scenes. Then a manager took him into a conference room and asked him to resign.

headline: Is Washington’s Metro Improving? After $150 Million, Maybe
text: WASHINGTON — The installation of thousands of new electrical insulators has helped reduced track fires and smoke. Tens of thousands of new railroad ties are making for a smoother ride. Deep-cleaning crews have visited many of the grimiest concrete subterranean stations — in some cases, for the first time in years.

headline: Kenzo: Spring 2018
text: The label’s men’s 2018 collection.

headline: Israel Suspends Plan for Egalitarian Prayer Area at Western Wall
text: JERUSALEM — Yielding to pressure from his ultra-Orthodox coalition partners, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday backtracked on a decision to create a space at the Western Wall in Jerusalem where men and women can pray together and non-Orthodox rituals can be practiced.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 26
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jurors Find Video Isn’t Providing 20/20 Vision in Police Shootings
text: The body-cam video suddenly turns shaky as an Ohio police officer fires his gun into a car, leaving an unarmed black motorist dead, shot in the head. In Wisconsin, slow-motion images show an armed man lobbing his gun over a fence, then falling backward, before a police officer fires a fatal shot into his chest. And in Minnesota, a police dashboard camera captures an officer abruptly firing seven shots at the driver of a car he has stopped, as the man’s girlfriend and her young daughter watch from inside the car.

headline: Ailments and the Rangers’ Home Runs Leave the Yankees Reeling
text: Before Sunday’s game at Yankee Stadium, a parade of pinstriped alumni took the field for Old-Timers’ Day. By the end of the game, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi might have thought about recruiting a few of the retirees to bolster his drained team, which lost to the Texas Rangers, 7-6, for its 10th defeat in 12 games.

headline: E.U. Commission Approves Billions in Aid for 2 Italian Banks
text: The sometimes creaky machinery of the European Union moved swiftly on Sunday to keep the struggles of two small Italian banks from undercutting confidence in the country’s fragile banking system.

headline: Third Point, a Hedge Fund, Sets Its Activist Sights on Nestlé
text: LONDON — Over the past two decades, the hedge fund mogul Daniel S. Loeb has established himself as one of the biggest activist investors around. Now, he has set his sights on one of Europe’s largest corporate citizens: Nestlé, the global food giant.

headline: Elias Burstein, Pioneer in Semiconductors, Dies at 99
text: Elias Burstein, a pioneering physicist whose research helped pave the way for the development of silicon semiconductors, died on June 17 at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 99.

headline: Above It All, Riverside Church

headline: Which Is the Real Confederate Flag?
text: How did the Confederacy come to be symbolized in the flag that roils American politics to this day?

headline: Takata, Unable to Overcome Airbag Crisis, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: TOKYO — Takata, the Japanese auto parts maker crippled by vast airbag recalls, filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States and Japan and said it would sell its surviving operations to a Chinese-owned American rival, Key Safety Systems.

headline: Team New Zealand, Rising Power, Closes In on the America’s Cup
text: HAMILTON, Bermuda — Four years later, with Emirates Team New Zealand back at match point against Oracle Team USA, this edition of the America’s Cup is certainly about the bikes. But it is also about gambling on youth and daring design.

headline: In Advertising Paradise, Reality Is Just a Conversation Away
text: CANNES, France — The top hitters in media and advertising descended on the beaches of southern France last week, lounging on yachts and sipping wine and frozen rosé slushies as the sun sparkled on the cerulean water of the French Riviera. They networked and cut deals at parties in chic hotels — the type where rooms cost $500 a night.

headline: With Trump Set to Meet Narendra Modi, Many U.S. Indians Are Hopeful
text: JERSEY CITY — With Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India set to meet President Trump on Monday for the first time, many Indians in communities like this one have had high hopes for the relationship between the two leaders — both of whom swept to power as media-savvy political outsiders pledging to revive their national economies.

headline: Quotation of the Day: From Deep Grief, a Solid Bond With Trump on Border Policy
text: “It was almost an out-of-body experience after being so deeply hurt and nobody listening and nobody wanting to talk to you about this.”

headline: European Forum Looks at Productivity, and Britain Rules on Fox’s Sky Bid
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: Italian Runoff Elections Boost Center-Right Parties
text: ROME — Center-right parties scored victories Sunday evening in runoff elections in more than 100 Italian towns and cities, a result that emboldened right-wing parties, raised the prospect of shifting coalitions and took the political temperature of Italy ahead of national elections expected within the next year.

headline: Political, Provocative and Always a Party: New York City’s Pride March
text: New York City’s annual Pride March was founded as a civil rights demonstration and a remembrance for those lost to illness and violence. This year’s march included a protest against gun violence. But the event is also known as the city’s biggest early-summer party, and Sunday’s march was no exception. Thousands lined the streets of Manhattan waving rainbow flags, and costumes were ever colorful (albeit, sometimes barely there).

headline: At the Pride Parade, the N.B.A. Embraces Hard-Won Victories
text: Rick Welts, the president of the Golden State Warriors, arrived at New York’s Pride March on Sunday with his partner, Todd Gage, wearing a T-shirt that read, “Proud Champions.” While the shirt commemorated the Warriors’ recent romp through the N.B.A. playoffs, its graphics were not confined to the team’s blue and gold but shaded in the colors of the rainbow.

headline: At Cannes, the Great Gusher of Content Comes With Warning Signs
text: CANNES, France — I imagine that covering the annual Cannes Lions advertising festival here is a little bit like covering the great Texas oil boom a century ago — only with better food, cocktails and scenery.

headline: Review: In ‘Measure for Measure,’ Desperately Seeking Solutions in a Problem Play
text: It’s hard to know what to do about “Measure for Measure,” the kind of play for which Shakespeare’s “problem plays” were named. It includes some of the finest moral argumentation in the canon: thrilling back-and-forths between well-matched antagonists with a great deal on the line.

headline: Progress in a Sweep for the Mets, and in a Win for a Shaky Pitcher
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When Rafael Montero first reached the major leagues with the Mets in the spring of 2014, he was regarded as a better pitching prospect than Jacob deGrom.

headline: No Corrections: June 26, 2017
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Is a Facial Worth the Fuss?
text: For the beauty do-it-yourselfer, we live in boom times. Between masks and eye strips and deep-cleaning products and YouTube videos on face massage, you can do a pretty good approximation of a spa facial in the confines of your home for a fraction of the price.

text: We are honoring the top winners of our Eighth Annual Found Poem Student Contest by publishing their work from June 13 to July 3. You’ll be able to read the whole collection here as we go.

headline: Cuomo’s Use of Troopers in New York City Frustrates Police Leaders
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has embarked on an unprecedented campaign to put the stamp of the State Police on New York City, rerouting troopers to city airports and toll plazas from upstate areas that rely on them and bewildering some of the officials charged with carrying out his orders.

headline: No Frills, No Crowds, No Money: The Lonely Road to Tennis Glory

headline: Yoplait Learns to Manufacture Authenticity to Go With Its Yogurt

headline: A Utopia for a Dystopian Age
text: The term “utopia” was coined 500 years ago. By conjoining the Greek adverb “ou” (“not”) and the noun “topos” (“place”) the English humanist and politician Thomas More conceived of a place that is not — literally a “nowhere” or “noplace.” More’s learned readers would also have recognized another pun. The pronunciation of “utopia” can just as well be associated with “eu-topia,” which in Greek means “happy place.” Happiness, More might have suggested, is something we can only imagine. And yet imagining it, as philosophers, artists and politicians have done ever since, is far from pointless.

headline: Progress on Gay Rights in Serbia, With a Catch
text: Serbia hardly has a progressive track record on gay rights. So when President Aleksandar Vucic announced this month that he was nominating Ana Brnabic, a 41-year-old, openly lesbian, woman as prime minister, he stunned Serbians and outside observers alike.

headline: Where the Senate Health Care Bill Fails
text: Speaking at a rally for his wife’s presidential campaign last year, Bill Clinton called Obamacare “the craziest thing in the world.” As he put it, “The people who are out there busting it, sometimes 60 hours a week, wind up with their premiums doubled and their coverage cut in half.”

headline: College Students Want to Talk About Sex. They Just Don’t Know How.

headline: The Iran Puzzle

The most important manifestation of that effort was a deal negotiated by the administration and its allies under which Iran agreed to curb its nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of economic sanctions.

headline: Socialism’s Future May Be Its Past
text: One hundred years after Lenin’s sealed train arrived at Finland Station and set into motion the events that led to Stalin’s gulags, the idea that we should return to this history for inspiration might sound absurd. But there was good reason that the Bolsheviks once called themselves “social democrats.” They were part of a broad movement of growing parties that aimed to fight for greater political democracy and, using the wealth and the new working class created by capitalism, extend democratic rights into the social and economic spheres, which no capitalist would permit.

headline: A ’70s Summer With Warhol and the Kennedys
text: In 1972, the legendary filmmaker, poet and artist Jonas Mekas captured a golden summer in Montauk at the Warhol estate, which Lee Radziwill rented for the season. He was employed by Radziwill’s sister, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, to teach her children, John F. Kennedy Jr. and Caroline Kennedy, photography and filmmaking. What resulted are dozens of images of languid summer days in the Hamptons, which are now on view in a photographic exhibition.

text: Barbara Hodgin, who was once president of the Pacific Crest Trail Association, is old enough to remember a time when, if you asked a backpacker what was for dinner, the standard answer was either “brown in a cup” or “green in a cup.” A clever hack for trail pad thai was an envelope of unsweetened lime Kool-Aid.

headline: A Surprise Collection, From Stefano Pilati, Revealed on Instagram

Yet there he was one afternoon, in Florence, Italy, during the Pitti Uomo men’s wear fair, taking in the J. W. Anderson fashion show as guests goggled over his cloven-hoofed Margiela boots; there he was again a week later, watching Kim Jones’s Louis Vuitton show; and yet again, this time as an unannounced model for the upstart line GmbH, which, like Mr. Pilati, is based in Berlin.

headline: Chefs Join the Swing Dancers at Damrosch Park
text: Dancing, dining and drinking are the summer outdoor attractions at Lincoln Center. This year, some well-known chefs will add their specialties to the food stands that have been on hand for many seasons. Épicerie Boulud will be up first on Tuesday and Wednesday with madeleines and canelés. Michael White of Altamarea Group is next with bacon palmiers. Motorino’s meatballs, financiers from Maison Kayser, David Burke’s cheesecake lollipops, François Payard’s macarons and David Chang’s Fuku chicken sandwiches will join the rotating menu served from 5 to 10 p.m. through Aug. 13 during Midsummer Night Swing and Out of Doors events: Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center.

headline: Dainty Invader: the Deptford Pink
text: It is hard to call a flower as dainty and attractive as the Deptford pink invasive. It seems incapable of threatening anything, but it is a plant originally native to Europe now growing with ease throughout most of North America, and it fits the definition. The plant has roots that lead back to the English town of Deptford.

headline: The Detective Was a Performance Artist. The Evidence Is Now a Show.
text: Aware of the artist Alison S. M. Kobayashi’s interest in “lost, discarded and donated objects,” as she put it, friends of friends of hers passed along a wire recorder — a clunky predecessor to the tape recorder — that came with two reels’ worth of chitchat. Nobody had any idea of where or when these recordings had been made, or by whom. Slowly she started identifying distinct speakers and figured out they were related.

headline: For the Griller Who Really Does Have Everything
text: A perfect burger is a work of culinary art. And to honor it, the German cutlery company Wüsthof has introduced a knife engineered to enhance the burger experience. Before you dismiss it as an expensive toy less useful than an asparagus peeler or avocado slicer, consider how well the generous rounded tip of the stainless-steel blade scoops and spreads condiments, how the fine serrations near the comfortable handle can cut through the bun without tearing, and how well the sharper edge slices neatly through the juicy meat: Wüsthof Gourmet Burger Knives, $99.95 for four, Williams-Sonoma stores, 877-812-6235, williams-sonoma.com.

headline: Jury Selection in Martin Shkreli Trial Begins With Name Calling

headline: Edwidge Danticat Wrestles With Death, in Life and in Art
text: Death and grief haunt Edwidge Danticat’s fiction and nonfiction — ghosts from her own family’s losses, and the sufferings of Haiti (where she was born and spent the first 12 years of her life) over the decades from poverty, murderous paramilitary thugs and a devastating 2010 earthquake that left an estimated 220,000 to 316,000 dead.

headline: Crossing the Line Festival Includes a Dancer’s Mini-Residency

headline: The Best of Paris Men’s Fashion Week
text: How best to sum up the Paris spring/summer 2018 men’s wear shows? Long days, short shorts and designers vying to up the ante and push fashion toward the monumental and long-lasting. The shows, which concluded Sunday, didn’t just feature great collections — it was filled with shows that we’ll certainly remember for a long time to come. With a schedule swelled by newcomers, Paris Fashion Week was — once again — in a league of its own.

headline: BET Awards 2017: Red Carpet Looks
text: Yara Shahidi, Jada Pinkett Smith and Future were among those who attended the BET Awards on June 25.

headline: Review: In BET’s ‘Tales,’ Rap Lyrics Get Lost in Translation
text: Years ago, Chuck D of the group Public Enemy called rap “the black CNN.” Now “Tales,” an anthology series beginning Tuesday on BET, asks if rap can also be HBO — a font of stories instead of headlines.

headline: Sick and Afraid, Some Immigrants Forgo Medical Care
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Dr. Luke Smith drove slowly through the unlit streets of a neighborhood filled with immigrants, searching for an address among small houses with windows ribbed by iron bars. Pharmacy bags lay at his feet.

headline: Iced Tea Is the Focus at This New Store
text: The city’s latest branded tea store is to open on Wednesday, this one from Pure Leaf, a company that sells teas meant to be served with ice. Gabriel Dela Vega, the store’s mixologist, will prepare an array of iced teas at a long bar in a soothing setting with lots of greenery. Golden chai, apple-flavored tea with a matcha float, green mojito tea with lime and mint, peach tea and rare Kenyan purple tea with berries are among the drinks sold in house or to take out ($5 to $8). Each will be finished with a splash of liquid tea essence pressed from fresh leaves to amplify the flavor: Pure Leaf Tea House, 79 Greene Street (Spring Street), pureleaf.com.

headline: Firefighters Battle Blazes in California and Utah
text: Firefighters are battling strong winds and the potential for triple-digit temperatures as they try to contain separate wildfires in Utah and California. In Utah, more than a thousand firefighters are still struggling to contain a huge fire that started on June 17 near Brian Head, a ski town. In Santa Clarita, Calif., north of Los Angeles, those who had been evacuated are now being allowed to return to their homes, and an official said on Monday that the fire was almost under control.

headline: 200 Years Ago, Erie Canal Got Its Start as Just a ‘Ditch’
text: On July 4, 1817, Judge John Richardson, who was also a local contractor, officially broke ground with a ceremonial spade, then unleashed the team of oxen he had hitched to his plow in a nondescript field in upstate Rome, N.Y., to begin construction of what eight years later would become the Erie Canal.

headline: Work Less. You’ll Get So Much More Done.
text: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice on living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: Steak Sampler Ready for Summer Grilling
text: When it comes to steak on the grill, one way to answer the question “Which steak is best?” is a side-by-side comparison. A new boneless strip loin sampler from New York Prime Beef makes that easy. Dry-aged American Wagyu, Japanese Kobe and dry-aged prime New York strip are included in this two-and-a-half-pound package, enough to serve four to six people. My crowd voted for the American Wagyu. The fresh steaks are shipped overnight: Strip Sampler Collection, $250 including shipping, 800-783-2569, newyorkprimebeef.com.

headline: Amtrak Picks Delta’s Former Chief to Lead It Through Challenging Time
text: Amtrak, the national passenger railroad that has been struggling to maintain its tracks in New York City, said Monday that it had chosen an airline industry veteran to be its next chief executive.

headline: Red Carpet: BET Awards 2017
text: Chance the Rapper, Solange, Migos, Bruno Mars and Beyoncé were among the artists honored onstage at the 2017 BET Awards. But who won the red carpet?

headline: Theater Jobs Skew White and Male, Study Finds
text: Women and minority actors and stage managers are getting fewer jobs and often wind up in lower-paying shows than white male theater artists, according to a new study by Actors’ Equity.

headline: Review: Chasing ‘The Rivals’ on a Summer Evening
text: “Quickly, quickly, now,” a servant in breeches and waistcoat urged, shooing the audience down a slope of lawn and onto a curving lamplit path to the duel. “Who lives, who dies — we’ll all find out!”

headline: Review: A Bawdy ‘Bastard Jones,’ Dancing With a Peg Leg
text: “Bastard Jones” opens with our hero, Tom Jones, in a close encounter of the sexual kind with a randy maid. When they emerge from behind a sheet, happily sated, she helps him screw his peg back onto his stump.

headline: Airlines Redesigning Uniforms Find Out How Complicated It Is
text: Long ago, airline uniforms reflected the glamour of flight. Now, they have to serve more utilitarian needs. Do they reflect the airline’s image? Will they look good on most everyone? And, perhaps most important, are they comfortable?

headline: Review: A Father Consumed by Grief in ‘My Eyes Went Dark’
text: On July 2, 2002, a passenger jet collided in midair with a cargo plane over Germany, killing 71 people. It was a mistake caused by technical issues and a slow response from the sole air traffic controller. Stricken by grief, Vitaly Kaloyev, a Russian architect who lost his family in the crash, sought revenge and ultimately got it.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee May Get Military Trial Over Bombings in Indonesia
text: WASHINGTON — Military commission prosecutors at the Guantánamo Bay wartime prison have charged a high-profile detainee with two deadly terrorist bombings in Indonesia, setting in motion what could become the first new tribunals case of the Trump era.

headline: Grayson Perry on ‘Divided Britain’ and His New Art Exhibition
text: LONDON — The artist and media personality Grayson Perry has made himself a household name in Britain by sculpting flamboyant engraved pots, stitching bold tapestries that grapple with modern social issues, and dressing, for some public appearances, as his female alter ego, Claire.

headline: By Criticizing Obama, Trump Contradicts His Own Comments on Russian Meddling
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump has accused his predecessor of “doing nothing” in response to Russia’s interference in the 2016 election — a misleading statement that contradicts his previous comments.

headline: New Gin Conjures the Flavors of the Forest
text: Terra Botanical Gin is the latest spirit to tempt your tonic and lime. Made by Cardinal Spirits, of Indiana, Terra Botanical is decidedly herbal, more reminiscent of pine woods with notes of mint and earth than the more typical juniper-forward London dry style. “I wanted this gin to have complexity, be smooth and to be good for sipping plain, not just in a cocktail,” said Lior Lev Sercarz, the spice blender who created the gin’s flavor profile. At 84 proof, this grape-based spirit shines through when combined with tonic or other mixers: Terra Botanical Gin, $33.99 at Mashbill Wine & Spirits, 24 Avenue C (Third Street), $34.99 online; 212-228-7510, mashandgrape.com.

headline: Waymo and Avis Reach Deal Over Self-Driving Cars’ Maintenance
text: Waymo, the self-driving-car unit spun off by Google’s parent company, outfits its autonomous vehicles with sophisticated sensors and other digital technology. But its fleet has decidedly low-tech needs too.

headline: Why Grown-Up Muggles Should Read ‘Harry Potter’
text: I started reading the “Harry Potter” series, which turns 20 today, in a dormitory in Hod HaSharon, Israel, alongside about two dozen other teenage muggles who had flown (by plane) from the United States. I’d completely succumbed to Potter hysteria at a friend’s urging even before I’d read the books, so the night before I left, I hadn’t hesitated to make room for the first four of them, all in hardback, by tossing out an extra pair of pants. Who needed pants? I wanted a good story.

headline: To Photograph a Galápagos Tortoise, Get Out of the Race
text: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, the photographer Federico Rios Escobar explains how he drew a particularly large subject out of her proverbial shell at a recent (and spontaneous) shoot for a Travel section cover story on the Galápagos Islands.

headline: Senator Puts Hold on Arms Sales to Persian Gulf Nations Over Qatar Feud
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said on Monday that he was putting a hold on any future American arms sales to a group of Persian Gulf nations in an apparent move to help resolve a bitter dispute between one of those countries, Qatar, and several of its Arab neighbors.

headline: Mayors, Sidestepping Trump, Vow to Fill Void on Climate Change
text: MIAMI BEACH — Meeting in a city confronted daily with the issues of rising seas and climate change, the United States Conference of Mayors approved resolutions on Monday to urge the federal government to rejoin the Paris climate agreement and to redouble their own efforts to combat climate change and commit to renewable energy.

headline: The Travel Ban at the Supreme Court
text: President Trump cares a lot about winning, or at least the appearance of it. So he was predictably quick to sound off in triumph after the Supreme Court announced on Monday morning that in October it would consider the legality of his revised travel ban and will allow the ban to take partial effect in the meantime. The justices’ decision, he said, was “a clear victory for our national security.”

headline: Shareholders Demand More Drastic Shifts at Nestlé
text: Nestlé, the Swiss food giant that helps bring the world Stouffer’s frozen dinners, Kit Kat candy bars and even L’Oréal hair coloring, is feeling pressure to change its corporate recipe.

headline: Few Overseas Have Faith in Trump’s Leadership, Survey Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Faith in American leadership has plunged in many nations around the world in the months since President Trump took office, according to a new survey, underscoring the challenges facing the new president as he prepares to make his second overseas trip next week.

headline: E.P.A. Official Pressured Scientist on Congressional Testimony, Emails Show
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency’s chief of staff pressured the top scientist on the agency’s scientific review board to alter her congressional testimony and play down the dismissal of expert advisers, his emails show.

headline: Kushner Adds Prominent Lawyer Abbe Lowell to Defense Team
text: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and adviser, has added to his legal team one of the nation’s most prominent trial lawyers, Abbe D. Lowell, his lawyers said on Monday.

headline: Street Sign Honoring Jimmy Breslin Is Gone Too Soon, Family Says
text: From the start, there appeared to be something slightly off about the street sign unveiled by Mayor Bill de Blasio in late May in honor of Jimmy Breslin, the muckraking journalist and Queens-born columnist for The Daily News.

headline: Pearl Automation, Founded by Apple Veterans, Shuts Down
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Pearl Automation, a Silicon Valley start-up founded by former Apple employees who tried to combine Apple’s dedication to quality with a more open corporate culture, has gone out of business.

headline: A 20-Pound Lobster Impresses Airport Security, but It’s No Record Breaker
text: On a conveyor belt of bags, purses and laptops at Boston Logan International Airport on Sunday, one meaty package was clamoring for an additional security screening. Next to the rest of the luggage that morning, it was a fish out of water and appeared overstuffed, perhaps too big to fit under an airplane seat.

headline: With Crowding in U.S. Market, Activist Investors Look to Europe
text: Activist investors — money managers who seek to shake up a company’s strategy in search of huge paydays — have been growing in size and power in the United States, bending the knees of even the biggest corporate titans.

headline: Can Good Corporate Citizenship Be Measured?
text: If you spend time around corporate boardrooms these days, you’ll hear the abbreviation “E.S.G.” thrown around with such frequency it is almost a trope.

headline: For Dodgers’ Cody Bellinger, the Sky’s Not Only the Limit, It’s a Target
text: LOS ANGELES — Clay Bellinger played high school baseball in Oneonta, N.Y., in the shadow of Cooperstown. He hit .193 over four major league seasons, but collected more championship rings than many members of the hallowed institution near his hometown: the National Baseball Hall of Fame. Bellinger played for four teams, and each one reached the World Series.

headline: Trump Meets India’s Leader, a Fellow Nationalist Battling China for His Favor
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, two nationalist leaders with a shared passion for social media, met on Monday as India sought to vie with China for Mr. Trump’s favor in the region.

headline: D’Angelo Russell, Happy for a Fresh Start, Is Ready to Lead the Nets His Way
text: D’Angelo Russell did not behave like a 21-year-old who had been slighted when he took part in his introductory Nets news conference on Monday.

headline: For Men Cleared in Jogger Case, Belated Pomp and Circumstance
text: The auditorium in the northwest Bronx was speckled with balloons. Balloons that said, “Congrats Grad!” and “You’re so special!” Balloons arranged on stage in columns of white, blue and yellow. Balloons in the shape of champagne bottles. And a parade of shiny floating letters that spelled out “Graduate of 2017.”

headline: Yankees’ Jacoby Ellsbury, Back From Concussion, Swiftly Finds His Role
text: CHICAGO — Jacoby Ellsbury seemed to have a strong sense of opening day expectation as he spoke before the Yankees began a four-game series against the Chicago White Sox on Monday night.

headline: President Michel Temer of Brazil Is Charged With Corruption
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Michel Temer was charged with corruption by Brazil’s prosecutor general late Monday. He was accused of taking a $152,000 bribe via an intermediary, an act that, according to the prosecutor general, Rodrigo Janot, “helped to compromise the image of the Federal Republic of Brazil.”

headline: U.N. Brought Cholera to Haiti. Now It Is Fumbling Its Effort to Atone.
text: Even as the United Nations expresses growing alarm over a cholera outbreak in war-ravaged Yemen, the organization is increasingly worried about the fallout from a stubborn cholera scourge in Haiti that was caused by its own peacekeepers more than six years ago.

headline: Hope Ryden, Wildlife Protector and Photographer, Dies at 87
text: Hope Ryden, whose lifelike photographs of North American beavers, coyotes, mustangs and other wildlife helped elevate them into poster animals for conservation campaigns, died on June 18 in Hyannis, Mass. She was 87.

headline: 3 CNN Journalists Resign After Retracted Story on Trump Ally

headline: Pharmacist Gets 9-Year Prison Term in Deadly Meningitis Outbreak
text: BOSTON — The tainted injection left Rachelle Shuff with pain that requires 15 medications to manage and, she said, perhaps only two years to live.

headline: Andrew Cuomo to Call Special Session to Extend Mayoral Control of Schools
text: ALBANY — Acting to avert a leadership crisis in New York City’s schools amid a legislative stall in the Capitol, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo intends to call a special session of the State Legislature as early as Wednesday and introduce a bill that would extend mayoral control of the city’s educational system for one year.

headline: The Senate’s Secretly Bipartisan Health Bill
text: In 2010, when Democrats passed the Affordable Care Act, Republicans complained that they did so with no Republican support. Democrats responded by pointing out that the centerpiece of their plan — tax credits to buy private insurance — came from a Republican governor, Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

headline: Australia, Diverse and Graying. Also: Johnny Depp, and a Controversial Push to Decrypt

headline: Fact Check: The Senate Health Care Plan

headline: Syria Will ‘Pay a Heavy Price’ for Another Chemical Attack, White House Says
text: WASHINGTON — The White House said late Monday that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria appeared to be preparing another chemical weapons attack, and warned that he would “pay a heavy price” if one took place.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Shopping Without Instagram: It’s Full of Surprises
text: Juoksentelisinkohan is a Finnish word that translates to “I wonder if I should run around aimlessly.” Retail is increasingly a space for brand experience more than actual commerce. But brand-as-destination requires established familiarity, a digital history. Foot traffic in successful stores is rarely aimless.

headline: An Untamed Island Meets Its Match
text: As I stood on the splintered boat dock with John Anderson looking south across Mississippi Sound to Horn Island, his lion’s mane of hair blew straight back, as if we were already bumping across the water, underway for the island. But the Gulf of Mexico was especially choppy, and the boat I hired was heeding small-craft warnings. Horn lay eight miles offshore, a hyphen on the horizon’s hazy line. Still, it felt within our grasp. “The fact that I can’t always go makes me value the island even more,” he said.

headline: A Welcome Payday for Obscure Teams in the Champions League
text: As they wrapped up the final days of training and preparation at their camp in Slovenia, the players and coaches of Trepca ’89 still had no idea how they would get to the biggest match of their lives.

headline: The Weird, Mystic Pull of Southwest England
text: Go ahead, say their names: Avalon and Tintagel. Believe deeply enough, and they might emerge from the mouth as through an enchantment-induced vapor, as though borne on the breath of a dragon. (Especially after at least four people have corrected your pronunciation of Tintagel: Be gentle with that “g,” it’s tin-TAJ-l.) And, indeed, these two sites in the southwest of England are epic and romantic, the stuff of myth and mystery.

headline: The Weird, Mystic Pull of Southwest England
text: The area is a place of pilgrimage for late-model would-be knights of the Round Table, as well as mystical seekers of many stripes.
